		<shortDescription>An enjoyable romp but when the end justifies the means, one shouldn't call it a documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had just written a review for a documentary by Werner Herzog, where I stated that, although Herzog will at times "spice" scenes up a little to fit his vision, he generally doesn't push points, opinions or believes on his viewers. After all, that's what documentaries should do: Show what is and not what you think or believe there is. Then I thought of the complete opposite to Herzogs style and the first thing that came to mind was Michael Moore and his "Bowling for Columbine".Don't get me wrong: I did enjoy the documentary, it was very entertaining and (for a non-American) at times even educational to watch. It gives the outsider a deeper look into the American psyche, but I think, if I was an American ? hence having to choose whether I'm "pro" or "contra", which the film virtually forces the viewer ? I would have enjoyed it much less. For one, I don't like to be manipulated. If a documentary like this one tries so very hard to get a point or opinion across, that it no longer shies away from bending facts or manipulating through style, it ceases to be a documentary and becomes propaganda (or, in the slightly milder form, a mondo-documentary like "Mondo Carne").I also get a little nervous when the rhetoric is so geared and pointed, despite often being very entertaining. That may well have to do with my background: I'm German and we had some bad experiences with rhetoric some 80 years ago. However, more than 10 years after it's release, "Bowling for Columbine" seems to have sparked a whole wave of this form of documentaries (for the lack of a better term), being used by both sides. To mind come films like "Supersize Me" (where a vegetarian tries to convince the viewer that eating at McDonalds every day is unhealthy) or "Expelled ? No Intelligence Allowed" (where a religious fanatic try to convince the viewers that school-kids should be taught science according to his holy book), etc. Not a good sign when how you say something becomes more convincing than what you say.An American friend of mine, who seems to be slightly more neutral on political subjects, once pointed out that the so-called "Left" a la Michael Moore and the "Right" like Rush Limbaugh are just two sides of the same coin. If that is true, I would suggest a new currency.So, how to grade such a film? As a "real" documentary I'd give it 2/10, as an entertaining piece of polemic 7/10 and to stay on the neutral side 5/10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Unconvincing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In this documentary, Michael Moore attempts to explain the reason that America has the gun violence it does. In the process he examines a number of claims but fails, unfortunately, to come up with any meaningful answers. For example, he visits Columbine High School outside of Denver which, as everyone probably knows, had the terrible school shooting back in 1999. He points to a nearby factory owned by Lockheed-Martin and speculates that there is a connection between the making of military ordinance and the school shootings. To me that argument just wasn't compelling because I don't believe that Dylan Klebold or Eric Harris killed 12 students in cold blood because of a nearby plant that produces missiles. He then gives statistics of other industrialized societies and compares their gun violence records against that of America. He goes on to suggest that since Canada has almost as many guns (per person) as America that the prevalence of guns is not the reason for our fatality rates. Again, I found the comparison unconvincing for several reasons, primarily because not only is Canada more rural than the U.S., but it also has social programs in place which take better care of its citizens. In other words, the comparison is one of apples to oranges. He then examines the factor of "white fear" and implies that some of this gun violence is due to racism against blacks. To a certain extent he may be correct. George Zimmerman probably fits this diagnoses quite well. However, it should be remembered that it isn't the whites who are committing a huge proportion of the violent crime. And saying this isn't racist?it's factual. The bottom line is that the U.S. is inundated with over 250 million guns and it is relatively easy to obtain one at any given day?with thousands upon thousands more being pumped out by the gun manufacturers every month. Throw in things like poverty, fear and illegal drugs into this volatile mix and the results are plain to see as they are splashed across our newspapers and television screens every day. In short, although Michael Moore asked a lot of questions in this film, I wasn't quite convinced that he had the right answers. I rate it as average.</fullReview>

This is a film every American should see.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-11-25</date>
		<username>Ronin47 (samurai1978@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Funny and incisive, but a bit muddled (***)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore's latest documentary is a powerful, thought-provoking, and frequently very funny examination of gun violence in America. Among the questions raised: why, in countries like Canada, where there are just as many people with guns, are there only a few gun murders every year, and America has upwards of 11,000? Moore is quick to disprove foolish people who would say things like "violence in movies" or "Marilyn Manson", because people everywhere (including Canada) watch loads of violent movies and listen to lots of angry music. So what is it?Moore knows that a definitive answer can't be found to this question, but he takes a look at it from several different angles that are usually very involving.And even though it is very funny a lot of the time, there are scenes that will take your breath away. Columbine is, of course, a frequent point of conversation, and at one point we see actual surveillance camera footage of the massacre. Though nothing graphic is shown, the effect of the footage (mostly of students hiding under tables and running for cover while Harris and Klebold wander from room to room shooting) is so startling and immediate that I didn't even notice tears had welled up in my eyes until they were already there.There is another quick montage of suicides and murders caught on film that, again, even though the camera cuts away before any blood is actually seen, the effect on the audience is like a punch in the stomach. If anything really brings home the ugliness of gun violence, that is it.The movie is very powerful, but there are a few problems. Moore attempts to cover the story from too many angles and in the end, has talked about so many different societal ills that it's hard to see how they all tie together, even if they do. As a result it's too long (no matter how interesting the subject matter, 2 hours is usually pushing it for a documentary) and the point he's trying to make seems diluted by the end. I give the movie 3 stars because of these slight flaws and for its overall enjoyment level, but it's an extremely important movie that I urge you to go see. Though you may not always agree with what Moore is saying or doing, he deserves praise for at least caring enough to make people think about important topics, and doing it in an entertaining and enlightening way.It's the kind of movie you should go see with friends and go out to dinner for conversation afterwards. I should know, because I went alone, and I was dying to join in one of the many passionate conversations going on in the lobby when it was over.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>exdumpling</username>

		<shortDescription>Largely unbiased &amp; deeply moving... wow!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My initial reaction is... wow! Deeply moving. It was hard to believe that I had just sat through a 2 hour long documentary. When it was over, I was not ready for it to be over. Unlike other feature-length documentaries, it held my attention for every minute.I think Michael Moore's main reason for making this movie was to get people to THINK in a different way about the gun/violence issue in America. Bowling for Columbine definitely succeeded in this area. Upon leaving the theater, I got in a 2 hour long discussion with the people I saw the movie with. The little gears in my head were turning. This movie made me see the entire issue in a new light.If this movie had any specific agenda to push, it was very difficult to discover. The best thing I could come up with as Michael Moore's "thesis" per se is that the USA is a society of fear. It is profitable to keep people afraid (sales of home security systems, firearms, etc...) thus the media, popular culture, etc perpetuates the myth that there is a "bad guy" around every corner (specifically a black bad guy) just waiting to pounce. Americans constantly live in fear, unlike our Canadian neighbors.Yes, Michael Moore is probably a leftist, but he does a great job of showing all the sides of these issues. He does not leave us with a conclusion of what "the answer" is... but, as I said before, this movie will really make you THINK!See this movie!!! Well worth the time and your $8!</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Moore shoots a Strike with "Bowling for Columbine"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I walked into Bowling for Columbine with my grade 12 English Writing class it was with mixed expectations. On one hand missing a day's worth of classes with a legitimate reason is always fun, but on the other hand I would be in store for nearly two hours of what could very possibly be an extremely boring film. Having heard almost nothing about it, I didn't know what to expect, but as the lights began to dim and the hushed whispers of the almost 60 teenagers cramped into the theater gradually died down, I sat back and let myself get swept away by what I think is arguably one of the truest, most thought provoking films ever.Bowling for Columbine is an eye opening experience, a film that shows you the true nature of the United States giving us a real look at American politics and not just the sugar coated CNN version of them. Michael Moore takes us on journey through the seedy underworld, the dark bowels of the country, where all its shameful acts remain hidden from international scrutiny. As a Canadian who's always harboured something of an Anti-American sentiment I found this film refreshingly rewarding. Moore not only sheds light on America's less than reputable dark secrets but also goes out in the open and talks with Americans about their personal philosophies, namely their ridiculous obsession with guns. Moore has impeccable screen presence, as he chats with the Americans in such a deliciously patronizing manner that the unsuspecting rednecks are made fools of without even knowing. The film drips with satire with brief interludes of Chris Rock's hilarious stand up comedy pertaining to gun control to a hilarious cartoon entitled "A Brief History of the United States of America" that runs through the series of events that made America such a great nation, from the massacre of the Native Indians, the random burnings of the Salem Witch trials, the exploitation of blacks for slavery, to the "coincidental" simultaneous formation of the KKK and NRA, followed by the Rosa Parks inspired black uprising, all the way to the gentrification of today's white suburbs.It's not all fun and games though, while most of it will have you chuckling to yourself Bowling for Columbine is a serious film that does in fact deal with the titular school. Using the tapes from Columbine High's security camera's Michael Moore shows us the horrible footage of the Columbine High massacre. The haunting ambient music playing in time with the slow motion footage of students being shot at and blown up leaves the audience in a state of open mouthed shock and left at least one member my class in tears. And that's really the goal of the film, Michael Moore assaults us with shocking images of violent acts not to terrify us, nor to entertain the sadistic, but rather to educate us all about the increasing danger of "firearm-mania".Bowling for Columbine made me laugh, it made me think, but above all things it made me incredibly proud to be Canadian. Seeing Moore dumbfounded and utterly amazed at the Canadian way of life: the healthcare, the violence free cities , the general friendliness and peaceability of the people, made me glad I live in "The True North Strong And Free" and feel sorry for those who didn't. I may have walked in unsure about the movie, but I left the theater knowing one thing for certain. Bowling for Columbine is brilliant. It's true, honest film making at it's best, and there's simply no way anyone in their right minds can disagree.5 1/2 stars out of 5</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Go see this thing!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before I touch on some details from the film over which Michael Moore is getting flack, I'd like to happily declare that this is the best and most satisfying $8.50 CAN I spent on a movie in a long long time. "Bowling for Columbine" is so insightful, so honest, so spirited and above all - right on target that it hurts. There isn't a movie, TV broadcast (Nightline, Frontline, 60 Minutes...), or a newspaper investigative report out there that better summarizes the issues around the problem of gun violence in America today.Now, I noticed that some reviewers take Moore to task over his tactics in interviews with Dick Clark and Charlton Heston. I most definitely didn't have a problem with either one. In the first instance, Moore didn't accuse Clark of anything, as somebody wrongly pointed out here. Issue centered around a single black woman whose 9-year-old son found a gun in his uncle's house (kid was living there because his mother and him were evicted as she couldn't pay the rent), took it to school and killed a classmate. Before the killing, kid barely had a chance to spend time with his mom who was in a work-for-welfare program. Moore simply wanted to get Clark's opinion on this woman's situation and the fact that she as a single mother was assigned by the State of Michigan to work in one of Clark's theme restaurants 60 miles away from her home in order to earn her welfare money. Time spent in the restaurant with commuting back and fourth effectively took her away from her child as she literally worked from dawn 'till dusk while the money earned ended up not even being enough to pay the rent. That however, didn't stop Clark's restaurant from applying for a tax exemption on the grounds that it employs welfare cases. THESE ARE ALL FACTS AND MOORE MERELY STATED THEM. He then, successfully I might add, argued that this state program of busing poor people miles away from where they live and forcing them into odd jobs to get basic welfare is wrong, especially if they're single mothers with small children to raise at home. Moore talked to state officials and the mayor of Flint who agreed that this program is useless. Being a well known celebrity with indirect ties to the case, Clark's opinion on the whole issue was sought by the filmmaker. However, Mr. American Bandstand wouldn't give him the time of day. It is Clark's own fault for coming off as an arrogant ass because he most definitely acted like one. Nobody came at him with a spear! All he had to do is give a civilized comment and state his opinion, and he couldn't even manage that.With Heston Moore was a bit rough. But when you take into account the kinds of things that the NRA president is advocating and condoning, little squirming over his own record is the least he can take.Some have even gone as far as accusing Moore and his movie of being anti-American and point to a sequence which details various American military interventions around the world after WW2 until present day, showing the civilian death toll in millions and misery they've produced. AGAIN, THESE ARE ALL WELL KNOWN FACTS, and Moore played them to a great effect to contradict the PR person from Littleton's Lockheed (producers of nuclear arms, cruise missiles and other weapons of mass destruction, largest supplier of American gov't) who suggested that they (Lockheed and American government) "use their weapons responsibly" and that the Littleton kids who shot up the Columbine High School couldn't have possibly learned their violent ways from them. Lockheed, btw, has its headquarters and largest plant in Littleton and since it is the largest employer in the area has family members of many of the kids from Columbine HS working for them.Like "Roger &amp; Me" before it, "Bowling..." is another masterpiece and essential viewing for everyone living in America.</fullReview>

How does over 11,000 gun related deaths a year in the United States sound compared to less that 100 a year in Canada? The film Bowling for Columbine is a documentary directed by and starring film maker Michael Moore. The film takes a humorous and very ironic look at gun violence in the United States. It centers on the Columbine high school shooting in Littleton, Colorado and on militia activity in the mid-west. 		<fullReview>By far one of the most thought provoking movies since, well, Michael Moore's last film The Big One, this powerful documentary is the most stunning film of the year. While these questions have been raised before, no one does it with as much cojones as Moore does. While not all of the answers are given, that's part of the point. This is the type of film that could go on for hours, but leaves enough discussion points to let the viewers answer the questions. It's the asking that is Moore's specialty. Some of the answers do come courtesy of celebrity interviewees Charlton Heston, Marilyn Manson, and Matt Stone (South Park), but the most revealing come from the camera-shy corporate execs and fumbling PR reps that are often the director's favorite targets. His view may be one-sided at times, but he presents it in such a humorous and loveable way that it's hard not to side with him. And why wouldn't you? He's successfully made his targets look like complete idiots. Movies, music, racism, news media, parents, isolation, culture, and poverty are all probed but in the end there seems to not be one single guilty party. Over 11,000 people are killed in this country by guns per year and the only 165 in England. Canada has 10 million people and 7 million guns. So why do they have less violent deaths than we do? The fact that you may even be thinking about it while reading this makes the film successful. One of the funniest moments of the film comes in the form of an animated South Park-like condensed version of American history to date. While far from politically correct, its biting, yet fair criticism of our forefathers before us show us that it is indeed our violent history and legacy of fear that makes our problems unsurprising to our neighboring countries. Most of the film handles the tough subject with a humorous tone, but the most effective moments come courtesy of the interviews with previously unknown, everyday people. This includes former Columbine students that had been shot in the tragic school massacre, the father of one of the Columbine victims, a teenage boy attempting to create napalm, and a teacher who watched one of her grade-school students shoot another one with a handgun. All give this film the extra depth that is sure to detract any cries that it is all propaganda or faceless finger pointing. While funny, sad, scary, intriguing, and poignant all at the same time, Michael Moore proves while he's not the best "director" in the world, he's definitely the best documentary filmmaker out there. This is the first documentary accepted into Cannes Film Festival in 46 years and it's easy to see why this piece of work could not be denied its well-deserved accolades. This is an important film that needs to be seen. Given Moore's previous success, one can only help that between his good name and word of mouth something this powerful makes its way into the conscience of the American public and beyond.</fullReview>
	</review>

Moore brings up a excellent question asking the bank manager, "aren't you a little afraid to be handing out guns at a bank?" Moore has the cameras go down the halls of Columbine High School, showing the viewer that it is no different than any of the other thousands of American High Schools. 		<username>Kurt Berger</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Another strong effort from Moore</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore is a maverick filmmaker in every sense of the word. He's extreme, he's opinionated, he challenges the biggest institutions he can find, and he has a quirky sense of humor and timing that makes him one of the best documentary-makers out there. "Bowling for Columbine" is his latest film, a look at the gun culture of the United States. His major focus is on several elements: the Michigan Militia; the Columbine shootings; the track record of American history as it relates to guns and violence; a look at Canada and its startlingly lower homicide rate involving guns; and a school shooting of a six-year-old girl in his hometown of Flint, Michigan. For Moore, a lifelong member of the NRA, the basic question is this: Why are there so many gun deaths in the United States as compared to other countries such as Canada? With such a complex issue, Moore can't give any easy answers, but he does address most of the major components of the issue. Is it lax gun laws? Is it an inherent violent nature? Is it music, media, movies that influence our thought processes? Is it anger or resentment? He seems to settle on the idea of a culture of fear that inhabits suburban America, which leads them to want to protect themselves in any way possible from a perceived threat that may not actually exist. One pertinent sequence in the film illustrates this - Moore wanders into a subdivision in Canada, opening doors and walking into houses because nobody seems to lock their doors - and he's greeted with mostly friendly reactions, and certainly no threats. "Thanks for not shooting me," he tells one homeowner.Moore's modus operandi here is fairly similar to the structure he used in his debut, "Roger &amp; Me." He plays the part of American Everyman, a little befuddled at what he thinks are simple questions asked of people who have no ready answers. His 'man on the street' interviews with other common folk are used mostly for laughter - clueless kids and goofy militia members. James Nichols - brother of Terry and associate of Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bombers - comes across as completely insane. A lot of this is, of course, a result of creative editing. Moore has the power to portray everyone how he sees fit - those who he agrees with are given much more respect in the editing process than those he doesn't, such as Nichols. Since he's not claiming to be impartial, he can do this, but it hurts his overall cause somewhat if the opposing opinion isn't given any credence at all.Moore's claim to fame is going after the big boys, representing the common man. Here, he does so in an appeal to K-Mart headquarters on behalf of Columbine survivors, and an interview with NRA spokesman Charlton Heston.Moore has a good sense of timing regarding when to go for humor value and when to bring in the serious issues. He offers some disturbing statistics and shows some very provocative footage, such as the security tapes from the lunchroom at Columbine, which clearly show Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold - the shooters. Chilling stuff. Overall, it's a powerful piece of filmmaking that deserves to be seen, if only for the questions it raises. Whether you agree with him or demonize him, Michael Moore certainly makes people think and makes people talk.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Gun lovers should like this movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For years, gun control opponents have been saying "guns don't kill people, people kill people". Pointing out that there are plenty of guns in Canada (7 million in a country of 10 million families) but only 165 gun-related deaths (compared to over 11,000 in the US), Moore begins to explore why "people kill people" in America.Perhaps the reason that gun lovers are so opposed to this movie is that they don't like the answers that Mr. Moore presents. He looks at uncomfortable issues such as racism, a fear mongering media, and American foreign policy while examining their affects on the American psyche.This movie is extremely well put together. The disturbing footage and somber mood are perfectly off-set by well timed comic relief that in no way makes light of the subject matter but, rather, sheds light on the subject matter in a way that makes it possible to endure.That being said, it isn't perfect, while it paints an excellent picture of American gun culture, it glosses over many of the assessments of other countries in order to support its thesis. Also, the criticisms of Michael Moore's self-promotional tendancies aren't entirely off-base. This style, however, is somewhat neccessary in order to paint the picture he manages to. If it weren't for the predatory interviewing style that has become his trademark, many of the entertaining and absurd material he manages to amass would just not be possible to collect. The interview with Heston characterises this as Moore's near cruelty in badgering the senile old man only serves to outline how unfortunate it is that such a damaged mind has so prominent a voice in the American dialogue.Whether you like Moore's position or not, its extremely important to see this movie because, despite a few weaknesses, it still manages to make some very important points. "Bowling for Columbine" is moving, funny, and far more intelligent than most of the dialogue on gun violence that pervades the media.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I find it amusing that the detractors of this film choose as the lynch pin for their arguement a fact that is not even part of the film. This film is not anti-gun. It is not even pro-gun control. Sure, it does raise the question of why a homeowner would need a weapon used to mow down tens and twenties of armed soldiers with the efficiency of a Craftsman tractor but this is not Moore's arguement. If one took the time to decide to watch this film objectively (in the same vein of Errol Morris' filmmaking style) as if it were just another piece of film to be absorbed and thought about instead of being predisposed to dislike it for its "liberal" agenda they would see the point (or arguement if they feel it must be argumentative). This film poses facts. It poses facts but no direct questions. Moore poses questions to many figures, both famous and infamous. But his questions are not pointed directly to the audience. Perhaps the debates seem like a "smart vs. dumb contest" because he is posing questions that have merit to people who have never allowed the thoughts outside their own agenda to permeate into their heads. They're not bad people. They aren't people who hate peace. They just haven't thought f both sides of the issues they stand for. I will not deny that there are moments in the film where certain figures seem a bit insensitive even buffoonish. Of course these are moments that occur within these figure's own arenas. No body forced Charlton Heston to fumble about, briefly blaming our violence problem on the United States' mixed ethnicity. A point that bites down hard after we are shown examples of the mixed ethnicity of Canada, where the number of gun owners is relatively similar to ours yet the deaths by firearm are nearly as dissimilar as they possibly can be. The question that this film poses is not why do we need so many guns. The question posed by this film is why do we need to kill each other. Why do we feel the necessity to keep our firearms at the ready at all times, perfect for my children or your children to get them and place silver dollar sized holes in their own faces? Why is it that out of the entire world we, the country with the most wealth and opportunity, have population numbers that fluctuate vastly every time some one feels they have been insulted? Why does a country like Canada, our neighbor, not go through the same strife as we do? The ultimate question presented in this film is not why can't we lock down all guns. The ultimate question in this film is why do we as a people allow this unnecessary violence and heartache perpetuate within our own backyards. Why do we just sit and accept it? This film is dangerous and in a way offensive to people not because it shows horrific scenes of the world. This film is dangerous and offensive to some people because it does what all good documentary film does. If you are open enough to do so, it makes you take a long hard look at all the worst impulses of yourself. This film is a cue for humanity. If you are disturbed by what you see and the facts that you are presented in this, why are you disturbed? If you are disturbed, what are you doing to make it all right again?It would be a shame for this film to be dismissed as propaganda. Regardless of which side of the fence you stand on concerning guns and violence you should see this film. See it with and objective eye. Absorb the statistics. If you don't believe the statistics, look them up for yourself. Do your own research on the issues. Form more than an arguement. Form a strategy. Take the time to realize that we are living in the midst of an epidemic that may never go away and think of how we can minimize it if not solve it. This film is a significant piece of cinema. It is exactly what it is suppossed to be, a starting point. A beginning for us to make this world better, starting at home. You owe it to yourselves to see this film. You owe it to your families. You owe it to America.</fullReview>

Regardless, this film is an amazing example of well thought out, well executed propaganda. If its message appeals to your politics, then good. If not, the film can still be enjoyed for it's persuasive powers. It does not present objective fact, but rather is a carefully carved out work that is designed to make you see one distinctive side of an issue. In that sense, 'Bowling for Columbine' has more in common with 'Judd Suss' than it does with, say, 'Woodstock-the Movie' or 'Hearts of Darkness.' Moore uses a superiorly deft hand at making the audience see things his way, largely through his gift for humor and wit. At one point Moore inserts a few minutes of Chris Rock's 'Bigger and Blacker' video, which are extremely funny. The audience will laugh at Chris, but after the movie is over, will only remember what a funny movie 'BFC' is. It is the same technique that has sold millions of records for Puff Daddy: give 'em a groove they already know, and they'll buy it because it's "new." That, my friends, is successful mind control, and Michael Moore is to be praised, for he possesses a gift for it. The important thing is to keep that in mind every time he gives us a new "documentary" to consider. 9/10</fullReview>

Instead, this film, which sometimes looks no better than "The Blair Witch Project" proves that all the production values in the world cannot compete with a raw talent for entertaining. There is fascinating, heartbreaking footage of the Columbine massacre - I don't know how he gets his hands on this stuff. This is a no-win movie. You can leave your smugness at the door. Liberals behind the media (COPS, CNN) certainly don't come out of this smelling like roses -and republicans? politicians? corporations? - don't even ask. I left the cinema feeling that the American gun problem was more phenomena than problem. Leaving the cinema was like leaving a rabbit hole where everything was curiouser and curiouser. Highly recommended.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not quite simplistic and polarizing.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, I found it to be a compelling statement on the need for gun control in the US.I would have to partially disagree with earlier comments on the way the information is presented, especially as the info used to support the writer's claims is itself "simplistic and polarizing". It makes what I feel is a fair attempt to show both sides of the issue and leaves the viewer to make up their own mind. It does this with out having any of the force feeding of opinion through one-sided reporting of facts that is so prevalent in most commercial media.More power to Mr. Moore for tackling such a divisive issue and being as even minded as he was, in other hands the facts could have been twisted much further.</fullReview>

		<username>jdesando</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I just marvel at a child-like filmmaker doing what few others can-making unmistakably provocative films.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***Could contain spoilers even though film is a documentary****Michael Moore (`Roger &amp; Me') knows no shame. In this funny, flawed, and ultimately important documentary about guns in America, `Bowling for Columbine,' Moore's greatest moment is when he corrals poor Charlton Heston, president of the NRA, into an interview. Moore stalks the aging, pre-Alzheimer's actor, cornering him into frustration about why he headed a rally right after a 5 year-old boy shot a companion in the same town. Heston can't ably answer; he just shuffles away to the innards of his Hollywood compound, looking old and alone. What mostly gained Moore access to Heston and credibility all around is the fact that he is a life-long NRA member.The film is filled with regular people making Asses of themselves about guns. Very funny is the bank officer opening an account for Moore that includes a gun as a prize. Moore can barely contain his outrage that banks could be in the gun business.Cannes accepted this film into competition, the first documentary in 46 years, and for good reason. Moore explains maybe a bit too easily America's longstanding `culture of fear' from colonial days, partly answering why its gun-murder rate is so much higher than other country's. When he rakes over giant Lockheed Martin, whose arms manufacturing juxtaposed with welfare-for-work makes it a worthy target, he is at his ironic and supercilious best.Other interviews with Goth rocker Marilyn Manson and `South Park' creator Matt Stone help Moore's thesis that obvious icons of rebellion are much less responsible for violence in America than a K-Mart that sold ammunition used at Columbine.Although Moore's logic is a times specious, at other times sheer demagoguery, there are instances when he is himself startled by the truth of his discoveries. For instance, when a Michigan prosecutor states that the white suburbs have more problems with guns than black urban areas, Moore confesses, `I didn't think that's what you were going to say. I thought you were going to say it was black kids in the inner city.' At moments like these I forget Moore's being accused of manipulating or manufacturing interviews; I just marvel at a child-like filmmaker doing what few others can-making unmistakably provocative films.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-10-21</date>
		<username>Howard Schumann</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Simplistic and Polarizing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Compassion is the only source of energy that is useful. Anger always accelerates the damage." -- Zen master Thich Nhat HanhI often gauge a film by my initial reaction when I leave the theater. Am I satisfied, uplifted, frustrated, angry, sad? Admittedly, this is not always the best way to judge a film, but more often than not, my initial reaction seems to stand up. After seeing Michael Moore's documentary on gun control, Bowling for Columbine, I left the theater feeling strangely empty. I wanted to like this film because I know it took some courage to make and films that contain biting social criticism are few and far between. I am grateful that these thought-provoking issues are being raised; however, I found the film so strident in its tone that I fear it may further polarize the debate and not bring people together.Moore begins by using one of his favorite techniques, that of showing his opponents in a ridiculous light. In this case, it is the Michigan Militia, using their own words to show the addled thinking of gun supporters. For example, one Militia member states: "It is an American's responsibility to be armed." Mr. Moore then goes to a local bank in Michigan that provides guns for people opening an account, making some pointed comments about how inappropriate it is for a bank to be giving away guns stashed in their vault. All of this is funny until you realize that it is all manipulated to support his point of view. Now of course I laughed because I agree with its message, but I stopped to think -- what if he was using this approach to attack a point of view I supported? I would be furious and rightly so.Having lived in Canada and the United States, I can attest to the fact that much of the material Mr. Moore uses to promote Canada and denigrate the U.S. is full of half truths and distortions. He implies that the source of U.S. violence cannot be the unemployment rate because Canada has an unemployment rate of 8% while the U.S. rate is only 4%. This completely overlooks the fact the rate of unemployment in Black and Latino areas, areas that produce a high crime statistic, is much, much higher. Mr. Moore also asserts that a hospital visit in Canada is free and quotes some local Canadian residents as saying it should be a basic right of people to have access to free medical care. What he doesn't say is that it is not free. Canadians, at least in British Columbia, pay a premium of $108.00 per month that may not be that much lower than what some Americans pay to Blue Cross. Besides, he doesn't mention the long waiting lists for surgery for life threatening illness, and the inadequate hospital facilities in many areas that require delays in transporting the needy by helicopter to other hospitals. He quotes the Mayor of Sarnia, Ontario promoting social welfare programs, and contrasts that with the cutbacks in the U.S.. Well, perhaps I should move to Sarnia because the government of British Columbia has slashed spending on health and education, cut welfare payments, and eliminated many programs that benefit the poor and the elderly. I did find much to like in Bowling for Columbine. I was elated that, as a result of visits from injured Columbine students, K-Mart announced that it would no longer sell ammunition after a 90-day phase-out period. In addition, in a segment dealing with the abuses of U.S. foreign policy, he shows how the school shootings arise do not occur in a vacuum but arise from prevailing political policies and community attitudes. I think he rightfully points out that the U.S. overbearing use of its power around the world sends a message to its citizens that it is all right to use force to settle an argument. He also makes a telling point that the U.S. media and corporate culture promotion of fear as a marketing tool creates a climate of paranoia. Bowling for Columbine is being touted as a must-see masterpiece. Allow me to offer a lonely voice of dissent. I agree that the film makes some very riveting and scary points, but it does nothing to promote resolution. I do think questions need to be raised and awareness brought to these issues, but Mr. Moore produces much heat but little light, and his self-righteousness drives people into opposite corners. I know there are no simple solutions, but the epidemic of violence, Mr. Moore to the contrary, exists not only in the U.S, but all over the world. This is not just an American issue. In poking at these issues, Moore jumps all over easy targets like Dick Clark, the NRA, and the Bush administration. The issue, however, is not the mindset of George Bush or Dick Clark or a sadly deteriorating Charlton Heston. Scapegoating is not the answer. It is this "us against them" attitude that doesn't work, whether the antagonists are George Bush and Saddam Hussein, or Michael Moore and the big corporations. The focus must be that, if we are to survive, we can no longer afford to live in an ego-driven "you OR me" world. It must quickly become a "you AND me" world united by our common humanity, or there will only be more Columbines.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Definitely see this</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm not asking everyone to agree with this movie. That, in my mind, was not the point. I do think that everybody should see this, and think about it before waving a hand, arching an eyebrow and dismissing this as "left wing propaganda." If you think his arguments are propaganda, then coherently diffuse them. There are factual statistics that can't be simply dismissed. If you ask me what Michael Moore wanted when he wrote this movie, I say he wanted people to think. Do that. Don't just knee jerk an angry response because you categorically disagree with everything Michael Moore says because he's some bleeding heart. Personally, I love the guy and his work, but I don't expect everyone to. All I want is for people to see this and think about it. Some parts had me laughing harder than I had in a while, yet other parts had my stomach in my shoes. It's definitely worthwhile. That is, if you actually intend on watching the movie, not just rejecting it outright.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-10-21</date>
		<username>enicholson</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A great film -- but with at least one flaw</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all, let me point out where I think this film is flawed. BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE almost exclusively focuses on gun violence in America as it stems from or relates to "white" America -- with very few exceptions. That means there is nothing in this film about drug violence, gang violence and the gun culture within urban, "non-white" America. Much of the firearms murders during the mean drug wars of the 80s, 90s and today are/were "black on black" homicides and other homicides within the context of urban (and suburban) organized crime. BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE never once touches on this subject, which is unfortunate. And it leads me to believe that Michael Moore is rather uncomfortable relating examples and statistics of firearms murders committed by anyone other than Caucasian Americans (there is a funny scene early in the film where Moore has to write the word "Caucasian") -- as though it were somehow politically incorrect or mildly reactionary to touch on the subject of the very obvious gun culture within the cultures of American organized crime as well as in the culture of non-white ethnic groups (in other words, the gun culture that is far removed from the likes of Columbine and the Michigan Militia).I think Moore stayed away from the subject of non-white gun violence because it could perhaps undermine his quasi-thesis that all or most gun violence in American is somehow the result of a deep racially-motivated psychological fear that can be traced from the pilgrims, to the slave holders, to the westward pioneers, etc. He seemingly arrives at his semi-theory through process of elimination. But to imply that there is a separate problem (though perhaps related in certain ways) of firearms violence in America that does not involve white people scared to death of non-whites or other types of strangers would perhaps challenge Moore's semi-theory more than he would like. Michael Moore is well known for wearing his left of center views on his sleeve, which is of course why it's rather surprising to learn from the film that Moore is a member of the NRA. He does a remarkable job at building a case that it's a culture of fear of the non-white man that creates this obsession with guns and over-abundance of killing, yet clearly there are thousands of murders in the U.S. every year that are committed by non-middle America, non-rural, non-suburban, non-whites. So why do black criminals, Hispanic criminals, or criminals from other non-white populations kill with guns? What "fear" do they suffer from? Do they fear other non-white homicidal criminals? Moore, as fearless as he is, seems to fear touching on this issue. Could it be that there is a culture of greed that arises from the business of organized crime that also parallels this culture of fear that perhaps is not really part of organized crime? I think so. I think Moore had more than just an opportunity to explore the gun violence in urban, organized crime; I think he had somewhat of a responsibility to explore this too. But he doesn't. And I can only guess it's because this issue somewhat challenges his quasi-thesis of "white fear."But despite my criticism that I have offered so far, I have to say that this is a great film -- easily one of the best documentaries I have ever seen. It's debatable as to what kind of documentary this is. Is Moore some kind of "satirical documentarian?" His skill at interviews, his pithy observations, his wit and his desire to confront and shock are tremendously on the money. And Moore's skill at getting just about any human being to be candid and say what's really on their mind is amazing. This film is not only hilarious and disturbing, but it is also tremendously moving. I was practically in tears when the film showed the miserable poverty in Moore's hometown of Flint, Michigan. He is tremendously skilled and passionate when it comes to shining the spotlight on the underclasses, the forgotten, the downtrodden and those people and problems in America most of us wish would just go away. Moore refuses to let us ignore these problems, and he relates them with such a genuine compassion that it is impossible not to be moved. And he exposes the selfishness and the disinterestedness of the privileged (and well armed) with such effortlessness that it is impossible not be amazed, shocked and outraged.The film works partly because it shows Moore exploring and struggling to come up with the reason or reasons why Americans are so homicidal with firearms (as opposed to our well armed, but less murderous, Canadian neighbors to the north). Moore tries to find an answer or answers -- and he does come up with a theory -- but he implies that his theory may not be the only theory or that it may not be absolutely correct. As Moore irreverently points out in the film, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold liked to bowl, and bowling was the last thing they did before they murdered a dozen or so students and teachers at Columbine High School. So could bowling have been the cause of the Columbine massacre -- any more than Marilyn Manson or easy access to guns? Hence the title BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE.But the film is also a kind of a broader expose on the culture of violence and misery that is unique to American culture. Interestingly, the film briefly essays the culture of violence in American foreign policy -- and how from time to time the U.S. government has, openly and secretly, had a policy of military aggression in many troubled spots around the world. Moore does not explore the history of these conflicts at all, but instead implies that culture of violence within everyday America and the culture of violence used by the American political establishment overseas is related. It isn't complete (nothing about this film is) but it is effective, informative and revealing.But, as I stated already, I think this film is somewhat flawed -- because it does not explore or reveal quite enough. Well, actually, I think it's incomplete. Now Moore needs to go out and make the sequel: BOWLING FOR THE MAC DADDY or BOWLING FOR GANG BANGIN'. He could start with my neighborhoods here in LA and Venice Beach.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>You're a brilliant comedian, now keep your opinion to yourself</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a very funny movie. Moore has such a wonderfully twisted sense of humor. Sure he's using dead children as his canvas but then again most comedies are based on some sort of misfortune or bad character trait. Don't see this movie for a great debate on the gun issue. See it as a comedy. I am a second amendment advocate and I loved the movie.The movie is about Moore trying to figure out through a series of interviews why America loves guns. In most of his work he blames the corporations. In this one he correctly blames the American public rather than the NRA and the gun companies. Sure they get a little of the blame but most of it he drops on the electorate. After all who's fault is pollution? The oil companies, or the commuters who don't want to pay more money for clean burning fuel? Whose fault is violence? The gun makers or the criminals that actually pull the trigger. Moore puts more blame on the trigger pullers in this film.He also has some great interviews. Charlton Heston and Maryln Manson are two of the more memorable ones. Both are accused of causing Columbine but Manson does a much better job of defending himself. Actually when asked what he would tell the kids of Columbine, his response is genius. Charlton Heston on the other hand is made to look like a real monster in front of the camera. Of course, to his credit, it was early for the old man and Heston thought he was dealing with an NRA advocate. That's why he agreed to the interview. We all have seen Heston advocate the NRA and we know that he is smarter than what is seen here. The end of this movie was actually quite sick. Moore makes the argument in his film that violence is the fault of the American public's paranoia but in one of the closing shots he still insists on blaming it on Charlton Heston just like the popular media he criticizes does.There are some very funny scenes such as when Terry Nicol's brother utters the classic line: "There are a lot of nuts out there". There is another sequence when Moore is interviewing a police officer about an accidental shooting by a dog that gets a lot of laughs because the police officer refuses to be in on the joke. There are many other great laughs.I disagree with everything Moore has ever said but I am a big fan of Roger &amp; Me and TV Nation. He has a way of making brilliant black comedies. At times this movie may have been a little sick, but then again so was Pulp Fiction, another movie I loved.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-10-20</date>
		<username>Ralph Michael Stein (riglltesobxs@mailinator.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not About Gun Control But Not About Columbine Either</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At times engaging, engrossing and brilliant, "Bowling for Columbine" suffers from Michael Moore's unquenchable desire to sketchily indict many putative disparate evils without deeply exploring their nature. A documentary of pieces, the sum is poorer than many of its parts.Moore, the enfant terrible of American documentarians to many, reprises the filmmaking techniques for which he is justly renowned. The sharp edit that leaves many viewers suspecting unfair manipulation of subjects, the ego centrality of Moore's presence and the rapid and almost seamless juxtaposition of antagonistic issues so as to suggest (but not develop) their mutual relevance to the film's theme are in abundance.Moore isn't anti-gun. He is anti-violence, a stand no sane person could dissent from. And he brings to the screen the hardly novel reality that gun violence is epidemic in the U.S. and not a problem in many other Western countries including our northern neighbor, Canada. In jaunts to Windsor and Toronto he allows young and old interviewees to wade in on the question of why their country is so much safer from gun violence, despite the great prevalence of weapons for hunting, than is the U.S. Their answers are neither enlightening nor profound but they do seem more laid back than my fellow Americans (this is news about Canadians?).Moore does demonstrate true physical courage in his exploration of Canadian neighborhoods where, he's heard, denizens don't lock doors. He opens a few doors to confront unsuspecting and remarkably undisturbed homeowners. If man of Moore's size with his unkempt appearance opened my door and walked in unannounced - well, I don't have a gun but I keep two killer cats for a reason.The big problem with this film is that it accuses so many while explaining so little The news media, popular law enforcement TV shows ("COPS"), American foreign policy, arguably corrupt support for dictators, racism, the insinuation that the public is so gullible that any news story from the spread of Africanized bees to the danger of bacteria sparks panic - all fall within Moore's purview. Moore can not let go of his interest in, indeed near obsession with, the fate of his native Flint, Michigan, subject of his brilliant "Roger &amp; Me." The minutes showing the continued decay of this once vital industrial city add nothing.There are sobering and moving moments. The principal of a Michigan elementary school having the sad distinction of being the scene of the murder of the nation's youngest school gun victim, a little single-digit aged child (killed by a peer), projects strength and love for and commitment to her children before faltering and succumbing wordlessly to tears. She knows she doesn't have the answers. With what she's experienced, we know she has fears for the future that can not be disspelled.The interview with an aging Charlton Heston adds little to the film. No one knew at the time of the actor's Alzheimer's Disease but it doesn't matter. Moore's lying (there's another word?) to Heston to get the interview is a common journalistic ploy but the encounter itself uncovers nothing of interest. Heston is old, his steps almost faltering. For those who do not remember that Heston publicly fought for racial justice forty years ago, inclusion of his hardly prepared or thought out comments that can be interpreted as racist was, simply, an unfair act by Moore. Leaving a photo of the little child killed in Michigan on Heston's grounds was tacky.Moore does score a victory in this film when he takes two Columbine victims, one now a paraplegic, to K-Mart's HQ to demand that the mega-chain cease selling ammo for handguns. To Moore's obvious sincere surprise the corporate spokeswoman pledges to exactly meet that demand. A symbolic victory but one that doesn't solve the real issue Moore never satisfactorily explores: why there are so many rage-filled teenagers in our culture?In her brilliant, penetrating and devastatingly brilliant sum-up of her life as a journalist in the nation's capital, "Washington," the late Meg Greenfield draws on her experience to argue that for most, high school is their defining emotional and maturational experience. Obviously, few high school students become killers and they enter school with many values and attitudes formed. But so many teens are emotionally supple and painfully vulnerable. Were the Columbine killers so different other than in the degree in which they acted out? I suspect they weren't. And that issue stands apart from any underlying American culture of gun violence. I would love to see a more thematically constrained Moore explore high schools, perhaps just one.And, unfortunately, I had no greater insight into teen homicidal violence after the film than when I entered the theater. Moore lost a tremendous opportunity here.7/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

A symbolic victory but one that doesn't solve the real issue Moore never satisfactorily explores: why there are so many rage-filled teenagers in our culture?In her brilliant, penetrating and devastatingly brilliant sum-up of her life as a journalist in the nation's capital, "Washington," the late Meg Greenfield draws on her experience to argue that for most, high school is their defining emotional and maturational experience. Obviously, few high school students become killers and they enter school with many values and attitudes formed. But so many teens are emotionally supple and painfully vulnerable. Were the Columbine killers so different other than in the degree in which they acted out? I suspect they weren't. And that issue stands apart from any underlying American culture of gun violence. I would love to see a more thematically constrained Moore explore high schools, perhaps just one.And, unfortunately, I had no greater insight into teen homicidal violence after the film than when I entered the theater. Moore lost a tremendous opportunity here.7/10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Moore's best work, ever.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore had to win me over with this film, because I was not a fan of his before I saw it. With American gun culture being a far more intriguing issue than the nebulous attacks on "stupid white men" that Moore's previous work is known for, my interest was piqued enough to be very excited about Bowling For Columbine. The verdict is nothing short of fantastic. Despite what detractors of this film have said, Bowling For Columbine is not "anti-American", "socialist propaganda" or gun control propaganda. I defy anyone to name an instance in the film in which Michael Moore advocates stricter gun control, because the facts are that, although there is footage of gun control advocates, Moore clearly doesn't believe that banning guns is the answer to anything. I am forced to question if those accusing this film of being "propaganda" were in the bathroom while say, the entire segment on Canada, was on. To quote Moe Syzlak, "if you're so sure about what it ain't, how about telling us what it am," which is a fair enough question. What Bowling For Columbine is, is an intriguing look at the American psyche. There isn't really a whole lot to say about the film without ruining it for those who haven't seen it. But for those who bemoan the lack of a definitive "answer" for the problems posed in this film, how exactly is such a complex issue going to be resolved in a matter of hours? There are clearly ingrained mental problems that America as a social entity has to deal with. In regard to American violence, simply asking the right questions, which Bowling For Columbine did in spades, is a triumph, that will hopefully put us on the track to an answer. ***SPOILER*** I will say that perhaps the most disturbing aspect of this film was the interview with the not so subtle bigot Charlton Heston. Would I have called him that before he implied that the presence of minorities in America is responsible for the high amount of gun deaths (as opposed to the ever vigilant and responsible Caucasian gun owners)? No. As for those who accuse Moore of "ambushing" Heston, Moore asked a simple question, "why does the NRA continue to show up in locations which have just suffered through gun related tragedies?" Heston had no answer. If Heston did appear "ambushed" it's because he took Moore's NRA membership to mean that all NRA members follow the Charlton Heston party line, and that he would be getting slow pitch softball questions. I always thought that Heston might be a better person than the NRA sound bites made him look, but amazingly, he's a far worse person.See this film, if nothing else, it will make you think about something.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Well Worth Seeing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore's Bowling For Columbine is a film which I can highly recommend. It's a good, old-fashioned, something-for-everyone liberal documentary from the kitchen-sink school of documentary filmmaking. Moore tries hard to bring ideas to the general population which most American media would find to be sacrileges (but which I wholehearted agree are some of the keys to America's problems, chiefly our problem of violence.) Such as that our exploitive media terrorize us by constantly focusing on violence and instilling fear, causing a perception of our world which does not match the reality. For example, Moore brings up that while violent crime has decreased in a certain time period by (I think) 40%, media coverage of violent crime has increased 600%.Moore, who is excellent at finding subjects or situations which will yield succinct expressions of some nebulous concepts, runs into a news camera crew in South Central Los Angeles at one point, and interviews one of the producers. He asks in a case where there are two story possibilities - the "near-drowning" of a baby, and a man brandishing a gun - which the news crew would go with. The producer responds, "The gun. Always go with the gun." That says it all.During this same short sequence, Moore is shown the "Hollywood Sign", off in the distance - or rather, it is pointed out for him, but can't be seen, due to smog. Moore wonders aloud why the media aren't covering that story, and the contrast between the importance of the two stories - pollution on a vast and killing scale, and one man in South Central waving a gun - makes it exceedingly clear how the rigidly formatted, reductive television news programs fail to cover the real news of the world, in favor of the sensational. The only real crime here is that, instead of labeling themselves as entertainment, they call themselves "news", which it becomes obvious they are not, except maybe with an asterisk reading "of the exploitive, dramatic, and summarizable in ten words or less."Despite its overall success in being an engaging, thought-provoking, and often emotional film, Bowling For Columbine's failings are Moore's usual ones. Chiefly, an occasional lack of respect for certain things or people (e.g. Charlton Heston) which may cross a line for some viewers, making us wonder how fully we can support some of Michael Moore's tactics, which as a result can make his idealism seem a little expedient.Also a flaw, in my book - and probably less evident to the average filmgoer - would be Moore's over-eagerness to make some of his subjects look stupid (while Moore comes off looking clever) by his editing of their statements. This, again, undermines his idealistic stance, since it frequently seems (to me) he uses people as stand-ins for the two-dimensional attitudes of ignorance and stupidity he wants to express; that, even if the person being interviewed is not as stupid as Moore would like a subject to be in a given scene, he leaves their more balanced views on the cutting-room floor.Moore's strengths are again his usual ones, such as a willingness to do things that make us nervous, like bring two survivors of Columbine (both with bullets, purchased at K-Mart, still lodged in their bodies) to K-Mart headquarters with a request that K-Mart take the bullets back, and a request that K-Mart stop selling ammunition.In this particular scenario, if you're anything like me, you'll be surprised at what happens. It's clear Michael Moore was among the most surprised of all.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Bowling For Columbine is Michael Moore's latest documentary. In it, he attempts to understand why America has such a violent culture, and why so many Americans seem to be afraid all the time. Although many seem to think that his main target is the NRA, in fact it is the American media and the way it emphasizes the violence in our country, and uses fear to hype their ratings on the news. (Killer escalators, killer bees, etc.)Having said that, the movie also struggles to understand why so many people live in such fear that they keep a loaded gun in the house at all times. It seems especially absurd when Charlton Hestons proudly boasts that he keeps a loaded gun in his Beverly Hills mansion, which is surrounded by a gate, and protected by a security service. When Moore questions why Heston has a loaded gun in his house, Heston replies that the Second Amendment gives him that right. He may or may not have that right under the Second Amendment, but the real question is why is this man who lives in a crime-free neighborhood with gates and security guards so afraid that he feels the NEED to keep a loaded gun in the house. After all, Heston admits that in his long life, he has never been the victim of a crime. It is this fear of that Moore tries to understand throughout this film and I give him credit for making me stop and think about why we Americans are so terrified all the time.</fullReview>

But Moore's talent is his aggressiveness, and the sequence in which he brings two Columbine victims to KMart headquarters is an extremely powerful bit of populist action (though I wouldn't expect those who disagree with the cause to find it so). All in all, it's no Roger and Me. But it is refreshing to see a movie come out that is unafraid to take a stance - with all the fear of offending anyone with centrist politics that dominates the film world. If just for that, I hope people see this and talk about it.</fullReview>

So just what is it that makes the U.S. stand apart from every other industrialized country in the world when it comes to violence?Well, the search for the answer to that question is what this movie is really about. It should also be noted that Moore does not play favorites when it comes to political leaders. He takes Clinton to task as well as Dubya. Finally, this movie couldn't have come out at a better time as we ponder the military invasion of Iraq. 		<fullReview>I thoroughly enjoyed this film, and for that reason, I wanted to give it a high score. Until I sat down and tried to digest what Mike Moore had been telling me. And then I realised - I haven't got a clue.I have enjoyed Mike Moore films in the past, although I am fully aware that I am not being given the full picture in order to evaluate all of the points. They tend to be more "propoganda" than documentary. But hey, at least he does it in an entertaining way, and as long as you go out and research the other side, at least he has presented you with some interesting viewpoints.That was the kind of case for this film. Except, I really don't know exactly what his viewpoints were. But then we seem to have left that subject and gone to the specifics of one particular crime ... and then another ... and we are all of a sudden spending quite some time examining the low wages paid by Dick Clark (who owns the chain of restaurants where the mother of a 6 year old gun user worked). Oh, so the reason for that crime (all crime?) is because of poverty? But hang on, he's just dismissed that reason when he compared gun crime with certain other poorer countries. So why are we trying to interview (blame) Dick Clark? ... Oh, we've moved on, and now we're talking about the negative way in which news reports stir up fear amongst the public. But we don't give any real evidence of any direct link between this and gun crime. Just examples of negative press stories from the past. And now we're back to a specific incident (the Columbine one) and we're blaming KMart because they sell bullets (not that I am defending KMart) ... oh, and we have also heard drawn out implications that America's gun crime is due to the fact that gun owners are all white, and the NRA is racist, and Americans all own guns because they are afraid of the black man. Hence the high gun crime ... erm .... pardon? We are directed all over the place, but at no point does Moore give us anything tangible that we can use in a debate. If I present an argument during a debate, I will expect the first response to my point to be "Why do you think that?". At this point you need evidence and good, strong arguments if you are to succeed. Moore doesn't really have any of these. Not only that, but he can't resist numerous, irrelevant sideswipes at the Bush government, which (valid though they often are) often have nothing to do with the overall aim of the film.My review is not to argue with Moore or his points, but merely to say that if you are expecting an Oscar winning "documentary" to provide you with useful arguments and convincing theories, then you'll be a bit disappointed. But, if you are a fan of Moore's general style of presenting an argument, and do not mind if he is random and doesn't finish any avenue he explores, then you will enjoy this.A shame, because I tended to agree with many of the points (not all!), but just felt that Moore didn't do them justice if he was trying to talk to intelligent people who are capable of forming their own opinions, and need solid reasoning in order to do so.</fullReview>

		<username>kennyjp</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Documentary Media Class Review</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For my film review I chose to watch a documentary by Michael Moore entitled "Bowling for Columbine." In this film Michael Moore discusses the Columbine High School shootings which occurred on April 20th, 1999 in Columbine, Colorado. Two students, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, brought shotguns, pistols, and pipe bombs to their high school and then went on a shooting rampage against their fellow students. It was one of the most deadly school shootings in United States History and at the end of the day 12 Students and one teacher were killed while an additional 21 people were wounded. In his film, Moore discusses the possible causes for this shooting. He states the glorified use of guns throughout American History as a possible catalyst for the shooting rampage. Moore also explores the process of obtaining a fire arm in the United States and how it is a very simple process that is not very difficult at all. He also states several statistics about gun deaths worldwide and then compares them to the yearly amount of gun deaths in the United States and the numbers that has found are quite staggering. Throughout his film Moore talks about the way Americans feel about guns and gun control and he does, in my opinion, do a very good job of presenting opinions that represent both sides of the issue. He does this by interviewing people who represent both sides of the issue and give very interesting and thought provoking responses to Moore's questions. For example, Moore interviews Timothy McVeigh's brother and gets his opinions about gun control and why he thinks that citizens of the U.S. are allowed by law to carry guns and arm themselves. I think that with this film, Moore does a good job of not pushing his own views extremely hard on the viewers but does represent them in a way that would not influence the viewers greatly but allows them to form their own opinions about gun control. I think "Bowling for Columbine" is an example of the kind of film making that Michael Moore does best, he takes a very serious social issue in the U.S., in this case gun control, and explores it to great extent by gathering info and opinions of a wide range of people. Much like his other pieces of work, including "Fahrenheit 9/11" or "Sicko", Moore discusses both the background information of the issue he is documenting as well as what is currently going on with the issue, and even adds some speculation as to what effects the issue will have in the future. Moore also takes whatever issue he is talking about and compares what is happening with the issue in the U.S. to the rest of the world. For example in "Bowling for Columbine" he gives statistics for the amount of guns and the number of gun related deaths in the United States and compares them to Canada. By doing this he is able to show to what extent guns impact our society and to what extent they impact other societies. I think that by picking a country that is right next door to the U.S. he is able to show how drastically different the severity of the problem is in the two countries. The editing in this movie involved a lot of steady camera shots which did not provide a feeling that it was shot with a hand-held camera. The individual scenes vary greatly, there are some where there are longer interviews and others where the interviews are quite short. One thing that both of these aspects have in common is that neither one is performed in a standard sitting at a table asking questions, they are usually standing somewhere or walking around someone's house or place of work. By doing this I think that Moore is able to hold the audience's attention better and to get away from the sort of interview that one would find on the nightly news. The movie progresses not so much chronologically but from theme to theme. Moore discusses gun control while presenting people's opinions that he has gathered about it, he will then move to talking about gun accidents and give examples and statistics for this. I feel that the film does a very good job of staying organized and doesn't jump from idea to idea in a haphazard manner, but is very streamlined and smooth. Moore also narrates during his movie while he is transitioning between clips or to give a little background information about an interview before it is played in the film. The cinematography of this film used a lot of literal visuals to get across the issue of gun control. He shows visuals of guns, news paper articles, as well as old news broadcast clips. The documentary was shot in color film with only a few old clips in black and white. Moore uses a variety of shots in his documentary including various interviews and some shots of scenery. He does do a lot of close up interviews with people but he also shows visuals of schools and cities where he is. The film does not have a very shaky feeling to it which means that it was probably not shot in a hand-held fashion. But I think that for this kind of film that is the best way to do it because you don't need to convey a sense of action when you are exploring an issue and interviewing individuals. The film also gives a very strong sense that a lot of the interviews and visits that Moore makes are not scheduled in advance but more of an "on the spot" set up. I think this makes the film seem a bit more real just because it seems like the person being interviewed is giving an honest answer and has not had time to prepare exactly what they were going to say.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Bowling for Columbine Michael Moore's documentary Bowling for Columbine is an examination of gun culture in America; it explores the issue of gun violence and gun culture. It focuses on the media's role in society and the way it effects and their perception of the perception of violence in America. While the film covers a very serious issue it is also very entertaining, the documentary captivatingly conveys the shocking problem of gun violence, the media's connection to it and the atmosphere of fear that Americans seem to feel. Moore follows the cycle of violence and fear ruining his society.There is no doubt that the media has a huge effect of society. It can not only spread positive messages but also negative ones. Moore focuses of the way media can affect the emotional climate of the country. He uses examples of stories like Y2K and the Africanized killer bee plague which threw America into a state of panic. It demonstrates how the media portrays black people in a negative way, creating fear. It uses sharp editing of crimes committed by black men accompanied by loud narration repeating 'black man wanted for crime' or 'wanted: black male'. This makes it seem as if white men do not commit crimes and that we should fear black people, which is not the case. Moore's point is clear: the media has to be more responsible and stop creating the terrible fear in the community. The media, the corporations, the politicians have all done such a good job of scaring the American public; it's come to the point where they don't need to give any reason at all.The documentary suggests to us that this fear leads to greater consumption of guns and associated products. Moore opens a bank account and is supplied with a complementary gun; he buys bullets from his hairdressers and can pick up a gun at k-mart, proving how accessible weapons are. The easy access to weapons and the fear that Americans have does nothing to create a safe environment in America, in fact it does the exact opposite, which is clearly demonstrated by the terrible number of gun deaths in America per year: 11127. This number is by far the largest in comparison with Australia (65), Japan (39), Canada (165), Germany (387), France (255) and the UK (68). These figures clearly show that the easy access to weapons and the fear created by the media do not create a save environment.The easy access to weapons is unsafe and unnecessary; it creates a casual attitude towards them, Kids find them at home and are not afraid as they should be because they haven't been bought up to fear them. One six year old child even felt comfortable picking it up and putting it into his school bag; he took it to school where he shot another six year old girl in his class. The girl died in the class room after the single bullet traveled through her body. The boy found the gun at his uncle's house where he was staying. His attitude towards the gun was not fear as it should have been, children shouldn't be comfortable around guns and families should not be leaving guns in places where children can find them. The girl's death was a tragedy, the youngest school shooting in history.Moore's Documentary is both entertaining and thought provoking. Bowling for Columbine powerfully presents Moore's point of view on the shocking problem of gun violence in America and the effect that the media has in intensifying the fear.</fullReview>
