		<shortDescription>Michael Moore's Best Documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I sometimes criticize Michael Moore for his "pretend" documentaries that are usually so biased that they qualify not as documentaries but rather as propaganda. "Bowling For Columbine," however, was I thought pretty well done. Yes, Moore has a bias which comes across but his bias seems more muted than in his other movies, and he seems far more interested in asking the question "why?" than in simply attacking and ridiculing those he disagrees with. Why are there so many gun deaths in the United States compared to other western countries? Fair question. Moore doesn't really come up with an answer, but raising the question is nevertheless a worthwhile task.Politically, the movie paints with broad brush strokes. Both Bush and Clinton come in for criticism of how their actions have contributed to the gun culture. The real target of the movie, though, is the National Rifle Association - that bizarre (there's my solid Canadian bias showing) - lobby group that seems to think that the more guns there are in people's hands, the safer everybody will be. Moore makes great play of the fact that he's a life member of the NRA (which surprised me) and therefore can ask questions from the inside, so to speak, as he does at the end of the movie when he confronts Charlton Heston (at the time the president of the NRA) with some of these questions, with Heston in the end simply agreeing to disagree and walking away. His brief encounter with Dick Clark took me aback. The one scene that really stood out in my mind was the interview with the brother of one of the Oklahoma City bombers (who seemed a bit crazy himself and who was apparently also a suspect at one time) when the man looked at the camera with a bit of a wild look in his eyes and said, about why he needed weapons but thought that access to weapons-grade uranium should be restricted, "there's wackos out there." True - and a lot of them have guns! It's all set with the 1999 school shooting at Columbine High School in Colorado as the backdrop, and it does raise very legitimate issues and questions. In my view, it's Michael Moore's best "quasi-doc," although it portrays a bit too benign a view of Canada's gun problems. 7/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Peace for our time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A full review of this movie should discuss whether it is true to the facts, but many others have done so, on and off IMDb, much better than I can. In any case, one should never go to a political documentary hoping to learn The Truth. I am particularly skeptical about Michael Moore because I remember him stating, in "Roger and Me", that General Motors was making "huge profits" in the 1980s. (That does not mean that everything Moore says is wrong).Leaving facts aside, I shall focus on two other issues. The first is that it is wrong to say that this movie is anti-gun: it is anti-anything that Moore doesn't like. That includes, but is not limited to, big corporations, the media, and American intervention abroad. Moore even tries to blame violence on the media's obsession with violence; which, taken to its logical conclusion, implies that he should blame violence on his own documentary.Arguably, the broad range of targets makes it a better movie: if Moore had only one target, he would have presented only one side of the argument. The drawback is that the viewer can get any message he or she wants to get. At least, this is the impression that I get from the IMDb reviews.The other issue that I want to discuss is related to the opening sentence of the movie: "It was the morning of April 20th 1999 (...) The President bombed another country whose name we couldn't pronounce." A minimally-educated European will be reminded of Neville Chamberlain saying: "How horrible, fantastic, incredible, it is that we should be digging trenches and trying on gas-masks here because of a quarrel in a faraway country between people of whom we know nothing."As I said, American intervention is, in fact, one of the targets of this movie; but Moore does not discuss in detail any specific war, possibly because he could not pronounce the name of any of the countries. The reason Moore is opposed to these wars is that he thinks they have created a culture of violence within the USA. The evidence that he offers for this claim is that Marilyn Manson also thinks so.So Michael Moore reveals himself: not a new Riefenstahl or a new Goebbels, as some people claim, but a new Chamberlain. Michael Moore wants peace for our time. We foreigners can kill each other without restraint: Michael Moore won't make documentaries about it, unless we live in countries with names easy to pronounce.Actually, the comparison to Chamberlain is not entirely appropriate: Neville Chamberlain was an elected leader, and his policy of appeasement had the full backing of the British people, who are collectively to blame for the failure of appeasement. Moore, needless to say, does not have the full backing of American people.Incidentally, Moore does not mention Chamberlain in the movie, but he does mention Gandhi, during the Charlton Heston interview. However, it would seem that Moore has no clear idea of what Gandhi actually accomplished.While my comments range from the sarcastic to the scathing, I did find the movie quite entertaining, and it introduced me to some interesting characters, James Nichols for example. People who have read this review up to here will probably look at the movie critically, and therefore I can recommend it to them (except if they don't want to finance Michael Moore, of course). Unfortunately, it is more likely to be seen by people who would stop reading at the first negative comment.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Savae Cycle</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Jessica Kruse Emily M. Liebman English 102 03/03/04The Savage Cycle The movie Bowling for Columbine is an attempt by its filmmaker-activist Michael Moore to pry open the frightened eyes of Americans in order to reveal the source from which gun violence emanates. While in pursuit of an explanation, Michael compares U.S. factors such as history of violence, gun availability, violence in the media and ethnicity to those of several other countries, revealing many similarities. Yet, no other country reports a shockingly high crime rate comparable to the U.S. With unsatisfactory results from statistical comparison Michael is forced to further examine the American psyche, revealing fear as the motive of action, resulting in more fear. As the savage cycle continues and is spread through the media, corporate and political America enables more individuals access to guns, fueling the economy in the self-destructive process. Through the use of sarcasm, contrasting images, and striking social examples, Moore successfully rips the white wash from our country's history revealing the bloody truth - making me scared and ashamed to be an American.In the opening scene Moore receives a free gun for opening an account with a bank in his home state Michigan offering `more bang for your buck'. After humoring their vague questioning and background check he then asks, `don't you think it is a bit dangerous handing out guns at a bank?' This question directly addresses and recognizes our country's sad economical state, foolishly rewarding currency with tools of violence. Next, Moore visits the Michigan militia to interview James Nichols the brother of Terry Nichols who with the help of Timothy McVeigh bombed the Oklahoma government building killing one hundred sixty-eight innocent people. James Nichols casually shows Moore around his farm proudly explaining that his produce is one hundred percent natural and safe for consumers. Nichols then displays unstable mentality by cocking his pistol and raising it to his temple exclaiming no one can tell him he can't have his gun kept safely loaded beneath his pillow. When asked if all Americans should have atomic bombs at their disposal Nichols replies `no way, there's a bunch of nuts out there'. Our attention is then drawn to the massacre of twelve students and one teacher at Columbine High School in Little, Colorado where the schools mascot is the Rebel displaying a soldier carrying a gun. With Lockheed Martin the largest U.S. bomb manufacturer's headquarters employing most of Littleton's residence, the company's motto states `we are Columbine' and rightfully so, as the children of this town are brought up admiring the production of weapons and their use. As a result of these conditions a victim's father emotionally pleads, `something is wrong here, lets do something about it'. Moore now asks, `What is wrong with America?' Excessive media coverage of the Columbine Shooting shouts accusations in all directions blaming violent American history, entertainment, musicians and the `breakdown of the American family structure' for the contaminated minds of violent youth. Moore then shares a brief insight to our bloody American history mocking prejudicial fear traced from our founding four fathers trough slavery and repression to our current Iraq situation. Our casualty cluttered heritage is further exploited as dark bloody images of our history's victims are paraded in celebration of our all mighty power to the song of Ray Charles's What a Wonderful World, creating ironically morbid eye opener. Now having convinced his audience that our haunting past lives in the present, Moore decides to remind us of Germany's Nazi camps, Japan's invasion of China, and the British ruling do to use of guns. Still, The United Kingdom, Germany, France, Canada, Australia and Japan's murder rates combined equaled 973 compared with 11,127 in the United States. The question then arose; maybe America just has more guns than those countries. Unfortunately, that was not the answer; as of Canada's ten million families there are seven million guns. After interviewing several teenage boys in Canada Moore found that people there tend to watch just as many violent movies as do Americans, yet still return home at night leaving their doors unlocked as they retire for the evening. While sitting at a Canadian bar contemplating the vast differences of Windsor's ethnically diverse community versus Detroit's just across the river, Moore focuses on Canadian evening news discussing new speed bumps added to the streets rather than several shootings as found on U.S. television. After reviewing many recent stories covered in U.S. media such as Y2k, razors in Halloween candy apples, animal attacks and the migration of deadly African Bees, the message is clear. As Marilyn Manson had claimed in his interview with Moore `if the media keeps everyone afraid, they'll consume'. A police officer interviewed, states that although crime rates had consistently dropped 30% within the last 5 years that media coverage had increased over 600% causing viewers to feel safer at home watching the news rather then venturing forth from their locked doors. When a news cameraman in Hollywood was asked if he would choose a story of a shooting over a near drowning he confirmed that shootings are sought as audience attention grabbers. When a couple of Canadian kids were asked why Canadians were not as violent as Americans they responded that `we are not pumped full of fear like they are in the U.S.'. And here it is, in Michael Moore's self glamorizing attempt to discover the cause of our self-destruction he himself contributes to the source filling fear in the open minds of content American viewers such as myself with brutal visions of hatred. Yes, I agree with Michael's closing thought, `It is a glorious time to be an American'.Works Cited Bowling for Columbine. Writ. Michael Moore.Prod. Michael Moore. 2002</fullReview>

		<username>kapali</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A modern satirist ---POSSIBLE SPOILERS</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While Michael Moore's "Bowling for Columbine" is hardly a balanced account, and I'd be worried about anyone who was swayed by its arguments, I found it to be a funny and profound condemnation of America's obsession with guns. Some of Moore's assertions are a little trite and easy, but he does provide a disturbing satire on American gun culture. This is one of those rare cases where a film deserving of an Oscar actually won the award. Moore himself, I might add, comes across as an intelligent, likeable, and articulate individual.Reasoned arguments do not make good movies, which rely on relatively simple arguments joined with evocations of strong emotions. Moore does make effective use of such techniques, but his arguments could actually have been a little stronger. The viewer is made cognizant of much of the folly, cruelty, insensitivity, and general stupidity behind America's love of guns. The director's sense of humor, inspired choices of interviewees, and general wittiness mark him as a talented satirist.Some of Moore's assertions do weaken the general impact of the film. He appears to blame gun violence in America largely on whites' fears of blacks and on media manipulation of those fears. As an American living in England, I can say that the local television news in American is more sensational and exploitative than television in the UK, but it is different in degree, not in kind. The media in the UK can be pretty bad, and newspapers here are often far worse than newspapers in the US. Consequently, Moore's argument does not work. His assertions that racist fears have fueled America's obsession with guns is no more convincing. While such fears have undoubtedly played a part in that obsession, the situation is surely more complex, and a cartoon version of American history, like that Moore gives in his film, does not prove his argument. It is funny though. His explorations of historical reasons are a distraction. Those reasons are simply too complex to present in a work like this, and Moore's simplifications distract him from his main target.I was also troubled by some factual manipulation. For example, Moore provides us with the number of murders committed by guns in the US and the much lower numbers committed in other wealthy democracies. While the disproportionate numbers are frightening, they give no indication that violence is more pervasive in the US than in the other countries. In order to say that violence is more pervasive in the US, the total number of murders (expressed as ratios to the populations of the countries) would have had to be presented, whether they are committed with guns or with other weapons. If the total murder rates were then similar in the US and the other democracies, many of Moore's conclusions just would not hold. I suspect that the US is a relatively more violent society, but that suspicion is hardly proof I could use in an argument. A more thorough examination of the facts would have helped to make the director's assertions more convincing.These faults do not, however, greatly detract from the impact of the movie.The viewer should be aware that "Bowling for Columbine" is not a "factual" documentary. It is a satire. This should not deter anyone from viewing it, however. It is well made, effective, funny, and profoundly disturbing.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>One of the best films of 2002-2003!! Definetly the best documentary i've ever seen.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Documentaries are perhaps the most overlooked movies out there. Most of them are considered just as interesting and exciting as spending an hour at school. Well this is neither boring or dull and it manages to be interesting, watchable by everyone while effectively dealing with a very serious subject: gun possession and murders in USA. The film itself, as suggested by the title, is mainly about the Columbine High School Massacre. It tries to explain who is responsible for that tragedy and why a large part of the American population owns guns. The film moves in an excellent and very original pace ,for a documentary, it goes from hilarious to shocking, then depressing, then hillarious again and so on and so forth. Michael Moore examines every aspect of the problem, from America's history and the Wars that America has been, directly or indirectly, involved in to the influence of rock music and Marylin Manson who ,very much to my surprise, speaks very logically like a very sensible man, ditching his monster of rock persona (but not the make-up). Also worth of note is a short film by Mat Stone and Trey Parker about America's history. The main question that Moore poses throughout the film is why the USA has such so many shooting victims when other countries that have an equally if more blood-filled history (Germany and Britain are stated as examples), similar social problems like unemployment and poverty have significantly smaller numbers of shooting victims. Although a direct answer is not given, several factors are hinted, like the fact the governement it self with the wars that it wages promotes gun violence and violence in general. The biggest problem is, according to Moore, fear. Fear which is caused by the media and their constant coverage of violence making the people afraid of their own neihbors. Towards the end of the film we get to see Moore as an activist as we see his and two Columbine survivors' (successful in the end) effort to make Wal Mart ban the sale of guns and ammo. The film ends with Moore ridiculing the president of the NRA, Charlton Heston. In conclusion, this is a very enlightening and moving documentary about a very serious problem. No matter what you thing about gun possession you have to have a look at it. Could be the best film of the year. 10/10</fullReview>

		<date>2003-10-12</date>
		<username>Roland E. Zwick (magneteach@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Horrifying and Hilarious Documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>`If more guns made people safer, then America would be one of the safest countries in the world.'This statement, uttered midway through the film by a Canadian citizen, serves pretty much as the guiding thesis for `Bowling For Columbine,' the amazing, eye-opening `dissertation' by Michael Moore, which won the Oscar for Best Documentary Feature of 2002. Moore, the well-known left-wing tub-thumper and self-appointed thorn-in-the-side of the American conservative establishment, is clearly a man on a mission. He wants to figure out why exactly it is that Americans seem to have a running love affair with violence and guns. Moore takes on Charlton Heston, the NRA (of which Moore claims to be a member), the news media, and the overall culture of paranoia and fear that seems to hold Americans in its grasp. The director views the Columbine High School shootings in 1999 as the symptom rather than the cause of the problem, the inevitable tragic outcome of a munitions-obsessed culture.Anybody turning to this film for a `fair' and `unbiased' study of the problem certainly does not know much about Michael Moore and the kind of movies he makes. Moore is upfront and utterly unapologetic about his own left-leaning sympathies and the film will assuredly outrage many on the opposing side of the issue. Yet one thing that even Moore's greatest detractors will have to admit is that he is definitely a man of passion, an individual who sees a problem in the world and who pools his resources and skills as a documentarian to help awaken public consciousness and, thereby, prompt reasonable-thinking people to come up with a solution.Perhaps, the most astonishing thing about `Bowling For Columbine' is just how funny so much of it turns out to be. Though basically a jeremiad, Moore's film still manages to find humor in the mind-bending absurdity and jaw-dropping irony of so much of what we see on screen. Moore is an amazing satirist, yet in many cases all he has to do is to let the people and situations speak for themselves in order to achieve his laughs. For instance, he starts off his film answering an ad from a bank (of all places!) that offers its customers a gun for opening up a new account. No fictional satirist could come up with better material than that. Why press your issues when your subjects are doing such a fine job of it for you? From that point on, Moore is off and running, taking swipes at not just the NRA but at the defense industry, the Clinton and Bush administrations, welfare reform, and shows like `COPS,' which Moore sees as exploiting and enhancing Americans' irrational fear of crime and people of color. In some ways, these are the weakest sections of the film, perhaps because Moore seems to be casting his net a bit too widely, muddling his message and making assumptions that sometimes seem unwarranted and overly simplistic. One appreciates his attempt to come up with some possible wider answers, but, frankly, he is at his most compelling when - for lack of a better phrase - he keeps the gun industry and those who support it clearly in his sights.Still, Moore makes a compelling case for much of what he is implying in this film - that the culture of violence is all-encompassing in this nation and that incidents like Columbine are just small pieces in an overall much larger picture. Sure there are those who will accuse Moore of being `un-American,' of always trying to cast the United States in the worst possible light, of even, perhaps, giving `aid and comfort' to the nation's enemies. Yet, isn't this what a healthy free society needs - someone who is willing to point out a nation's shortcomings in the hope of making it a better place in which to live? It seems to me we need more Moore's - on both the left and the right - to help keep the powers-that-be honest and connected to the concerns of ordinary people.Alternately hilarious and horrifying, harrowing and heartbreaking, `Bowling For Columbine' will make you cry one moment and laugh the next. Moore is a man in total control of his medium, his message, even, perhaps, his audience. That might be a scary, dangerous thought if you happen to find yourself on the opposite side of the issue from Moore. After all, one man's `truth' can be another man's `propaganda.' All I can suggest is that, regardless of which side of the political spectrum you fall on, give the man a fair hearing. The right should be so lucky as to have a filmmaker of Mr. Moore's caliber and skill on its team. Perhaps some day it will.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE (2002) D: Michael Moore **1/2 Make no mistake, I think Michael Moore is a jerk who made a buffoon of himself at the Academy Awards, and tries to make idiots out of Americans here, too. Heston is filmed distantly from behind and "appears" to turn to look at the picture but then continues to walk away, disinterested. There is speculation on the internet that these sequences may have been faked, with Moore's substituting the shot of himself holding the photo afterward. I wouldn't doubt it. There would have to have been two cameramen at work, and it's clear that there is not one present by Heston in the shots where Heston walks away - so who was filming Moore from the front at this time?Moore's ultimate nerve at taking the liberty of placing the photo of the dead girl at Heston's home is more cruel and unforgivable than anything he tries to expose in his shockumentary.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Provocative, stirring, insanely funny...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's a real shame that such a wonderful, hysterical documentary as "Bowling for Columbine" had to gradually sink to a level of infamy this past year - when, around the time it won its Oscar, reports surfaced that a good amount of footage, facts, and interviews were grossly manipulated. I have never seen any other previous works of Michael Moore, but have heard a great deal about the notoriously outspoken, leftist filmmaker who made "Roger &amp; Me" and "The Big One". Apparently he has quite the reputation for fabricating a lot of his material, and putting such shameless spins on certain subjects that it ends up ultimately alienating the viewer.However, as flawed as this film clearly is in some respects, one must give Mr. Moore a lot of credit for having the gusto to put together such a fascinating collage of biting social commentary - biased or not - on the U.S.' current obsessive state in gun culture and violence.Featuring an impressive number of different interviews and celebrity run-ins with the likes of rock icon Marilyn Manson, Matt Stone (the co-creator of TV's "South Park"), and NRA spokesman Charlton Heston, "Bowling for Columbine" is a constantly riveting, never boring, look into some subject matter that I don't think has ever been presented like this before. It's certainly a very powerful piece, and contains a lot of half-serious, half-amusing coverage on everything from American history to violent influential sources to Canada by comparison...and of course, to the film's centerpiece: the tragic massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado on April 20th, 1999. I admire Michael Moore very much for this inspired presentation, its creative interaction, and its bevy of interesting (albeit sometimes exaggerated) "facts" on various issues. Say what you will about its credibility now, but there's no denying that this man can make a film with a rich scope and a thought-provoking atmosphere. Always a ripe topic for discussion, "Bowling for Columbine" is a flawed masterpiece of voyeuristic filmmaking, and undoubtedly one of the funniest, saddest, and most heart-wrenching pictures I have ever seen.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-03-24</date>
		<username>Dylan-12</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not a bad documentary, but very good agit-prop satire.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's interesting to see this documentary arouse so much ire from the American pro-gun lobby - possibly those most fervent with criticism haven't seen it, as it extends much of the argument that the NRA itself puts forward: that guns themselves are not the problem. Yes, Moore plays a little fast and loose with the chronology and comparisons. OK, so Germany and Japan have hugely violent histories, but the violence was State violence, committed by governments against their own or foreign populations, not the citizen led "frontier" violence which is seen to make up so much of US history. Moreover Moore can be accused of resorting to the same hype and hysteria that he then berates the US media for indulging in.Moore works a lot on guilt by association - that Columbine and the bombing of Belgrade happened on the same day is only of symbolic importance. In the end, it's not really guns that Moore is after. He sees them as a symptom of the deeper problems that are his favourite targets - US foreign policy, the lack of an adequate welfare system, White America's mistreatment of its minorities, and corporate malfeasance and perniciousness.Moore's real heart and energy lies in issues like the failure of welfare to work schemes, which seems to take up a quarter of the film's running time, and the way big business has left the working classes to rot as they move out in search of cheaper foreign labour and a higher profit margin - pretty much the themes of Roger and Me and Downsize This. But he rightly knows that these are not hot-button issues. Guns are!Seen this way, it's no surprise that his critique of gun culture is so scatter shot and poorly aimed, pardon the puns, relying on the likes of Marilyn Manson, himself an arch exploiter of the culture of fear and alienation to produce popular consumer fodder that he and Moore attack, to spew out glib Oprah-isms: "I would have just listened to them (Klebold and Harris, the Columbine killers) - That's what no-one did", etc. How much of their well documented, pathetic, often racist fantasies and paranoia he would have been able to sit through before telling them just to grow up a little?After this, it comes across as a little unfair that Charlton Heston and the National Rifle Association are held up as Moore's prime scapegoats, (though one has to wonder, as Heston surely does in retrospect, "what was he thinking, if thinking it was?" in response to many of his poor, ill-or-rather-unadvised responses, his alleged mental incapacity notwithstanding).After all, as obnoxious as they are, the NRA's crimes are merely gross insensitivity, blatant opportunism and misguided zeal. However while the gun issue is never satisfactorily resolved, Moore really strikes home by correctly widening the question beyond the simple issue of gun availability, to point out these issues do not exist in a social vacuum, that the violence and fear emerge from underlying structural problems in American society, even though such problems seem to exist elsewhere in the developed world without such lethal results. Could it be that the core American values of self reliance, meritocracy and achievement, and the equivalent distaste at such concepts as social justice (read "social engineering") and community (read "communism") can't help but breed this degree of panic, insecurity and paranoia? If you are constantly in competition with your neighbour, isn't it natural to fear and resent him? In one of the film's few worthwhile celebrity moments, Matt Stone of Southpark fame identifies the fear of failure relentlessly hammered into school children as a major source of the damage. (ironically, and much to Michael Moore's chagrin, George Bush has tried to do something to repair the harm, by exhorting in a graduation speech, that these days "...Even a C student can get to be President")Many have questioned the film's value as a documentary, whether such an obviously partial and polemic film can be considered a documentary at all. After all the film is far shorter on facts than it is on shock, sensation and opinion. Such questions are not asked by people interested in the epistemology of the documentary form, but by those who wish to denigrate the film by holding it against some bogus "gold standard" of objectivity, no doubt inspired by the bland pedagogy of the educational programming found on the National Geographic or Discovery Channels.Bowling for Columbine is not and never pretends to be journalism (apart from maybe in its more "gonzo" forms). Moore's approach maybe more closely related to satire and agitprop than the traditional documentarian would feel comfortable with, but that in itself is not a fault. Those who offer such criticism fail to see that ALL documentaries have a subjective point of view and will never achieve unsullied access to some supernatural truth. "Bowling for Columbine" admits and confronts you with its biases is all the stronger for admitting its position. Identifying it as something other than a documentary would neither mitigate its weaknesses nor diminish its effectiveness and power. Those who disagree are invited to make their own films and add to the debate.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I just watched Bowling For Columbine this afternoon, and was totally fascinated. They gave statistics for France, Germany, Canada, UK, Japan and Australia, which, combined, came to roughly 800 deaths a year from shooting. Total combined population of those countries is about 380 million. Deaths by shooting in America totalled 11, 200 in the same year. With a population of approximately 280 million.The obvious answers included that America 'had a more violent history' (proposed by Charlton Heston) but that was shot down, because Germany and England have a bloodier history. Heston also said (and I quote) maybe it was because America 'has greater ethnicity'. An answer which Moore ,rightly, didn't even dignify with a response.Gun availability? Apparently Canada has 7 million guns in a population of 30 million, freely available from any gun store, with proper permits.In the end Moore puts forward the proposition that the reason behind the violence in America is the culture of fear, with the media largely to blame. One news anchorman admitted that if they had to choose between reporting on a gun related story or the near drowning of a baby (this was filmed at the scene of one such incident) they would go to the gun story every time. The film suggested that Americans are bombarded nightly with TV horror stories on the news and shows like Cops, and that they are so fearful they have learned that guns will keep them safe. While filming in Canada he showed a montage of the news items there, which were far less dramatic, and with less emphasis on ratings-grabbing drama. He interviewed a number of people who said they never locked their doors, even in Toronto, a city of millions, and when he went to check, by opening doors in random houses, it was true. They just said they weren't really afraid in their communities, although they had sometimes been victims of crime.There were issues of racism, and some possibly far-fetched conspiracy theories involving Lockheed and other big corps, but on the whole I was engaged by the argument here, and I'm not even talking about such emotive incidents as the NRA rallies held in Columbine and Flint after the school shootings there. But he made some good points about families and communities and the inefficacy of the Welfare to Work program, on the whole I was gripped throughout and wondered how it was received in America, since it was pretty critical of some sections of American society.Interestingly Michael Moore is a lifetime member of the NRA, but i couldnt help wondering if he had kept it up merely to allow him access to people who otherwise might have refused to talk to him.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Michael Moore didn't come up with much fresh material this time around. Most compelling scenes were now-old news footage rehashing Columbine pathos. Drug abuse -- and, okay Michael, perhaps even bowling -- contributed to the final disaster. At least the material linked to Moore because one of these recent school killings was in his hometown of Flint, Michigan, so that this film is a sort of sequel to his earlier documentaries. The statistical part of the film, closer to the end, where Moore compares the US to other countries that have much less murder per capita, is genuinely thought-provoking. The appearance of Charlton Heston, however, must have inspired the filmmakers into some unrealistic sense of grandeur as far as running time is concerned. Like some of Heston's other film accomplishments, this one is just too darn long for the amount of material it has to cover.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-01-18</date>
		<username>Spleen</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>This is the kind of thing we want from a documentary.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's good that the guy in charge of the whole thing is willing to stand in front of the camera HIMSELF, and simply tell us whatever it is he wishes to tell us. He doesn't fancy himself an artist (yet he knows enough not to resort to digital tape, and to tell his crew to hold the cameras as steadily as possible, which is more than most documentary-makers know) and he realises that his job is to inform. Simple virtues, but rare ones.Predictably a few clueless souls complain about Moore's "bias". It could hardly be otherwise if the work were any good. It's the object of any documentary - of any work of nonfiction whatever - to be as biased as possible: biased towards the truth. Since Moore's desire to get to the bottom of things is obviously genuine, and since his biases in fact lead him to get things right rather than wrong, the most serious charge that can be laid against him is that he is sometimes tactically unfair - as in the Charlton Heston interview at the end. No doubt Heston deserved it, but that's no justification. Still, the points Moore is making here are correct.So why ARE there so many armed murders in the United States, according to Moore? He answers this question in the only reasonable way: by taking every promising line of inquiry in turn, favouring those that are more promising than others. Some lines of inquiry he dismisses too readily. It can't be that there's so many guns so readily available, he says: just look at Canada, with no shortage of firepower, but a far lower murder rate. Too brisk. He hasn't established that Canada's GUN (as opposed to bullet) control laws aren't relevantly different; and even if they aren't, lax or laxly enforced gun control is still - obviously - a necessary condition for a high armed murder rate, and therefore, in some sense, a contributing cause.It can't be America's violent past, or brutal foreign policy, says Moore, since America is not unique in these respects: look, for instance, at Germany. Too glib. In many ways America IS unique, or almost so. The highest murder rates in recorded histoy occur in California - in the NINETEENTH century. And it's undeniable that, in the past fifty years or so, no country in the world has been so consistently brutal in its foreign policy. Germany looks nasty if you look at the decade 1935-45, but not otherwise. The USA looks nasty if you look at ANY period of time from WWII on; there are simply too many atrocities for Moore to be able to fit them into his montage (which should have begun, I think, with the bombing of cities - Dresden and Hiroshima and Nagasaki - DURING the war, since if there was ever a violent turning point, this was it). Is there a link between the US's unparallelled international brutality and its ALMOST unparallelled murder rate? Not obviously not.But Moore's central claim is still half-right: it's not the fact that half the federal budget is spent on tools of destruction that's responsible for the domestic violence (there's a telling moment when the guy from the world's largest arms manufacturer says that he's making weapons purely for defensive purposes ... and, so help us all, he REALLY BELIEVES IT), but the fact that this money thereby ISN'T spent on medicine, art, education, welfare, public transport ... in short, on anything useful whatever.Okay, Moore can only answer his central question with perfect accuracy because his answer is "I don't know". But he still comes a good deal closer to knowing than most people.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-12-16</date>
		<username>pweb</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>redefining documentary?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I found Michael Moore a pretty unattractive character, I liked his documentary. No wonder it was a hit at Cannes. Firstly, the overall structure, the way the material divided up into phases each with a distinctly different feel, was reminiscent of some very enjoyable feature films, creating the impression of guiding the viewer on a tour through a succession of different places. In fact in many ways he&gt; borrowed from the feature film genre very effectively. Phases I identify include: a) Humorous - Starting right out with some nice easy humour to get us on side and relax us. b) Shocking - Flashing up a succession of brutal images. c) Objective - Looking at the statistics, trying to pick up an overall view of the gun/violence situation. d) Voyeuristic - Giving us a nightly news style intrusive view of Columbine massacre, complete with voiceovers of people in emotional meltdown. e) Exploratory - Taking off to Canada to look at alternatives. f) Confrontational - Taking on K-Mart and Charlton Heston. Secondly he had a good repertoire of filmaker trick to throw at us. I liked the way he opened with some of his best material (free gun for opening bank account), which said to us, I've got some good stuff to show you. The use of humour to lull us into a comfortable relaxed state before hitting us over the head with some brutal violence, echoed, for example, what Tarantino did so effectively in Pulp Fiction. The occasional deliberate rough-round-the-edge moment contrasted nicely with the overall polish of the piece. e.g. the grossly overexposed footage for the wheelchair going into K-Mart said to us: "We've only got one crack at this. No time to stop and pretty it up". I especially liked the way Charlton Heston kept popping up, building, though we didn't know, to the final confrontation. Thirdly, his skillful manipulation of the audience in presenting himself as the little guy hero with a sort of child-like innocence saying "Wow, I didn't know I could do this". We see him as a big kid (scruffy clothes, baseball cap) doing things we know are a little bit naughty, but we secretly admire him for getting away with it, pushing the envelope. Like when the camera peers over his shoulder when they've been told to stay out of the bedroom. In fact the emotional manipulation, was probably the key to this film's success. Sometimes I'm tempted to have reservations about whether filmmakers should be doing this, but don't we just allow ourselves to be manipulated? They do it so well in some feature films, but I can't recall seeing it used so effectively in a documentary before.</fullReview>
	</review>

An astonishing sequence in which Moore takes two Columbinestudents, with bullets still in their bodies, to Kmart headquarters to"return the merchandise." (The Columbine killers bought theirammunition at their local Kmart.) Kmart actually agrees to stopselling ammunition at its stores. ? Moore may be amarksman, but this target proves elusive.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Why you should and shouldn't see Bowling for Columbine</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Early in the film, Moore tells us that he is a card-carrying member of the National Rifle Association, and he points out that Canada has more guns per capita and less gun violence than the United States has. If the guns alone are not the problem, he asks, what is? He proceeds to examine aspects of our culture, especially our media, that may promote fear and hostility (he does not blame the common scapegoats, lyrics and video games). It's an important topic, and Moore points out a great number of facts that seem relevant to the discussion.I didn't agree with everything Moore said and implied, though, and you certainly won't. For example he criticizes local news broadcasts for repeatedly showing African Americans in handcuffs, and this imagery seems to me to be more a symptom of gun violence than a cause. He ambushes Charlton Heston in his home under arguably false pretenses, and asks the actor and NRA chairman to apologize for holding rallies near, school shootings. While his accusation of insensitivity may be on target, Moore chooses, at this point, to ignore his earlier point, that given the example of Canada something other than high rates of gun ownership must be at work. He might have addressed this point in his conversation with Heston and acknowledged the possibility that by holding these rallies the NRA might be making the same legitimate point that Moore himself was making in the beginning of the film; that gun ownership rates and gun violence (with its associated raw emotions) could be separated in the national conversation.Bowling for Columbine is by no means an evenhanded treatise, nor does it offer a clear path to a reduction in gun crime. However it's an important film because of the questions it will raise in your mind, many of which have probably not occurred to you.Why you should see it: You take the duties of citizenship seriously and believe you're obligated to give a fair hearing to multiple opinions on an issue like gun violence.Why you shouldn't see it: Hearing the name "Michael Moore" renders you incapable of giving anything or anyone a fair hearing for approximately two hours.--from my review at www.1man365movies.com</fullReview>

		<date>2007-10-31</date>
		<username>Jake Cole</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>An Even-Handed Look at Gun Violence</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore's documentaries are heavily criticized for their one-sided portrayal of the films topic. People don't seem to realize that nearly all documentaries (with the main exception of Ken Burns' work and nature docs like Planet Earth) are biased. However, Bowling For Columbine is a pretty objective look at why Americans have more gun-related deaths than any other developed country. Moore mainly uses the Columbine shooting and the shooting of a six year old girl named Kayla by another six year old as his big examples of the violence in America.Moore interviews a wide variety of people from law officials to Columbine survivors to Canadian citizens to shock-rocker Marilyn Manson. He interviews Canadian citizens and politicians as to why Canada, despite having 7 million guns in 10 million houses, has only a few gun deaths a year. Michael uses Canadian interviews juxtaposed against Americans' opinions why gun violence is so prevalent in the US. All the reasons people list are refuted as Canada has the same issues and population.Moore spends the bulk of the film analyzing the Columbine massacre (makes sense; Columbine's in the title), and interviews people who knew the boys, survivors, Lockheed Martin execs (the company that made the weapons), and the outspoken father of one of the victims. The best interview, however, is with Marilyn Manson. Manson received a lot of blame for the massacre basically for being weird and a rock star. He has the most articulate musings on the killing. You can tell as Michael interviews him that Manson has thought long and hard about this. As someone who became a scapegoat for no justifiable reason, he has studied the event and what may have actually caused it, something the media never really did. He gives the most thought-provoking response in the entire film when Moore asks him what he would say to Eric Harris, on of the Columbine shooters. Without hesitation he says "I wouldn't have said anything to him, I would have listened to what he had to say." Anyone who considers Manson a brainless, evil rocker should check out this interview.Moore, a member of the NRA, doesn't condemn the organization, though he strongly objects to some rallies that Charlton Heston held following both of the shootings Michael covers. Many accuse Moore of bullying, but in his interview with Heston, Michael is the calm one. Where some would just lay blame at Heston's feet, Moore is genuinely interested in the man's opinion of the root of the number of gun deaths.Despite funny interaction, powerful archival footage, and captivating interviews, the film is not without flaws. While Moore investigates the cause of the death of Little Kayla, he confronts Dick Clark because the mother of the boy who shot the girl worked a second job at Dick Clark's restaurant. Dick Clark has the thinnest possible tie to the case, yet Moore makes him out to look like a jerk for not granting an interview. This is where the accusation of bullying could be valid. Also, he uses certain camera shots to suggest things about some people (Clark, Heston, and an LA sergeant) that may or may not be true. He makes them into jerks or racists, which really can't be determined by a little camera work though it can mislead. Still, this is a wonderful look into violence and the media that feeds it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-03-20</date>
		<username>Benjamin Cox</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Moore's finest but as heavily one-sided as the man himself -92%</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It took me a long time after release before I sat down to watch this. But I do remember being intrigued - I hadn't lived in London for very long and had spotted the posters on the Underground (which seems to have more posters than trains these days). Having read Moore's book "Stupid White Men" (and later, "Dude, Where's My Country?"), Moore technique could be described as using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. He is more in-your-face version of British comedian and political activist Mark Thomas. And while "Fahrenheit 9/11" might have earned more at the box office, this is by far and away his best film.Moore examines the reasons behind the tragic school shooting at the Columbine high school in Colorado (and others, including one in Moore's hometown of Flint, Michigan). Desperate to discover why more civilians are shot and killed in America than almost anywhere else, he explores the given reasons that it's violent video games or Marilyn Manson but quickly finds out that this is nonsense. Moore believes that the answers lay with a media that perpetuate the myth that America is gripped with violent criminals (it isn't - as one vox-pop says, crime is actually falling yet fear of crime is rising), the politicians that continually reinforce people's fear and the blatant hypocrisy of the National Rifle Association (NRA) and their ageing leader, Charlton Heston.Despite being marketed as some sort of comedian, Moore's points are far from funny. America is seen as a paranoid consumer-driven land of gun-owning maniacs and befuddled individuals lost in the chaos. True, the point does come across as amusing some times such as the bank that gives out a free gun on site whenever you open an account or the "South Park"-style animation halfway through detailing America's past and it's love of all things that go bang. At times, you can't help but shake your head at some of those who appear. One guy, who frankly should be locked up straight away, is telling Moore how hacked off he was when he discovered that he was second on the police's list of potential bombers. Not that he was upset at being appointed as some kind of risk but because some guy was actually more a threat than him - despite owning a manual describing how to make explosives and the guy making bombs a little smaller than a pipe-bomb. What the Hell did the number one guy have - a stealth bomber perhaps or a stolen warhead maybe? Moore's argument is undeniably convincing, given that the point is rammed home throughout the film that it is the media and government that have driven America to the brink of implosion. Moore's argument is helped by a cunning combination of interviews (or attempted interviews) with those in the heart of the matter and biting questions to those who Moore knows will not answer. Heston is worked over like a featherweight training with Tyson, storming out of his interview and leaving a poignant moment as the film closes. A number of those Moore speaks to recognise that there is a real problem in America, including K-Mart who Moore visits with two survivors of the Columbine massacre and who then agree to withdraw selling bullets in K-Mart ninety days later. The trouble is, Moore's detractors aren't allowed too much time to make their point of view. Personally, I got the sense that Moore was fighting a losing battle against American society as a whole and the corporations making a shed load of cash from people's fears. It isn't quite as one-sided as "Fahrenheit 9/11" and to be fair, most non-Americans know that there's a problem with guns in the States anyway. Indeed, he has a hard time convincing most Americans that there even is a problem.Disturbing as the truth may be, "Bowling For Columbine" is essential viewing. Despite a few sickening shots of people being shot (no pun intended), this is a film that should be watched by everybody. And although the film pulls no real punches, it is a wicked indication of what's happening in America and how, after recent events in Iraq and Afghanistan, American attitudes are damaging beyond their borders. Even for those who live with their guns under a pillow such as the Michigan Militia, this film will hopefully ring plenty of alarm bells and if it prevents just one more school shooting then it will have done its job. Documentary-making at its finest but not necessarily at its most balanced.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>(SPOILER) Proof that a documentary need not have any factual content.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With Bowling for Columbine, Michael Moore has demonstrated that he wouldn't know truth if it tap-danced on his dinner table. That it was awarded any kind of recognition as a documentary demonstrates that its viewers don't know any more than Moore.Some examples of Moore's lies in this movie include:His alleged membership in the NRA: Michael Moore told Tim Russert that he bought a life membership in the NRA specifically so he could be elected president and make the organization support victim disarmament.The hunting dog video: A complete fabrication, from beginning to end.McVeigh &amp; Nichols: The Michigan Militia threw these two individuals out of their meetings, yet Moore claims they were involved.America is uniquely violent: Not according to Interpol. There is NO record in any crime database of the numbers Moore claimed, for ANY of the countries he mentioned. He deliberately increases the US numbers and lowers the other numbers in every case, and does not mention that Japan's suicide rate ALONE is greater than America's homicide and suicide rates COMBINED.Charlton Heston: Moore is at his most creative here, cutting between numerous public events that take place up to a year after Columbine in order to make it appear that Heston was crass and barbaric just days afterwards. He not only deliberately lied about what Heston said, and when he said it, he lied about Heston's long history of civil rights activism. (What other actor do you know who joined Martin Luther King Jr. in his 1963 march on Washington?)The Michigan bank: Moore lies, claiming that one could go into the bank, open an account, and walk out with a gun. What he doesn't tell you is that you go into the bank, open an account, and get a gift certificate that you have to take to the gun store the bank was working with, submit to a criminal investigation, and then get not just any gun, but the riflery equivalent of a Rolls Royce. The only difference between that bank's program and those of other banks that give cars as premiums is that up until the PATRIOT act, you didn't have to submit to a criminal investigation to get a car from a dealer. Now you have to prove that you're not a terrorist even to get a car, which FINALLY puts car buyers in the same boat gun buyers have been in since 1968.Canada: More lies, of course. Far from Moore's vision of Canada as a gun-free haven, the fact is that nearly 2/3 of Canada's homicides are committed with firearms, according to the National Post. And the Canadian health care system that Moore describes in such glowing terms is in reality so poor that medical professionals are moving to the US to escape it, and many Canadians cross the border in search of American medical care because they don't trust the quality, nor can they afford to wait - sometimes for years - for basic care that one can get in a matter of weeks in the U.S. And then there's the Canadian Walmart scene, which was either in violation of Canadian law or deliberately edited by Moore to appear as something other than it was. Moore has refused all requests by the Canadian government to explain whether he faked the purchase, edited out the ID request, or violated the law.Race in America: A few points Moore either skips over or deliberately lies about include: Canada's minority population is incredibly low. The black population, for instance, is just over 1% (vs. 11% of the U.S.) of Canada's population - in fact, Detroit alone has more black people than the entire population (white and minority combined) of Canada. According to the FBI and the DoJ, over 70% of the violent crime in America takes place in inner cities, and in over 50% of violent crime, either the perpetrator, or the victim, or (usually) both, is black. Moore tries to link violent crime to slavery - yet fails to explain how the freed slaves and their children had a LOWER crime rate than inner cities do today. Willie Horton Ad: Moore combines two different ads, AND adds text that was not in EITHER ad, in order to make it appear that the people responsible for the phony ad he created for his movie were racists. He also fails to mention that it was Al Gore who originally condemned Michael Dukakis for his prison furlough program.Dick Clark: Kayla Rolland's killer's mother worked at a restaurant owned in part by Dick Clark. Somehow, this gives Moore the basis for a claim that Dick Clark is partially responsible for Kayla's murder.Kayla Rolland: According to Moore, her killer "just happened" to find a gun that he "just happened" to shoot her with, and nobody knows why. Oddly enough, the school she attended knew why, as did the police and prosecutors. The boy was known to the school to be violent, had previously been suspended from school three times, and had previously stabbed another girl. On top of this, he lived in a crack house that his uncle ran, his father was in jail, his grandmother and two aunts were in federal prison, and three other relatives were in jail for dealing crack. The gun he shot Kayla with had been given to his uncle as payment for some crack. So, we have a child with a history of violence, who had attempted at least one other murder in the past, living in a house surrounded by criminals, and somehow this is a reflection on the civilized part of society?All in all, Moore demonstrates that truth means nothing when it gets in the way of putting his point across, and therefore he will lie as much as possible.</fullReview>

Hollywood and "reality" don't have much in common and Mr. Moore's Bowling for Columbine displays this in perfect form.It's unfortunate that many individuals outside of the U.S. (and inside too) will view this film as "fact" and not the true fiction that it really is.Bowling for Columbine falls into the same category as movies such as Attack of the Killer Tomatoes and the Jerky Boys. 		<date>2004-02-15</date>
		<username>Robert J. Maxwell (rmax304823@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Tragedy and manipulation.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first thing that leaps out at a behavioral scientist is how problematic conclusions can be when they're drawn from a documentary movie rather than a respectable scientific study. Example. Near the beginning, Michael Moore interviews a relative of one of the guys who blew up the Murra Building in OK City. He seems a decent sort, describes himself as a "food farmer" and grows soybeans to be turned into tofu. Moore speaks to him in his kitchen about explosives and guns, and the guy begins to get slightly twisted. He carries on about all the explosive ingredients he's got stashed around the farm, about how nobody can protect a person except himself, certainly not the federal government. Does he keep a gun in the house? Absolutely. He sleeps with a .44 magnum under his pillow every night. Moore acts doubtful and asks the guy to prove it. The guy takes Moore into his bedroom, produces the .44, cocks it, and puts it against his own head, chuckling. He's a complete whacko, right?Now let's turn the picture around. Let's imagine Moore interviewing some rabid anti-violence type. It's easy to imagine a nice decent sort of guy who, during an interview, begins to seem twisted and by the end of the talk is raving about aliens being beamed down from UFO with armloads of weapons that they pass out.The kind of nut that Moore looked for, found, and interviewed may be more numerous than the second -- but the fact is we don't know. And before Moore's interview is over we have already formed a picture of the sort of person who collects guns and belongs to the NRA. I imagine there must be thousands of highly responsible NRA members out there, somewhere, but we're stuck with Moore's choice of respondent. That's what I mean by manipulation.Moore raises some extremely important questions -- tucked away amid the irony and agitprop. Countries of Western Europe -- the cheese-eating surrender monkeys -- have a handful of gun-related homicides a year. Canada, with its vast population, has a hundred and some odd. And seven out of ten Canadian households own guns. But the good old USA has over 11,000 shooting deaths during the same period. What's going on?Moore explores a couple of hypotheses. Violent movies and TV shows? Nope. People in other countries lap up our gore fests. The availability of guns? Nope. That's what is known as a necessary but not a sufficient condition. The Canadians have at least as many guns and, though Moore doesn't mention it, Swiss households are required by law to own guns -- it's just that they don't shoot each other the way we do.Moore pins it down, more or less, to the culture of fear we live in. Homicide rates in the USA have dropped precipitately over the past 30 years, but reports of violence have captivated the news media. So while murder has dropped to 20 percent of what it was, reports of violence on TV news has increased by 600 percent. That's okay as far as it goes. The Canadians in Windsor, Ont., may watch the same programs as the people across the river in Detroit, but they probably watch different news programs and are exposed to different role models in their news. (They don't, for instance, have politicians telling us that gays deserve to get AIDS.) Then Moore does something interesting at this point. Windsor is not unfamiliar with crime, including burglary -- it's a big city, about the size of San Francisco. But people in Windsor claim they don't lock their doors. So -- get this -- Moore goes out and walks from door to door checking to see if they're open. (They are.) It's a cute trick and a valuable one, absent a long and expensive survey. Reminds one of the old story about the rationalists and the empiricists in Ancient Greece. The rationalists would sit in a tavern and argue about how many teeth a horse should have in his mouth. An empiricist goes out to the nearest horse and counts the teeth.There isn't space to go into this complicated and controversial movie so I'll just make a few points. Let's grant Moore's proposition that a culture of fear begets the purchase and use of guns. It's a bit murky, but let it go. What, then, creates the fear? What ARE we afraid of? A clue may come from one of the few statistics one of Moore's interviewees cites. Murder has declined to some 20 percent of what it was some 30 years ago, I forget the exact figures but the decline is well established. Why did it decline? There's general agreement that it declined partly or even mainly because the Baby Boomers got older. Thirty years ago they were in their teens and twenties, the age at which violent crimes are most likely to be committed. That leaves the Baby Boomers now in their 50s. They look in the mirror and see what is happening to them -- the declining potency, the falling hair, the bulging thighs, the sagging breasts, the menopause, the intimations of mortality -- and they're frightened. And who can blame them? We have Ralph Nader telling them that everything they drive (or eat) is unhealthy. It's enough to scare anyone, but it's a difficult fear to define, or to aknowledge. The terrorists, the rioting ghettoes, poison in the aspirin bottles, African killer bees, the obesity, the second-hand tobacco smoke, the razor blades in the Halloween apples -- all objectify that nameless dread. I am falling apart but at least NOW I know what I'm scared of. Not impending dissolution but some maniac shooting me at random in the streets.Moore missed another popular explanation (there are surely lots of factors involved). It's been called the founder effect. Homicide rates not only vary between countries but also within the United States. They generally decrease as you move from South to North. Even within some STATES, like Ohio, rates are higher in southern counties than in northern ones. The Western shootout was an extension of Southern codes of honor brought first to Texas, then diffusing throughout the West. It's probably not coincidental that the North was settled by religious Puritans and Quakers whose culture centered on community law, while the South was settled by Cavaliers who were mainly concerned with getting rich and consolidating power on plantations, people of pride who made their own laws.It's a compelling and humorous movie, but it's irritating too. Moore pulls a couple of stunts that will strike many viewers as being in bad taste. He also inviegles his way into an interview with Charlton Heston and then begins challenging him, asking Heston if he'd like to apologize to the people of Littleton, Colorado, for holding an NRA convention there so soon after the shootings at nearby Columbine School. Heston is sadly aged but retains his dignity. He shakes hands, politely excuses himself, and hobbles away while Moore shouts embarrassing questions at him. Moore should watch out or he's liable to start believing in his own myth. The last shot of the film shows Moore rolling a bowling ball down the alley at Littleton. The camera follows the ball thundering along the wooden path so purposefully, so driven, so unerring, until it knocks every pin clattering and Moore racks up a strike. I wish that ball had left a couple of pins standing.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Pure Fiction</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As the record-low television audience that sat through Hollywood`s latest celebration of Hollywood knows, the Academy Award for a feature documentary film was given to Michael Moore`s Bowling for Columbine ?a painfully pretentious work of anti-American, anti-gun, anti-NRA propaganda.But many don`t know that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had to violate its own rules to allow Moore to compete for, much less win, an Oscar. The Academy`s "Special Rules for the Documentary Award" define a documentary film "as a non-fiction motion picture," with the emphasis "on factual content." Bowling for Columbine miserably fails this practical test. It is a work of propaganda, pure and simple, riddled not with slovenly conducted research but with calculated dishonesty.For example, Moore splices together two separate speeches by NRA President Charlton Heston to create the false impression that viewers are seeing a single speech given at the 1999 NRA Annual Meetings in Denver. Moore`s intent is to make NRA`s president appear insensitive to the senseless murders at Columbine High School earlier that year in nearby Littleton.To further his lie, Moore depicts President Heston raising a musket at the Denver meeting and delivering his familiar line "from my cold dead hands." The facts?that President Heston was actually filmed one year later and 1,354 miles away in Charlotte, N.C.?aren`t something Moore cares to document.The deception continues with Moore repeatedly referring to the Denver meetings as pro-gun rallies. He fails to document the well-known fact that out of respect for the families victimized at Columbine, NRA canceled all events and meetings in Denver except those required the Association`s bylaws and laws regarding not-for-profit corporations.No lie is too poisonous for Michael Moore. He actually tries to make viewers believe that NRA makes a habit of holding rallies in the wake of tragic shootings. After failing to document that NRA`s Denver meetings were scheduled years in advance, Moore jumps to a Michigan campaign rally, claiming: "just as he did after the Columbine shooting, Charlton Heston showed up in Flint, to have a big pro-gun rally." Moore wants viewers to believe the Flint rally took place immediately following the shooting death of child in a local classroom. In fact, the rally took place eight months later during the regular campaign season.Another outrageous sequence in Moore`s supposedly "non-fiction motion picture," tries to associate NRA with the Ku Klux Klan and depicts an NRA member assisting in a Klan cross burning. The rationale? NRA was founded in 1871?the year the KKK was declared an illegal organization. The absurd connection is intentional. It`s Michael Moore`s idea of humor.An honest documentary would record that NRA was founded by former Union Army officers who fought a war to bring an end to slavery. It would record that Civil War veteran Maj. Gen. Ambrose Burnside was the Association`s first president. It would record that the man who signed the act making the Klan an illegal organization later became NRA`s eighth president?Ulysses S. Grant.A true documentary would note that NRA`s early history was written by figures who had not only fought to end slavery, but who would later oppose the persecution of freedmen. Such a man would assume command of the Fifth Military District, and he would then remove governors in Texas and Louisiana for failing to oppose the KKK. That man later became NRA`s ninth president?Gen. Philip H. Sheridan.Bowling for Columbine is a compilation of deceit piled upon deceit?facts omitted, time lines distorted, and editing tricks employed to present a false view o f American culture in general and the "gun culture" and NRA in particular. And yet, no matter how shameless its deceptions, no matter how brazen its lies, Moore`s propaganda film does have its fans, including the Brady Campaign.When Moore`s Oscar nomination was announced, the gun-ban group was "very pleased" that " Bowling for Columbine is receiving the acclaim it deserves." The Brady bunch fell silent, however, in the days following Moore`s win. Possibly they found him less appealing after his tasteless Oscar acceptance speech. Unable to resist a captive audience, the self-indulgent Moore railed against the war in Iraq and President Bush. He may have been warmly received by the Hollywood millionaires in the Kodak Theater, but the poseur-populist was booed loudly by the stagehands actually working the event. A clear message was sent.As more and more Americans catch on to the deceit that is Bowling for Columbine , its maker will have to seek out a more gullible audience. The jury at the Cannes Film Festival created a special, one-time only award to honor his film and then gave it a 13-minute standing ovation." Most Americans would gladly say, Au revoir, Monsieur Moore!</fullReview>

		<date>2003-06-29</date>
		<username>bob the moo</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Muddled and a little unfair but a good documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore looks into the gun culture of America to try and find out why America has significantly more gun-related murders than other societies. He focuses his efforts on several small towns where schools have seen several high profile shootings and enlists many people from all walks of life to help him find answers.I enjoy Michael Moore's material. I watched TV Nation, read his books etc but yet I managed to miss this film at the cinema and then not really rush out to see it when it came on video. I finally got round to freeing up some time to watch it and I must admit to having mixed feelings about it. The main thing I think I came back with is that Moore is not as good a satirist as he thinks he is and he often goes over the top and damages his own point.However that is not to say that his work is without merit, because it is and this film deserved to win the Oscar from the pack that it was part of. The plot of the film is an interesting look at the gun culture (and wider issues ) of America. I think it worked well the way it covered a wide subject but occasionally he side tracked himself and confused the issue. Running after Dick Clark to badger him about using welfare workers was pointless for one. He certainly has a good point to make generally and it is hard to watch the film without feeling something.However Moore weakens his own film in two ways ? 1) he presents things as fact that aren't, and 2) he loves to be the centre of things. Firstly Moore uses facts liberally but never really separates the fact and the comic fiction. For example the footage of Heston saying `from my cold dead hands' is edited to suggest he said this in Columbine a few days after the shooting ? this was not the case (as the change of shirt shows). Also comments accredited to the NRA days after the shooting of the little girl were actually a significant time afterwards, right down to little things like the missile plant featured not actually producing weapons at all ? but I guess the transporting of the missile through darkened streets is a powerful image. However I still think he had more than enough good arguments to stop this `spin' spoiling the film.Secondly Moore simply can't do satire as well as some of the top UK people. To illustrate an example of this witness Moore's heralded interview with Charlton Heston. Heston begins to tie himself in knots and comes very close to saying that America has more gun crime because of it's high numbers of ethnic minorities! Rather than giving him enough rope to hang himself, Moore continually interrupts and actually gives Heston time to talk his way out of the hole ? with space Heston would have just dug himself a deeper pit. The interview still has merit (Heston walking off is a good shot) but it could have been better. Likewise, the Columbine kids at Walmart is a powerful few scenes and Moore should really have let the kids take centre stage ? instead he came across as someone who was exploiting the kids to his own ends.These are important flaws but I still found the documentary an interesting if harrowing affair. The scale of the problem is obvious and Moore has a good crack at trying to get answers. Some of his editing is in poor taste (a correlation between the NRA and KKK is drawn but then retracted ? but the retraction is treated as a gag) but the majority of the arguments presented are convincing. I actually found the film better when Moore let the material do the work rather than him. Seeing the history of the US was jaw dropping (and still is everytime I hear the same things in different sources) and to hear the speech by the father of one of the Columbine victims had me starting to cry. But sadly Moore too often badgers people rather than letting them speak.Overall I thought this was a good film that was thoughtful and reasonably well presented. It is a little misleading at times and Moore is given to going off on side issues too easily or hogging the camera when he should let the story speak for itself, but it is still hard not to get involved in this film and go away with a feeling that, whatever the causes, America has certainly gotten itself into quite a state and needs some strong domestic solutions just as much as we are told it needs military action abroad.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-02-25</date>
		<username>paul2001sw-1 (paul2001sw@yahoo.co.uk)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Mostly on target</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Bowling for Columbine' is Michael Moore's entertaining, and scary, journey through America's gun culture. As ever, Moore's style is more discursive than forensic, not every point he makes is relevant and some appear contradictory: he asks more questions than he answers. But he never loses sight of the bigger picture, namely that, unacknowledged by politicians, the U.S.A. is divided between the privileged and the under-privileged, and that this divide is crucial to understanding American society. A more telling criticism can be made of Moore's liking for stunts, in which he usually ridicules a soft target with emotive arguments. This use of emotion sometimes seems to ignore the fact that we are all morally compromised, one way or the other: picking on a random institution or individual and asking them to justify their behaviour could be seen as missing the point. For example, Moore attacks K-Mart for selling bullets for automatic weapons; but if it is legal to sell such ammunition, why shouldn't K-Mart have the same rights to sell it as anybody else? And is it fair to attack companies for trying to make profits when you own (via your pension) a share in such firms, and would doubtless moan if your pension collapsed because the management didn't pursue the profit motive? At times, Moore makes one squirm; and yet the alternative is to accept the status quo, and to assume that if everyone is doing evil then it can't be evil after all. Moore personalises issues; but without such personalisation, is there any possibility of change? We make the world we live in: at some level, we have to take responsibility. If you don't like Moore's choice of target, then the challenge is to find another. Or to do nothing, and watch as the murder rate continues to rise. In Europe, there might be little need for this film. But in America, it's an important movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
