		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore's film, "Bowling For Columbine", is the best documentary film I have seen in a long time. I also think that this film has paved the way for a new growing interest in this genre of movies. Would people have been interested in films such as "Capturing The Friedmans" or "Super Size Me" if this film hadn't been made? I doubt it.The film started with Moore's characteristic sarcastic humour. The pun on the President bombing yet another country "whose name we couldn't pronounce" was inspired. Interestingly, though, Moore did not attack the US government as much as you would think he would. In fact, unlike his follow up film, "Farenheit 9/11", he actually pretty much pushed it to one side to concentrate on the true subject of the film: gun culture.What was interesting was how Moore almost immediately confessed that he, along with many American boys, had a toy gun and even became a member of the NRA. It seems to me that his attitude to the whole gun culture topic was changed dramatically by the Columbine tragedy. Something that was looked upon that would have pushed this further was the later shooting of a six-year old girl by a boy in her class at their school in Moore's home town.This matter heralded the arrival of the film's first "bastard", as it were. Moore has this wonderful way of turning a wholesome, much-loved American celebrity and turning them into cold, unfeeling, selfish snobs. Dick Clark was the first victim of this. The "Bandstand" wonder man - who had been celebrated so much in housewives's favourite Barry Manilow's song "Bandstand Boogie" - had a welfare scheme that proved to be the reason behind the six-year old murderer's mother's economical difficulties. When confronted by Moore of this fact, Clark slammed the car door in his face and drove off. Yeah, nice move, Dickie. I doubt Manilow will write a sequel to the "Boogie" now.The person who was supposed to be considered the "bastard" - and was indeed by many of the authoritarian figures in the film - was Marilyn Manson. His music was criticised heavily after Columbine, as that was what the two boys listened to in their free time. Sure, blame music! Moore went to interview Manson, and what came out was an intelligent, well-spoken man who knew exactly what he was doing. His most valid point, other than the fact that it is all just a stage act when he performs, was that the President's actions on that day - the most severe day of bombing in Kosovo - were probably more influential than his songs. It is the same over here in the UK with the growing presence of garage music and gun crime here, though it is way lower than in the US of A.The last part of the film was probably the best. After his victory with two of the survivors of Columbine at K-Mart, where they forced them to agree to stop selling ammunition, Moore went to visit Charlton Heston, leader of the NRA. he proved to be the film's second and biggest "bastard". At first he was all for the interview, politely answering the questions Moore gave him as best as he could. It is certainly true that, in America at least, he had the freedom to have a loaded weapon in his house. But when Moore suggested he apologise to the towns of Columbine and Flint for holding NRA rallies in the same towns so soon after the shootings occurred, however unintentional they were, Heston just upped and left.Finally, I'd like to say that Moore's acceptance speech at the Oscars for the film, and the follow up, "Farenheit 9/11", was not really in my taste at all. His next film, "Sicko", is about the US health system. Maybe we will get back to the kind of Moore film that can be enjoyed INTERNATIONALLY as well as in the United States.In memory of Columbine and Dunblaine.</fullReview>

		<username>grendelkhan</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Outstanding, thought-provoking.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore's Academy Award winning documentary examines the reasons behind America's often violent society and gun-related crime rates. This has long been a hot-button topic, particularly in the gun-control/Second Amendment debate. Moore doesn't just stop with the availability of guns and America's violent past; he goes beyond into the psyche of the country and the culture of fear.Using the tragic shootings at the Columbine High School as a launching point, Moore depicts America's love affair with guns, from children's toys to adult assault weapons. Some of the footage is amazing, such as a bank which offers a free rifle with a cd account! Moore asks the obvious question about the sense of giving out guns at a bank. He also talks with many gun advocates, including militia members and highlights the everyday nature of it's members and their often bizarre viewpoint. He also shows the often tasteless by-products of the gun industry, including videos with scantily clad models firing assault rifles.Moore continues farther, examining the scapegoats cited by the media and politicians, such as violent video games, music, and movies. He points out that this same material is available in other countries, some in greater degrees, yet they have far less gun-related violence. Why? The answer Moore comes up with is the fear mongering of the media and politicians.The film documents multiple instances of fear inducing stories, from sensational murders to stories about killer bees and other "hidden terrors".These stories are sensationalized for quick effect, with little background investigation or expert input. The result is a perpetual climate of fear, causing the populace to react rashly. The Millennium fears provide a perfect example, as the film shows news footage of people stocking up and emergency supplies as a result of stories about potential disasters. These stories rarely pointed out that experts had been working on the problem for years and had started on major systems first; or that the world existed before computers and could sill operate without them In the end, nothing noteworthy happened.Moore compares this culture to that of nearby Canada. Canada has a similar ethnic mix, history, gun ownership, economic problems, and access to violent entertainment; yet, it has a much lower murder rate. Why? Well, as the film shows, its news media is not littered with sensationalistic stories which spread panic and fear. It also ensures that the basic needs of the population, such as health care, housing, and food, are met. Juxtapose that with America, where there is no national health care, and job programs center on menial minimum wage tasks, and racial fear is exploited.Moore also gives a voice to those who have been singled out as the source of violence, such as Marilyn Manson. Instead of a crazed psychopath, as he is often portrayed in the media, Manson is revealed to be an intelligent and insightful individual. At the same time, Moore gives NRA president Charleton Heston a chance to respond to some of the charges leveled at the NRA. Heston does try to give a reasonable, if not convincing rebuttal, but departs the interview when Moore makes a grandstand play. Moore does take a few cheap shots; but, so does the NRA and Heston has been a party to their grandstanding.In the end, we do see some positive change, after a couple of Columbine students accompany Moore to make a plea to the K-Mart Corporation to remove handgun ammunition from its stores. To their credit, representatives from K-Mart do listen to their requests and, later, act upon them. When Moore and the students present them with ammunition bought at one of their stores, the company makes an announcement that it is removing handgun ammunition from its stores.Moore's true aim seems to be highlighting the role of the media and government in perpetuating fear, rather than working to ensure that its citizens are safe and happy. This fear causes people to act rashly and seek protection through guns and violence, rather than analyzing the problem and finding a more positive solution. His theme is that its not the guns, but the reasons we feel we need guns that are at the heart of the problem.Michael Moore is a provocateur, but he always focuses on important issues. He stirs debate that hopefully leads to positive change. He isn't objective, but few documentarians or even journalists really are.</fullReview>
	</review>

He also places a huge amount of the blame on the government, suggesting that how can the government tell us to treat each other nicely if they are overthrowing governments and assasinating leaders. Even though I don't believe it all, it was a film that makes me think about these issues. Plus, this has some very funny moments, and nobody does satire like Moore. 		<date>2004-02-22</date>
		<username>Barky44 (barkybree@cox.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Many interesting viewpoints, but no conclusions</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Bowling for Columbine is Michael Moore's look into America's gun culture. At least that's what the promotional materials say. As a treatise on America's supposed worship of the gun, it falls flat. The movie puts forth a variety of interesting anecdotes (banks giving out rifles for opening new accounts); surprising truths (there are more guns per capita in the suburbs than in the inner cities); and disturbing attitudes (the NRA holding a rally within weeks of a grade-school shooting in Flint, Michigan).But the movie fails to link the anecdotes into a coherent, logical theory substantiating the idea that America has a gun problem. At one point, Moore argues that there are simply too many guns. But in another segment, he points out that Canada has roughly the same number of guns per capita with nowhere near the same level of gun violence as in the States. There are other examples where he goes in one direction and then provides evidence that this, too, is a dead end. This film is simply a collection of anecdotes &amp; Moore-badgering which, although entertaining, never comes to any conclusion regarding gun worship and gun violence. The one redeeming notion in the film is the look into America's culture of fear. Fear is used by politicians to maintain political power; used by bureaucrats to maintain control; used by corporations to increase sales and therefore profits; and used by media outlets to gain viewers and readers. This fear leads Americans to lock themselves away and arm themselves against the boogie man. This is where the film shines, but unfortunately even this is left hanging and not put into relation with any other idea presented in the film.I suppose documentaries are only supposed to show what's going on, and leaves the conclusions to the viewer. But it is still a form of storytelling, and as such requires coherence. Bowling for Columbine has many interesting facets but lacks the central core that would give that coherence.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-11-16</date>
		<username>Jacob Rosen (bix171@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Well-Worth Seeing But...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore should certainly be commended for confronting the extremely important American topic of gun control and he approaches his subject with enough gravity to empower his trademark literal humor. But Moore also approaches his subject with a chip on his shoulder and much of `Bowling For Columbine' is determined to aggressively portray a country alone in its wrong-headedness, as compared to the rest of the world; it's as if the current state of global affairs is America's fault--our bloodlust begins, Moore claims, with the Commander-In-Chief--while the violent tendencies in other countries have been quelled. Unfortunately, Moore makes his argument seem spurious by not offering to substantiate his facts (when listing the number of deaths by shooting per year in various countries--in order to show America's overwhelming leadership in this category--he fails to identify specific years) and his relentless stock-in-trade of ambushing his subjects seems self-serving and less a product of journalistic intent than the rant of a deeply unhappy attention-grabber. The ironic thing is that when Moore finally effects social change (K-mart decides to discontinue firearm sales after he and two Columbine victims protest to management) he seems genuinely non-plussed, as if being co-opted into giving up his contrarian attitude. (This forces him to go even harder at a deserving N.R.A. President Charlton Heston.) Moore is at his best when he exposes television news' exploitation of society's fears (the grab for viewers requires shock reporting) and he's extremely effective in pointing out that black males are consistently singled out as criminal scapegoats. But he carries his points to such an extreme measure (an animated segment paints a simplistically misanthropic history of the United States, filled with the alarming type of vitriol usually dished by the Far Right) that you find yourself deflecting the anger and hostility while trying to concentrate on the core arguments. Well-worth seeing but not without some apprehension.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>austin_earl</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Waste of time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoiler alert - if you plan to see this movie, don't read past the first paragraph. This documentary was a complete waste of time - Michael Moore presents one pertinent question in the film but he does an exquisitively poor job of exploring it - don't waste your time with this one.First of all, the central question of the documentary is "why are there so many more gun deaths in America than there are in Europe and Canada?" Moore presents some shocking statistics comparing the vast number of gun deaths in the U.S. with Europe and Canada's scant numbers. Moore then goes on to establish that Canada has the same number of guns laying around as the U.S., violent movies and video games abound there, ethnic diversity is similar, and the two countries are equal in seemingly every regard. Great, now we can get down to business! What factors are present in the U.S. that aren't present in Canada? If both countries have the same number of guns laying around waiting to be picked up, then the question should then become "why do people in America USE those guns to kill people more than people in Canada?"The documentary doesn't come close to answering this question, or even presenting any possible explanations. Instead, Moore decides to attack K-Mart, the store where the Columbine killers bought their bullets. He also focuses on Charlton Heston (NRA President) and Dick Clark (owner of a restaurant using "Welfare to Work" labor which caused the mother of a child who used a gun at school to be away from home).These confrontations don't tell us a thing about WHY people kill each other with guns in America. Moore, didn't you already establish that Canada and the U.S. have equivalent guns per household? If that's the case, then why does the NRA have anything to do with WHY people are killing each other MORE in America? Charlton Heston has nothing to do with it! Dick Clark has nothing to do with it! K-Mart has nothing to do with it! Sure, people might have access to bullets at K-Mart, just as they do at the local gun store, but that tells us nothing about the central question here - MOTIVE! What motivates people to shoot each other in this country, if it's not the guns themselves? People might treasure the fact that they have the right to bear arms (so they join the NRA), but what causes them to kill people with those guns?Moore starts to hint at this while talking about the media's tendency to put gun murders at the top of their list, and in the process he mentions that murders are actually declining while media coverage increases. An interesting follow up question - WHY are murders on the decline? Has something changed? Do people have more money in their pockets? Are there any social trends that we can point to? That question is not addressed. Moore focuses instead on the guns themselves, the presence of which he already established were not the CAUSE of the gun death differential, and he pays little to no attention to the essential question of what's actually happening in the minds of the people who use those guns to kill other people.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>perni</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The best movie I've seen in quite some time.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whether you're a major film buff or just an average joe watching the Oscars, there's no way you can't know who Michael Moore is and about his massively controversial documentary, Bowling For Columbine. Many have raved about both the director and the film, while others (namely Stupid White Men) have protested its claims about guns in America. With all of this hemming and hawing over one film, I knew that at some point I had to obtain a copy. Amazon.com wasn't very helpful at first, since the only VHS copies of the film cost upwards of $33, but eventually I struck gold and found one for a cheap twelve bucks. Let me tell ya, it was money very well spent. This is one of the best movies I've seen in quite a while, so wonderfully crafted that it strikes the perfect balance of humor, horror, and anger. The blanket theme of Bowling For Columbine is how America has become gripped with fear and armed itself with millions upon millions of guns. Mr. Moore attempts to convince viewers that because of the mass media, which obsesses over every single murder/scandal/threat that will improve ratings, U.S. citizens have turned into worrisome, gun-toting psychos who kill each other with guns more than any other nation on the planet. Some very troubling facts, stories, and statistics are presented here, like how while murders in America have decreased by 20%, media coverage of murders has gone up 600%. All of this research really strengthens Moore's argument, and by the end of the film I was totally convinced that our country has gone down the toilet. There are also many fascinating interviews with various celebrities and everyday citizens, such as the brother of the Oklahoma City Bomber, Charlton Heston, and Marilyn Manson. Sometimes the documentary literally shook me or made me cry, like in the timeline sequence where we are shown the many horrors America has suported throughout history (put to the oldies tune "What A Wonderful World," ironically), or when Columbine High School's security camera footage is shown in its entirety. Aside from those chilling moments there are also many hilarious scenes, like the animated cartoon that details the history of America. Filmed by the men behind the wonderful South Park series, this short segment is filled to the brim with laughs (that is, if you're not insanely conservative). After seeing this movie I have become a strong supporter of Michael Moore, and have picked up his two latest books, Stupid White Men and Dude, Where's My Country?. If you think that this "great" nation of ours needs some serious work, then I suggest you try and find a way to see Bowling For Columbine. It's a sharp, witty look at violence in America that will get you thinking, laughing, and crying all at the same time. 4/4 stars</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Watch it for the thought-provoking parts, ignore the preachy ones (MINOR spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MINOR spoilers!Moore makes some good points in this movie, and engages us by showing a side of America's gun-owning public whose beliefs about guns seem ridiculous to most people. Then, he does what many Americans did after the Columbine massacre: try to figure out who is to blame, why America has the highest murder rate with firearms of any developed country. At first, he eliminates sources: Violent movies and videogames (watched and played en masse around the world, especially in east Asia), violent history (Europe's whole history is wars and power struggles; most of Asia's is, too), and gun control (while gun control is prevalent in Europe and Australasia, what about Canada? They love to hunt! 7 million guns for 10 million people!).Then, he starts on the offensive: He reminds Americans that nearly everything we see on TV and in print is controlled by a few major media conglomorates, and his depiction of the fearmongering from the news organizations is so apt, it is, well, scary. Fear makes people consume, especially pouring money into security systems and firearms. So far so good. The excursion to Canada was funny and thought-provoking, but it starts to get preachy, and the preachiness escalates from that point forward. Instead of allowing viewers to come to their own conclusions by showing them captivating film, Moore shifts tactics, and tries to ram his point home with anecdotal evidence, blaming welfare-to-work (because one welfare-to-work child was left alone and committed a crime as a result, welfare-to-work is bad?), and the lack of state-administered health care in America (where does this fit in with guns?). It seems like he is pushing for a welfare state, and he believes that it will solve America's problem with violence, although he never states this opinion explicitly.Then, he goes from Moore the filmmaker to Moore the activist, with a publicity stunt to get K-Mart to stop selling ammo, and an interview with Charlton Heston. By the time the interview was over and Moore had left the picture of the little girl murdered by 6-year-old welfare-to-work boy, I wanted to grab my gun and shoot both of them. Well, seriously, I could not, because I am in China and NOBODY is allowed to own guns here. Even though Nanjing is a city of 5+ million people, most of them far poorer than any American, I still feel much safer walking the streets here than in the US. I think Moore is on to something with the media making Americans feel inadequate so that they will consume, but he overshadows the exposition of this sad truth by revealing himself as a preachy jerk and focusing on his own actions during the later part of the film. 7/10.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I viewed this last weekend with an open mind, not particularly caring for Moore's earlier work, and finding his Academy Award "speech" thoroughly repulsive. The bank that gave away guns, the sociopathic McVeigh relative . . . I could have easily watched 90 minutes of this kind of ironic cinema verite. But the film derails with the montage of "American crimes against the world" and never gets back on track. Moore throws everything against the wall and hopes that something sticks . . . the defense industry, the COPS show, Africanized bees (??), liberal revisionist history, welfare-to-work programs, you name it. There's no real thread here, it's all just knee-jerk reactionarism and finger-pointing. But the Kmart and Charlton Heston sequences really take the cake for misdirected heartstring-tugging. Leaving the picture of the slain kid at Heston's house while Moore walks away with head bowed literally made me want to puke. I think the best documentaries are those where the filmmaker has some kind of passive distance to the subject matter. I thoroughly hated this film.</fullReview>

		<username>Zac Goldstein</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Biased, but provocative</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After hearing about how great this film was for two solid months, I finally got around to seeing it. It has been my experience that the more hype something generates, the more worthless it usually is. This was not the case with Bowling for Columbine.... at least not entirely. Before watching Bowling, or any other Michael Moore movie for that matter, it is important to realize what you are setting yourself up for. While Moore is not the flat-out liar some have made him up to be, he does to a good job of distorting the facts and is VERY manipulative in his presentation. With that in mind, his films are generally of value for the questions they raise.... not for the "truths" they claim to reveal. The question raised in Bowling For Columbine is one of why America is so violent. Moore contrasts our country to our northern neighbor, Canada, and looks back into our history. Interviews are conducted with falsely labeled "promoters of violence", such as Matt Stone (South Park) and Marilyn Manson. He also examines the town of Littleton, Colorado (sight of the Columbine massacre) and draws some interesting conclusions. In my opinion, the film falters when Moore changes roles from that of an observer/inquirer to that of an active proponent. He pressures K-Mart into removing bullets from their store aisles and his unwelcome `interview' with Charlton Heston is little more than a denouncement of NRA activity.As a journalist, I find Michael Moore to be unethical and Bowling for Columbine lacking in integrity. As a film watcher and a student, however, its value cannot be denied. Whether you've heard good things about it or bad; see it and draw your own conclusions. You will be doing yourself a favor.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Moore doesn't have the answers... but should he?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have read many criticisms of this film, and they seem to boil down to two things: it is largely made up of lies or distortions of truth; and Moore fails to make any kind of solid point or answer any of the questions he raises. I cannot respond to the first claim, as I know the film certainly has some embellishments, though I am not aware of any blatant falsehoods. The second, however, is an interesting point to ponder...Is a documentary filmmaker required to answer questions? Surely if he did, he would be regarded as being "preachy". I believe that Moore's main aim in Bowling for Columbine is to get his audience asking those questions, and seeking their own answers. Why does the USA have such a high homicide rate? Is it the guns? Is it something else? I doubt Michael Moore knows the answer, but I believe it is a very important question.Moore isn't some kind of prophet - he just wants to make you think.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-07-19</date>
		<username>PlanecrazyIkarus</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the most intelligent documentaries ever</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched Bowling for Columbine, based on the perception that it was a half-documentary, hillariously funny blockbuster thing with an anti-gun message. That impression was based on the trailer.Instead, what I got to see was something fairly different. First of all, it seemed a genuine documentary which admittedly chooses the material on display carefully to make a point, so is not objective, but despite that it is genuine and truthful. And it isn't nearly as funny as I was made to hope. Instead, it manages to be clever, convincing and moving (although it does go a bit far to achieve that effect towards the end)This is a documentary, so I am wondering whether such a thing as "Spoilers" are possible or not. Let's just say the rest of this comment will deal with the documentary in more detail, giving away some of its points and features, so if you want to see it on a blank mind, you might not want to read on.The point of the documentary - against all expectations - has little to do with guns and gun control. Michael Moore is a lifetime member of the NRA, he happily points out that there's 7 million firearms in Canada, a population of 11 million families, with a dramatically smaller amount of violence plagueing that nation. So what is the point of the documentary?There are several points. While attacking big business (especially Lockheed Martin), schemes that eerily resemble forced labour for poor people (inluding, most mercilessly, single mothers), schools, politicians, nutjob extremists and others, those that come out worst out of this documentary are undoubtedly the media - specifically, the US media, for savagely going after that which gets good ratings - violence and mass hysteria - and thereby scaring the population into a stage where they no longer bother to think straight.Some of the points are very well-made, others are less convincing, but the overall documentary is a truly thought-provoking, interesting look at America today. Sadly, it is hard to laugh, because the entire thing is tragicomic, you are never sure whether you should laugh or cry at the situations displayed and documented here.There are moments when Moore aims for the laughs - the cute dog who shot his owner with a shotgun is more funny than tragic, and the most light-hearted bit of the documentary occurs when Moore pitches a show to replace "Cops" on American TV. But then we get to see people who seem to have lost all touch with reality, who tragically live in microcosms of fear and who prepare themselves for violence every day until it is they themselves (or their friends) who bring it about, not the rest of the world that they try to protect themselves against. We get to see people choking on their words, still affected by tragedies years after the fact, and we see snippets of real life footage that are gory and terrible.Towards the end, Moore aims for the dramatic, and while the visit to K-Mart headquarters appears to be a triumph, his escapade with Charlton Heston is little more than an attempt to find a villain in all the mess. While Moore points out faults left right and centre, he appears to need to give the villain a face - that American disease of identifying good and evil, of having someone to identify as enemy, has not left Moore unaffected, and so he picks the head of the NRA. In a way, it is a let-down after one of the most intelligent and moving documentaries ever.As last remark, I'd like to compare it with another American documentary that took the world by storm recently. The 9/11 documentary might have won prizes and popularity, but if you really get down to it, that documentary is nothing but a bubble of emotion, without point or thought, without statement or content. If you want to see something that bubbles with emotion, but doesn't forget to think, watch Bowling for Columbine. You might not agree with all of its points, but it is worth seeing anyway.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I got my first taste of Michael Moore's work on his TV show "The Awful Truth" which was hit-or-miss depending on the social injustice exposed in that episode. Fortunately this only happens when he tries to speak to Dick Clark who is just about to set off in his car for somewhere and is running late, and when interviewing Charlton Heston, where Moore was a bit tactless in confronting the ageing actor/NRA president.The basic message I got from the film was that the deeply embedded culture of fear present in the USA (reflected in its media) is responsible for the high rate of gun-related deaths (Canada having a similar amount of guns per person but far fewer deaths).I didn't really feel that this message was hammered home in the way that an episode of The Awful Truth's might have been but Bowling for Columbine is definately the most informing work of Moores I've seen yet. Politically I suspect I would agree with most of Michael's opinions - but there are several times when the arguments he presents just seem incomplete, or occaisionally plain don't make sense.For instance:He frequently makes the case that Americans are driven into a fearful state by the media, which exaggerates danger by harping on about crime and violence. This is very credible. For instance, I believe that in 2001 or 2002 there were actually fewer terrorist attacks worldwide than in any year since 1961 - but to watch the TV....He even presents a statistic that crime rates have actually _fallen._However.... doesn't this undermine one of the main premises of the documentary: that violence in America is out of control? I mean, you can't logically argue that the reason that America is consumed by violent crime is because people have been duped into believing that the crime rate is out of control when it's actually falling. Am I just confused here?There were a few other things that bothered me. Some of his scenes, with the shooting victims, with Heston, smacked of the same sort of emotional manipulation that he seemed to object to in the mainstream media.And please remember that this documentary is just another version of 'the facts'. How do we know how many doors he had to knock on in Toronto, to find three that were unlocked? Don't get me wrong; I enjoyed it; it raised some good arguments, but it's thinking was erratic and unsatisfactory in many respects. I have seen far more compelling documentaries than this.Still, it was thought-provoking, and that matters. Perhaps the best argued point was the way in which the media keeps the public in a state of alarm (regardless of what the crime rate really is).I'm giving it about 7 out of 10, but if I were a conservative I would no doubt have been harder on it.(For the record, I've been to the USA many times. 		<fullReview>As the documentary opens with the steady tempo of Battle Hymn of the Republic, I made a subconscious leap from "lightning of His terrible swift sword" to "thunder of the terrible swift bullets".Like many people, I'm sure, I am attracted to the documentary by Mr. Moore's gutsy statements at Oscar night. Each of the several subject matters touched on by BFC would take at least a books, and some a lifetime, to explore. The documentary is unquestionably successful in giving the audience a lot to think about, for a long time.BFC is well structured. I would try to see it in six acts, in roughly (but not exactly) the order they are presented.Act 1: Columbine Act 2: America the aggressor Act 3: White's fear of Black in the U.S. Act 4: Northern neighbour - Canada Act 5: Flint, and social problems Act 6: Crusades - Walmart and Heston One of the risks in presenting these subject matters is making sweeping generalizations. BFC does reasonably well in avoiding that. The documentary does take a view, and I have absolutely no problem with that as long as balanced material are presented. On this score, I don't have a problem with BFC either. As I said, it would take much more than a two-hour documentary to discuss these issues. What I'm going to do is just to make a few observations on things which I think are interesting.I'm glad to see the coverage given to Canada, and particularly Toronto, my home for over two decades. While it's only a small step, it's an improvement from the "moose-beaver-snow" mentality many Americans have when it comes to their northern neighbour.I like the statistics given about gun deaths in various countries although it would have been much better to have the figures as percentages of the population. However, the absolute figures here, while not ideal, do tell a story, as we see two or three digit numbers for all the other countries against the over 11 thousand in The States.Finally, I think the best "speech" in the entire documentary is by visually intimidating (to some) rock singer Manson. The viewpoints are expressed lucidly and logically, and certainly make a hell of a lot more sense than the "if you're not with us, you're against us" rubbish.</fullReview>

He listens to those who have a genuine point to make (note the excellent Marylin Manson interview) and he lets those with nothing to say make fools of themselves brilliantly.This is a film that does what many films rarely do nowdays, it educates and stimulates. 		<shortDescription>Theatrical applause.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoilers herein.It's a pretty interesting world, indeed, when a man is able to walk into a bank, open an account, and walk out with a free gun as a gift for joining. Situations like these may seem foreign to many of us, and Michael Moore is able to bring them to life in his breathtaking and ground breaking film Bowling for Columbine. Moore received high acclaim for the documentary, and it is rightfully deserved. Never have I sat through a film only to have the audience finish giving the absent director a hearty round of applause. A well deserved reaction indeed, for Moore's film is able to take us on a journey which is painstakingly real, and makes us all realize just how scary the world outside, and inside, our homes truly is. Moore's plethora of footage spans decades of interestingly related events on the use of violence in society, and the ghastly ignorance portrayed in those who use it. In between takes or Moore-shot footage and archive materials, the film captivatingly shows the intense battle of America's embrace with violence, guns, and fighting. Many interesting statistics, historical facts, and tidbits are given, but Moore is able to arrange them in a fashion which doesn't shove anti-gun tolerance down the viewer's throat. The most intriguing part of the film is that Moore states his opinion visibly without actually stating so. It's easily clear that he knows the hazards and hell of firearms in American schools and streets, but he cleverly presents the information to the audience and lets them decide their reaction on their own. He balances his views with counteracting points of gun-lovers, including NRA heartthrob Charlton Heston, and shows the fright of how they can coldly deny the problematic side of guns and, instead, sleep soundly with a loaded firearm under their pillow at night.Moore gives shocking footage here of the Columbine School Shooting, and takes two permanent wound victims to a K-Mart hot-shot and lets the bodily bullet holes do the talking. After the fact, the Kmart representative holds a brief press conference announcing the chain's discontinuation of firearm ammunition. Perhaps the fact that K-Mart won't sell ammo anymore will not stop shootings, or violence in general. But the movie as a whole, however, may make many people sit back and realize the true danger that could unknowingly occur within any of us. Moore tackles each little detail he can, on the never-ending search for truth on the subject of violence and why it exists. Not only does he interview an ex-producer of Cops, and suggests the importance of a could-be hit "Corporate Cops", but he goes so far as to interview shock rocker Marilyn Manson, the man blamed for much of the Columbine disaster. Moore asks Manson what he would have said to the murderers in hopes of deterring them from their actions. "Nothing," Manson stated. "I would have listened to them." I couldn't have said it better myself.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A nation of gun nuts or just nuts?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is an extremely effective, if not rambling film that asks the question `Are we (America) a nation of gun nuts, or are we just nuts?' Director Michael Moore uses the massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado as a jumping off point, then takes us on a journey that includes stops in Michigan, where it seems everyone owns a gun, a sit-in at K-Mart's corporate headquarters and an amusing side trip to Moore's idealized Canada. The movie is all over the place, and offers very few answers to the questions it raises, but I think it was Moore's strategy to present the facts and figures and get people thinking for themselves. Moore's everyman appearance is put to good use in the film's most effective scene. He talks his way into gun-nut Charlton Heston's Hollywood hills home for an interview, claiming to be a member of the NRA. Once inside he gradually warms Heston up before asking the hard questions about the consequences of living in a heavily armed society. Heston stiffens, ends the interview and walks away. Moore's camera follows him as he shuffles down a long hall. The Grand Wizard of the NRA is revealed for what he is, an old man, not the Moses of the gun movement. It's impressive footage that caps a film full of powerful images and ideas.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>What is the question; what is the answer</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What I found interesting about this film was that it considered the conservative explanations for violence (such as rock music) as well as the liberal explanations (poverty and the availability of guns) and came to the conclusion that none of these things can really account for the situation in America, given that other countries have music, poverty and guns, without the same results.Yet I'm not certain that the film's apparent thesis, that the American media's focus on fear and violence is that different from what is available in other countries. I sometimes follow the British news, and it also seems as if every murder, no matter where it happens in the country, winds up in the forefront.The film does show--rather convincingly, I believe--that people have become afraid, sometimes beyond the point of reason. The young student who was suspended for having nailclippers demonstrated how fear can overrule logic. I think it would have been an interesting point to explore: who benefits from a scared public? Obviously, papers and TV sell more, and weapons and security firms also do a brisker business. These things are mentioned, but briefly, as they are not the focus of the film.That is not to suggest that the question that the movie poses, considers, and does not really answer, is not an interesting one. It's something people should be thinking about: why is there so much violence in America (and is there, or is that just the perception left by the news?)? I just don't think it's the only question. To solve this problem, it's important to look at who benefits from a terrified public, and I suspect it isn't just K-Mart, who used to sell bullets, nor the TV station that probably has more viewers when it shows football games.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Who cares if it's not perfect?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yes, Michael Moore has an ego. Yes, he has an agenda (translation: a point of view that some people disagree with). Yes, he can be occasionally misleading or irritating.But, who cares? This guy is consistently provocative and supremely entertaining. I'd rather watch one of his movies than a dozen standard political documentaries.Bowling for Columbine asks a simple question: why do Americans kill each other with guns at ten times the rate (or more) than in any other developed nation? Of course, Moore himself doesn't expect to find a conclusive answer. His search, however, is fascinating.Who else would even try to tie together themes ranging from gun control, to sensationalism in the media, to health care, to US international political violence, to rock 'n' roll, to corporate malfeasance, and beyond? It's a hugely ambitious juggling act, and we shouldn't be shocked or disappointed if Moore drops a few balls here and there.For example: no, Canada is not the harmonious, happy-go-lucky heaven Moore portrays. However, we take many things for granted that Americans can't even imagine (like universal health care).No, it's not a perfect movie. But at a time when the US is once again spending billions of dollars overseas on bombs, and billions of dollars at home to expand tax breaks for the rich, we don't need Michael Moore to be perfect. We just need Michael to be Michael (even -- or especially -- at the Oscars!).</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>One of the most important films of recent years.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Shocking, direct, upsetting, emotional, exposing, frustrating, painfully funny and very, very important, Michael Moore's 'Bowling for Columbine' is one of the most absorbing films you are ever likely to see.Moore explores America's gun-culture in a quest to work out why US citizens are so intent on killing each other. He explores the part played by the national media and the government in creating a country where people are brought up to fear one another. He provides interesting comparisons with other countries, and is able to dismiss inaccurate explanations of America's disproportionate murder rate by using the example of Canada, where despite even higher gun ownership than the United States, experiences a much lower number of gun-related killings.Some of the footage is disturbing, including CCTV footage of the shootings at Columbine, which even the hardest of viewers will find painfully upsetting.Moore tracks the record of the US government over the past fifty years, namely the part played in foreign affairs. He paints a disturbing picture of corruption, hypocracy and brutality and includes a frightening connection between the US government and Osama Bin Laden. One could argue that his inclusion of the images of 9/11 were unnecessary, but this is open to interpretation.Bowling for Columbine is a classic satire, but is better seen as an emotional roller-coaster. A speech by a father of one of the boys killed at Columbine had me desperately upset, but Moore's sarcasm when interviewing an accused (but freed) conspirator of the Oklahoma bomber was squirm-in-your-seat funny.I beg you to go and see this film as it is important for many reasons. For Americans, it is a reminder that you are actually safer than you probably think. Moore brilliantly explores this point, concluding that both the TV Media and the government, are selling you fear. The Bush administration in particular, has justified such an enormous military budget by scaring US citizens into thinking that it is necessary. Moore will make you rethink the way you look at America as a gun culture and as a culture of fear. You may leave the movie theater a bit stressed or bewildered, and probably horrified by your government, but it's worth it. Your overwhelming feeling will be one of relief that you have seen it. I trust that you will feel, as I do, almost a duty to spread the word.Rating: 10/10</fullReview>

		<username>mmpmppm</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Never tries to be fair, but so what?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This message is a response to the posts below that accuse BFC as "propaganda" (quotation marks needed because the word itself is really neutral but most people use it derogatively as a given), unfair/biased, and/or even all lies.Personally, I loved the film. Nonetheless, I was glad to read about the ways in which Moore manipulates facts (generally, by telling only one side of an issue--an example being his failure to mention that Kayla's uncle ran a crackhouse). I don't think any less of the "documentary" if you insist to call it that; I only think differently of the issue(s) that BFC tries to address.First of all, it is unreasonable and pointless to demand an "objective" perspective from a documentary or any other representation of reality. Even if such a perspective really does exist (I think it doesn't), it or approximations of it exists in the intelligent viewer, not the film. Since the work is only two-hours long, there are bound to be facts and viewpoints omitted and ignored. No arrangement is ever innocent because there is, if nothing else, selection and prioritization. If Moore were to simulate reality as a cacophony of random opininons, BFC wouldn't even have the coherence to be watchable.Americans who accuse BFC as manipulative and "unfair" need to look no further than their own news media for a much more systematicexample(&lt;http://www.thenewamerican.com/focus/mcdonald/kal/kal2.htm&gt;). The American news media operate in a mode much more dangerous than the one BFC operates in because the former give the _illusion_ of fairness.Many of the posters I am addressing seem to be bothered by the category "Documentary", which traditionally has always been _supposed_ to be objective. Beyond the theoretical/philosophical impossibility of being "truly" objective, I suggest we not be stuck on a problem of categorization (just as the categories "fiction" and "non-fiction" are meaningful perhaps only to librarians and book-award contests). That BFC is in the Documentaries category in the Oscars means nothing more than just that.If BFC told you it tries to be fair (like mainstream US news media do), you could accuse it for its failure. But it is obvious from the start that Moore has a message to deliver, that he has a personal stance in making this film. The first scene with the ridiculous bank giving away guns is comical but immediately sets up the overall agenda. Whether the final scene with Heston is distasteful from an artistic standpoint, the message cannot be more explicit. Why would one demand objectivity from a film that evidently disregards it?The following is anecdotal and without reference, but I think reasonable and obvious. In a philosophy class my professor mentioned an experiment conducted on two groups of 15 or so people, one very pro-war (Iraq) and one very anti-. In a 3-day period, the 30 people were lectured on the historical, cultural, and political contexts and consequences of the war. Afterwards the researchers asked for their opinions again, and this time they became much more neutral.Whether you are convinced or not by the above, I urge try to think of BFC in a larger context (of films or media whatever), as _one_ opinion in a collective voice (along with the opposite opinions) dealing with the issues of guns and American violent culture that _taken as a whole_ will yield (an approximation of) objectivity and fairness.Just look at this forum for an immediate example. While the posts may be biased individually (some more than others), together they form a kind of social consensus that is much more valuable and desirable. Ultimately one text only says so much; "fairness" is in the critical and intelligent audience.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>America the beautiful??</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore has always been a blunt critic of the corrupt politics and socio-economic problems rampant in America, and this film shows more proof of it. This is a movie that everyone in the US needs to see right now, especially as Americans become more paranoid and fearful of the rest of the world. My brother, currently living in Europe, cited this film as the reason he's decided it's no longer a place he'd like to live and therefore left. Having just seen the film a few hours ago, I can clearly see his point. Bear in mind, this film can be quite bleak and grim in its outlook for the future. However, with Moore's tireless (and usually thankless) fight against ignorance and injustice, you will gain some insight on what exactly has lead to the current chaos around the world and in the US itself. The film was funny, but I also felt physically ill and angry after seeing it. Some of the film is very graphic and difficult to watch (i.e. dead bodies, people being shot). Do not let the disturbing nature of the film stop you from seeing it. It will open your eyes.WARNING! SPOILERS AHEAD!!This movie examines why crime and violence has risen so dramatically in the US since the nation's birth, in comparison to the rest of the world. The argument is that the root cause of the violence and increased crime IS guns. Specifically, the NRA's continued efforts to distort the 2nd Amendment to their agenda, thereby guaranteeing every citizen's right and access to bear arms in the US, has been a disaster for the country. The film also indicates that the US media needs to be revised and gun control is badly needed.Before anyone argues against gun control and points out Moore's apparent hypocrisy (he is a lifetime member of the NRA, as he freely admits at least 2 times in the course of the film), Moore brings up a number of relevant points. First of all, he's joined the NRA to gain access to areas that would otherwise be closed to him, such as being able to tape at NRA meetings and interviewing head honcho Charleton Heston himself. The interview with Heston, which occurs at the very end of the movie, is both revealing and disturbing. Heston clearly comes off as both uncaring of the innocent victims of gun violence (in the film's example, a 6 year old girl killed by another 6 year old) and worse, a racist of the worst caliber. Furthermore, Moore heads up to Canada to compare that country's low crime rates (despite its equally well-armed citizens) and how Canadians' can feel so secure (to the point that they leave the doors to their homes unlocked at all times). The film shows how the US media has focused on scaring the American public to the point that people are paranoid and distrustful of everyone else. The local and nationwide news focuses on violent crimes and thereby increases the public's fear and distrust. This is contrary to Canada, where the news is about social issues (health care, education...). The NRA further agitates the public by insisting that an armed society is the best defense against anarchy, yet ignores the very chaos and turmoil they've helped create.The film also points out that American society is no more violent than any other current society or past society. He uses the British Raj, Nazi Germany and World War II Japan as examples of societies that were much more misguided in their respective eras. The question lingers, why is the weapons-bearing American public so much more disturbed than the rest of the world? The question will haunt you long after the film's end.</fullReview>

		<username>Allan Houston</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant, dense and poignant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is perhaps one of the most pertinent and valuable films to reach our cinemas in the past few years. Especially now (or indeed because of what is happening now) the probing of Michael Moore into the American obsession with its right "to bear arms" (which was actually their right to bear arms against the british, but this latter piece of information seems to be ignored) raises a lot of significant questions and even answers a few, that the world, and the USA, should be asking itself.Bowling for collumbine is surprisingly rich with emotion and heart. It is at times relentlessly hilarious and at others chokingly horrifying. The highlights are the animated version of American history which attempts to find a reason for the readiness of the average American to reach for their gun, and the integration of video footage from various shootings, including the one at Collumbine, where America's liberties came back to bite them.An array of interesting and quite different people are interviewed, the best of which are the brother of one of the men responsible for the Oklahoma bombing (who comes off as a particularly stupid redneck), Charlton Heston (the president of the NRA - who Moore interviews at his home), and Marilyn Manson, who was blamed for promoting violence and hate through his music because the two boys at Collumbine had listened to his music. Of all those interviewed, it is Manson who perhaps comes off most level-headed and thoughtful. His insight into the "culture of fear and consumption" is enlightening.Overall this is a superbly structured documentary, and one which everyone should see. 10/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Bang, bang, the mighty fall.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I like Michael Moore. He makes highly interesting cinema about things that need to be talked about. In fact this film deserves a high ranking just for being made and distributed this widely. I'm amazed that permission was granted for some of the material in the film. I bet Charlton Heston hasn't got the poster for this film on his wall.This documentary is an interest-grabbing mission to find out what lies at the heart of the USA's love of all things gun shaped. Further, why does the USA have such a high rate of gun related fatalities compared to a lot of other countries. His search takes him through historical, racial, media, political and financial arguments. The focus is the tragedy at Columbine High School ("Home of the Rebels"). Why did those two kids do what they did? Why doesn't this happen in other countries? Ultimately no reason nor solution is offered. The closest Moore comes to attributing blame is on the culture of fear whipped up by the media in the States. Particularly he focuses on fear of the black community. In the case of Columbine he can offer no definite reason, preferring instead to say that you might as well suggest that they killed those children because they'd been bowling that morning.I think the weakness in this film is that it's very much preaching to converted. It's easy to see that Moore is often traditionally political (for instance his emphasis on the the welfare to work scheme in Michigan). Anyone who's got a built in left-wing detector is not going to buy much of what he says. Yes, a lot of people have seen this film but I bet that most of them will be receptive to his message before the trailers.It's also a shame that he doesn't offer any form of solution. It's important yet easy to criticize. It's vital yet hard to come up with solutions.The centrepiece is a short animation from the people who brought you South Park documenting in a really funny way, the culture of fear and armed response. It's a pity that a certain Mr. Bush isn't forced to watch this every morning.This film is a triumph both as film and as agitprop. I hope Michael Moore goes on to make loads more documentaries on a lot of other subjects. The world needs him.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-01-09</date>
		<username>ilovedolby</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent Satire!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Gun violence plagues the United States all too often these days. In the past five years, there have been several school shootings throughout the United States. And who could forget the most recent stint of extreme gun violence in our country but that of the Washington DC area snipers. Michael Moore, the director of such documentaries/ mockumentary films such as Roger &amp; Me, has chosen to make a film exploring why is it that America has such a love for guns, and why in America gun violence has exceeded that of most other countries in the world. It's a truly amazing satire of American society and gives a lot of good ideas as to why gun violence has become such a problem in the United States. As the film's title explains, Bowling For Columbine, generally focuses on what was the worst school shooting in U.S. history, at Columbine High School in Columbine, Colorado. (It's a shame that we have to refer to it as the WORST school shooting in U.S. history.) Moore explains that the boys who committed the crime went bowling at 6a.m. before school and then decided to do the shooting. Although the film takes a hilarious aim at explaining America's love for guns, it also takes a very dark turn in showing the video surveillance tapes from Columbine High School the day of the shooting. Moore concludes that America is so prone to violent acts with guns because of fear. However, fear of what? In a short animated skit in the film, Moore shows the history of America starting with the pilgrims coming over to the New World to escape prejudice in their homelands. When they arrive, they seem terrified of the Natives who already inhabit the lands and shoot them. The cartoon shows American's as frightened and constantly shaking in fear of anyone or anything that is different. And the only way they solve anything in by eliminating the problem by the barrel of a gun. It proved to be an extremely funny animated short film that is a pretty good, if not far-fetched explanation for America's love for guns. Moore also shows interviews with famous celebrities, and archival footage of political leaders throughout the years. As for celebrities, Moore interviews Marilyn Manson, whose lyrics have been blamed for violence among his younger listeners for several years now. He actually provides some good explanations for America's infatuation with violence and the news. After all, doesn't the media seem to sensationalize everything in the news. But another point that Moore tries to make in this film is that you can't blame entertainment for violence in society. It's just entertainment. Everyone has fantasies and desires that border on mental breakdowns. Who doesn't want to be that hero who saves the day? And the classic symbol of that hero is that of the man with a gun. Entertainment simply shows what the people want, in film and music. If people are blaming the entertainment industry for promoting violence, and anything else for that matter, then why don't they blame the Bible? After all, the Bible has specific references of violence. Oh sure, it's to set an example of morality. But guess what, so sometimes do film and music. It's just a form of art and entertainment, not to be taken into reality. One point that Marilyn Manson makes in this film is that perhaps people should've tried to listen to the boys of Columbine High School who committed the act, rather than having teased or manipulated them, as did occur. Clearly the boys had serious issues to deal with, or they were mentally unbalanced. The best parts of this movie occurred towards the end. Moore does an interview Moses himself, Charlton Heston. After all, wouldn't it make sense to interview the president of the NRA about what his thoughts as to why gun violence occurs so much in the U.S? And why not find out why Heston chose to have NRA rallies in the cities affected by school shootings as soon as ten days after the shootings. Heston didn't feel that it was the least bit insensitive, even after such appalling events had taken place. Also, it's necessary to point out that during the interview Heston couldn't even explain why violence has plagued the U.S. He tried giving some vague explanation at one point, in which he concludes that gun violence is so high in the U.S. because of so many different ethnic groups living together. But it was recently disclosed that Heston suffers from Alzheimer's disease, although he is in the early stages of the disease. I wonder if perhaps he was being affected during the filming of this documentary. Honestly folks, he's admirable as an actor, but in reality he seems like a very shallow person. And wasn't this the guy in the original Planet Of The Apes who was slamming his fists in the sand on the beach looking at the destroyed Statue Of Liberty while yelling, `You maniacs! You blew it up. Damn you. Damn you all to hell!' I guess we can conclude that Heston is for guns, but against nukes. In conclusion, Bowling For Columbine is definitely one of the year's best films. Certainly worthy of viewing, and plan on laughing because there are moments in this film that are hilarious in it's explanation of America's love for guns. But as I stated above, there are also a few moments that seem disturbing to watch. It's important to point out that this film is really not totally against guns. It's not trying to challenge the second amendment, which reads: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed. But it is important to point out that what existed in the late 1700's does not exist today in the U.S. It was a time where the average American hunted for food, and guns were necessary for protection because it was a time of our countries revolution. But in 2003, I don't think it's necessary, at least in some areas of the U.S. for the average person to have an automatic weapon or weapons used in combat situations. Moore has done a superb job in directing this film. ***</fullReview>

I can only assume he is therefore linking this in some way with the shootings at Columbine and the violence in American society in general? But he then goes on to apparently reject this view during his interview with Charlton Heston where he tells us that other countries such as England and Germany have committed similar atrocities in their past but yet suffer from violent crime to a far lesser degree than the US. So is there a link between a nations foreign policy and the level of violent crime suffered and perpetrated by its citizens or not Mr. Moore?Furthermore, having apparently concluded (through his observations on Canada) that the number of guns available in the US is not the main source of the outrageously high number of shooting fatalities in the US, then why is the NRA and in particular its president, Mr. Heston subsequently demonised in the climax of the film? Heston and the NRA are undoubtedly guilty of gross insensitivity but does he personally deserve to be put forward in this film as public enemy number one? I also found the request for an apology for the death of a 6 year old girl from Mr. Heston a tad melodramatic on Michael Moore's part (though the apology may have been for the insensitivity shown in holding a gun rally so soon after this childs death, in which case I am mistaken).Despite these criticisms (and others unmentioned), I'd like to congratulate Moore on the making of an entertaining and thought-provoking documentary whose most valuable asset is that it will undoubtedly promote debate on the serious topic of violence in today's society ...</fullReview>

The fact that he never specifically states this, I feel, is the quintessential, meaningful true moral of the story. He can't really say it or would they really let him release this movie nationwide? That's what I was left wondering.Kudos to Charlton Heston for actually granting Moore the interview (Would you expect anything different from Ben Hur?), but he could not handle the difficult questions regarding his inability to perceive how families traumatized by violence might just feel a little more victimized by his crass appearance at NRA rallies in those areas right after the senseless violence.Dick Clark's complete impassivity towards the suffering of the single mother who worked at his enterestaurant is appalling and noone who has a conscience should ever eat at the Dick Clark's Bandstand, watch his New Year's Eve krap show or allow him to invade their homes through their television for any reason ever. He's a piece of s*%@ and cares first, last and always about making a buck and nothing less. Simply put, he's a part of the problem.</fullReview>

		<username>richard winters (rwint)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Stunning</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If one is a fan of Michael Moore's work than one might be a little surprised with this one. Moore is of course best known for such movies as ROGER &amp; ME, THE BIG ONE, and his TV-series THE AWFUL TRUTH. These were highlighted with complete irreverence and off the wall humor. Although there is still some of that here, it also becomes much more serious and dare I say powerful. This is probably what makes this documentary a standout and what may propel Moore from simple cult hero to a serious even important filmmaker. The film is a basic essay on guns and violence and how our society seems so much more violent prone than others. A critic may say this whole thing is simply liberal propaganda. Certainly Moore has a agenda and some of the information is selective. Yet the points they do raise are quite valid. Moore seems willing to explore the ugly complexities behind the issues without having to dress anything up. He gives you the stats, gives you the theories, backs up the theories, and even takes some good shots at such giants as the media and big time corporations. In a way his style of clothes is similar to the presentation. He's a blue jeans and T-shirt guy. He practically always has a scruffy old baseball cap on. The caps may change, but they are always scruffy and old. No matter where he goes or what type of 'important' person he meets, he is always dressed this way. His directing style is the same type of way. It's eclectic, but never flamboyant. It doesn't try to align itself with anything, nor does it talk down to you or preach. Instead he just tells it to you the way he sees it. By doing it this way he gets you to consider he's viewpoint without making you resent it.  The film also grabs you emotionally without having to push it. The frantic 911 recording by a school principal when a 6 year girl is shot by another child seems far more gripping and tragic here, with it all played out instead of having it just a 10 second sound bite on a news program. The grainy black and white images of the Columbine students hiding underneath tables at the schools library is truly chilling. Especially when the images of the attackers comes in and they all go running. This just seems very real and startling no matter how many horror movies or other violent scenes you may have seen. It may be to early to call this a classic, but it certainly does weave you through all the human emotions. Like every great documentary, it also has those completely unrehearsed, unexpected gems. One includes a talk with James Nichols, brother of accused Oklahoma City bomber accomplice Terry Nichols. The interview is already highly lucid throughout, but his final comment is just unbelievable. It also has a shot ( no pun intended) of Charlton Heston speaking to a group of National Rifle Association members, while surrounded by a pair of bullet proof shields. Chris Rock's routine on the "$5,000 bullets" is funny and way too short.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A compelling observation of a psychotic country</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It is somewhat bemusing to see this movie portrayed as a comedy. True, there are humorous moments - but the humour is poignant, satirical and invariably derisive of America, specifically its capacity for self destruction and its fixation on violence. This is a movie every American should be compelled to watch, in the vain hope that as a society it will garner the communal courage necessary to rid themselves of the evil of weaponry, in the same way that England and Australia have responded to acts of evil committed by firearms - declare them illegal and remove them from their owners. But what Michael Moore clearly exposes, is that while real estate agents declare the failure to carry lethal firearms "unpatriotic" and misguided, pathetic actors become poster boys for racist gun glorifiers, such an eventuality is unforseeable. Can a whole culture be diagnosed as psychotic? Moore's evidence is compelling. Drawing a correlation between its global propensity to extreme violence, and its citizens' similar tendencies towards each other, his hypothesis would seem to be that US society suffers a serious and unique psychological malfunction. It is tragic that a country filled with kind, generous and caring people can collectively become a deranged and dangerous nation. The contrast is captured brilliantly in this movie - the chilling footage from the Columbine massacre on one hand, and the response from KMart to two victims of that horror on the other. As a citizen of a country America would regard as a close friend, I would hope that such a movie would have a significant social impact. Experience suggests that Terminator 3 has a better chance.</fullReview>

It raises many questions and encourages the viewer to rethink their views on guns and what causes people to shoot others.The film focuses on many different people including John Nichols (brother of Terry Nichols who blew up the federal building in Oklahoma City), rock star Marylin Manson, South Park creator Matt Stone, Chris Rock and NRA spokesman and famous actor Charlton Heston. Each person has his/her own take on the rights of people to have guns, why people shoot each other and how to stop violence. The movie goes beyond the quick and easy solutions the news media likes to give to this problem such as video games, rock music and violent movies. This is one of the best films I have seen in a long time and maybe the best film I have ever seen. It is really entertaining and takes on a very important topic. Everyone high school age and up should see this film.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A truly great film - and so what if it's subjective?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Plenty of people have praised this film already, and I can only add a "me too" in that I think this film is brilliant and should be shown to schoolchildren in America - of course it won't be, for all sorts of reasons. This film covered a LOT of ground. Its use of footage of the Columbine massacre was heartstopping and entirely justified; the footage of Charlton Heston intoning the words "from my cold dead hand" while brandishing a rifle was sickening and chilling, and I have no sympathy for him. Some people think he was stitched up by Moore, and/or that as he has Alzhemier's Disease he should be left alone. Well, if he'd stop holding gun rallies in places that have just witnessed carnage such as as Columbine, maybe there'd be a valid point there. Besides, he seems up for the interview and not obviously doolally. I don't suppose he will feel that he's lost out much from the film.The film is also extremely funny at times, prompting guffaws of disbelief in the audience at the cinema in London where I saw it - which also contained a lot of Americans, incidentally. My favourite bits are the incomprehension at Moore's question about Gandhi's peaceful methods; "thank you for not shooting me"; and the animated history of America.One point I'd like to add (and it may have been made earlier) is that documentaries do not have to be neutral. The charge of "bias" is meaningless here: this is clearly a polemic, and Michael Moore is perfectly within his rights to edit and shape the film any way he wants to, so that it best supports the thrust of his arguments. The interview with the former acquaintance of Timothy McVeigh was truly chilling, although I don't think any tricksy editing was required to achieve that effect - the man is clearly barking!I think Moore puts a most persuasive case as to what is behind the gun-fuelled malaise in the USA: poverty (exacerbated by politicians) and fear (stoked by the media) make for a pretty combustible combination.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Undeniably eye-opening...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Watching this one in the UK, but recently having visited the US, this was a thought-provoking study of what makes the US so notoriously fiream-reliant.A different experience to what I'm used to seeing in the cinema, this was the *reason* I wanted to see this. Something which wasn't afraid to go without a plot.It is, of course, a documentary, pure and simple, masterminded by the irrepressible Michael Moore, a man who's managed to show up so many political and social institutions in various ways, to the extent of convincing so many of his viewers that a ficus plant would actually do as good a job in congress/senate as a politician. And who would argue with him...In terms of this, he's gone for the jugular - this is obviously a man who is fiercely patriotic, to the extent he's made a career of attempting to right the wrongs - a one man morale crusader, if you like. And he's really done quite a good job with Bowling. I don't wish to 'spoil the story', so to speak, but it becomes clear that he's come very close to identifying the problems which face the US - pretty much all of which, it has to be said, are of their own doing.He doesn't oversensationalise at all, he seems to tell it like it is - common sensically.There are many moments where testimonials from interviewees make those interviewees look insane, and indeed, one might say that's the idea - to exploit these people into looking deranged, and clearly the problem. But the truth is they bring it on themselves, with a touch of editing, perhaps, but it's clear the influences on the American society which the movie explores have quite blatantly affected these people to an extent you don't see elsewhere in the world.Without giving any more away, I suggest you view this for yourself. It's a fine piece of current affairs, with the occasional hint of intended dark humour.</fullReview>
