	<review>
		<date>2002-12-08</date>
		<username>kcrawford</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An excellent start, but hardly a conclusion</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was impressed by Bowling For Columbine, and particularly impressed by Michael Moore's trademark doggedness in pursuit of answers. The impressive rate of gun violence in America is almost impossible to understand, and thankfully Moore decided to treat it that way -- not as a problem of gun ownership, or history, or violence in all forms of entertainment. As he astutely points out, all of those things exist in other countries that still manage to log annual gun-related deaths in the double digits. Over 11,000 people on average are shot to death every year in this country, and nobody really understands why.Now, it would be impossible to expect Moore to actually answer that question in three hours or less -- and he doesn't. He makes some interesting points about culture-wide fear (leading Americans to regard everything from plane travel to bean-stuffed teddy bears with anxiety), and manages to get a very unilluminating interview with Charlton Heston, but in the end the movie left me disappointed. Not because I had expected an answer, but because Moore failed to maintain a consistent inquiry into the issues. One of the most glaring problems came in a segment in which Moore helps (or encourages?) two Columbine victims to take a stand against K-Mart, where the two Columbine shooters purchased their ammunition. Moore, an NRA member himself, has just spent at least 20 minutes discovering that rates of gun ownership (which usually means owning ammunition as well) really have nothing to do with the propensity for violence. He tells us that there are 7 million guns owned in Canada, where the rate of gun-related deaths is miniscule in comparison with our own. So, we've abandoned the hypothesis that legal ownership (hence, legal sales) is the problem. But now we take a moral stand against K-Mart? Yes, it's frightening (and hilarious) to watch the 16-year old K-Mart clerks drop live ammunition, but what point does it serve? If anything, it undercuts the complexity of Moore's exploration, reverting to a simple and overused explanation that simply hasn't proved either effective or true.The other truly grand-scale problem with the film was Moore's inability to overtly discuss important issues that he raised tangentially. Again comparing Canada to the United States, he briefly interviews Canadians regarding universal health care, the (non)existence of Canadian slums, poverty, and rampant unemployment. What he does not come out and do at any point is discuss the political structure that guarantees health insurance, safe neighborhoods, and welfare checks to Canadians -- socialism. The flip side of this problem is that he fails to properly address the socio-economic issues of the U.S. -- issues that are clearly relevant to our culture of violence. Moore shrugs off the issue of inner-city violence as little more than a myth, attributing the idea to white fear of black people. I am not convinced. From what I see in the news, African-Americans are involved in American violence -- in large part because of the untenable situation in which they live. How can you expect people to get well-paying jobs and own comfortable homes when they can't get a good education because the homes they own are in lousy neighborhoods with no property value to fund the schools? It's ridiculous, and without blaming the entire murder rate on the black community (yet another highly unfair general assumption), Moore does have to do something other than deny that a problem exists. His concentration is in the (mostly white) suburbs of America, where gun violence has certainly become a problem (if a much smaller problem than the media coverage would have us believe). Here is the crux of the movie's problem: 11,000+ people die every year in this country because of guns. Less than 1% of those deaths involved suburban school shootings. Moore has a great question with a slightly skewed focus. With a slightly broader scope, he could have had a great film on his hands.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>A synthesis of what's wrong with America</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before posting this message, I read through a lot of the comments for both this movie and "Roger &amp; Me." Moore's critics are generally of two stripes: 1) those who accuse him of distorting the facts and 2) people who call him "too liberal" and accuse anyone who dares like his movies of being too liberal as well.What I think people are missing, however, is that Moore, liberal though he may be, isn't telling his audiences what to think. He's presenting a picture of the United States that, though most people don't like to look at, is what many people see, particularly people who live outside of this country (at least people I've met and relatives of mine from outside the States).I don't think this movie is a "Guns are Bad" movie. What this movie is really about is the "culture of fear" that Moore talks about in the movie, of which a "culture of stupidity" is closely related. The genius of Michael Moore is that he never walks onscreen and says, "OK, this is what I want you to believe." The juxtaposition between the U.S. media (Killer Bees! Y2K!) and the Canadian media (Potholes) is humorous but telling at the same time.Even before 9/11, the masses in this country were already preconditioned to panic. His point isn't that "guns are bad." His point is that we don't have a society that's mature or evolved enough to handle guns properly. Is some form of Canadian socialism the answer? I personally don't think so (as a conservative myself), but giving corporations tax breaks and sh***ing on the poor isn't a solution either (or truly conservative).It's hard to summarize my feelings on this film. I don't agree with everything Moore says, and I do agree with people who say that you shouldn't take everything Moore says and gobble it down with a big fat spoon. But Moore would probably tell you the same thing, and I think that's the point of his work. His clip of Bush talking about the "general alert" was also dead on; there are too many people today unwilling to think about anything that's happening in our world. If his "liberal views" bother you that much, I feel sorry for you, because he represents such a small portion of the population that isn't threatening to the mainstream views in any way.See this movie. It will make you think, even if you don't agree with everything he says. I don't (I thought his Canada/U.S. analogy was off), but still enjoyed it tremendously. 9/10 rating.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-12-05</date>
		<username>Nick Lambert (nicklambert@fcuk-me.co.uk)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A brilliant examination of the mentality of modern America</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ok, so I'm British, and I don't really know what America is like. But if 1% of your population are as crazy as some of the guys here, I may just cancel that trip to New York.Michael Moore is one of the best left wing writers around at the moment. His most recent book 'Stupid White Men' is an examination of the 2000 presidential election and the general state of the US at the moment. It is both hysterically funny and utterly thought provoking. Much in the same way, 'Bowling for Columbine' is superficially a documentary about the constitutional right to bear arms, but Moore also manages to work in some more general material about US history.This being made by Michael Moore, it is no dull, passive or detached documentary. On the contrary, it is both funny and moving, and Michael Moore wears his colours so boldly so as to completely reinvent the concept of a documentary as being unbiased.There are several stand out passages. The film opens with Moore going to a bank which is claiming to give away free rifles every time a new account is opened. This gives Moore the films best line : 'Do you think it's a good idea to be handing out guns in a bank?'. There is the shocking montage of gun violence, showing, for example, a man blowing his brains out in slow motion. Shocking too is Moore's history of US foreign policy since WW2, an account of all the dirty interventions made overseas in the interest of 'national security', culminating in footage of the first plane hitting the WTC. Sensationalist perhaps, but effective. The animated history of the US is one of the funniest cartoons you will EVER see, showing the genesis of the US as being a bunch of paranoid, fundamentalist bigots, and outlining the reasons for class disparity in the US today.Moore travels the length of the country to try and find reasons for the national obsession with guns, going to Columbine (from which we see harrowing CCTV footage of the massacre there) and Flint, Moore's hometown, where a 5 year old boy shot dead a classmate. He also travels to Canada to see why there is no gun problem, and comes up with illuminating answers about their strong welfare state.But the piece de resistance comes in the form of an interview with arch enemy Charlton Heston, president of the NRA. Moore quizzes the frail man at length a to why he made visits to Columbine and Flint in the wake of the tragedies there, prompting Heston to walk out. In a final move that borders on being sanctimonious, Moore leaves a photo of the dead little girl in Heston's palatial home.Yet this is a minor qualm. No other documentary maker is as brave as Moore is, and anybody with even a passing interest in politics or current affairs should see this; you will find the film a powerful and enlightening experience.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The Greatest Film most people will never see.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Michael Moore bowls a strike with his latest documentary about gun-violence and the culture of fear and paranoia which grip the United States and it's citizenry everyday.Already becoming the highest-grossing documentary in history, a feat it accomplished in 4 weeks, it has now also added a National Review Board award for best documentary to go with the only Unanimous Jury award handed out at the Cannes' Film Festival in 55 years.Finding the film near you unfortunately is easier said than done since it is only playing in roughly 220 theaters throughout North America. In addition to the fact it has received very little attention from the major media outlets. Possibly, due to the fact he uses the film to point out their nature of reporting violent crimes more often even when crime was on a downturn.The movie has some off points including Moore's tendency to jump off topic at times. This film does not deal with the gun control or guns solely, but focuses on the more important issue at hand why do we use guns the way we do? and Why do we as Americans have so much fear of our fellow citizens?Moore never explains why he just points us in several directions he feels are noteworthy and could lead us to an answer. Overall, I give this film a 9/10</fullReview>

Whether you agree or disagree with Moore's questions, at least this film asks a vitally-important question. In times like these, we need more thought-provoking movies such as this. I do not always agree with Moore, but I was moved by the courageousness of this film.One of the great non-fiction films of all-time and easily one of the top three movies of 2002. 9.5/10.</fullReview>

Having said all that, Canada can easily play the role of 'straight man' for the true 'punchline' in any movie, any time, if it is for a worthwhile cause. 		<date>2002-11-10</date>
		<username>MICHAEL O'FARRELL (mpofarrell)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Gun Crazy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Documentaries offer an immediate response from viewers very different from scripted fictional films with actors. Because they purport to show the "truth" , documentary films offer a "you are there" feeling that is palpable. But just as fiction films are molded and shaped by their creators , so-called "real-life" movies are also a product of sleight of hand. The director , screenwriter , editor , cinematographer and music composer of a documentary can just as craftily manipulate audiences around their cinematic fingers as easily as any story film makers can. This is not to say that there aren't any documentaries out there with an honest point of view ; many fine, even great "non-fiction" films exist. It's just that the nature of the beast in nearly every case precludes a totally objective point of view.This is certainly true of Michael Moore's riveting and often disturbing new work, BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE. A relentless examination of America's fascination with guns and their connection to the alarming escalation of violence and death that plagues this country, Moore takes the viewer on a frightening tour to the heart of middle America's homes, schools, survivalist groups and discount retail stores. The picture that Moore persuasively paints is one of a country consumed with fear which is exacerbated by the constant barrage of television news that endlessly offer up alarming reports of domestic , street and blue collar crime. The Media is an easy target for Mr. Moore to skewer, and one of the most damning displays of television's shallowness is the scene where an on-location reporter changes moods between takes for a news story of a child's murder in a local school. On-the -air the young man is grimly serious ; when the tape stops rolling he seems to lose his temper at a co-worker , then jokes about his windblown hair which is in bad need of mousse. Hairstyling becomes the off-air topic , a sharp contrast to the event being reported.Director Moore makes much of the fact that the United States has the highest civilian casualty rate of deaths by firearms than any other country in the world. To expediently prove his point, he heads to Windsor , Ontario and other Canadian towns and cities and interviews everyone from the average man on the street to local police chiefs , asking why Canada's death- by -gun rate is so low in a country where guns are easily purchased and seemingly everywhere. The average Canadian interviewed by Moore seems mystified by the American attitude that one's family must be protected at all costs , when almost all Canadians keep their house doors unlocked! There are many hilarious moments in Moore's film. Some unfortunate individuals unwittingly become the butt of the joke when explaining their philosophy of life. A Michigan Survivalist group is mercilessly put under Moore's microscope, and the more questions asked, the more bizarre the answers.The most chilling moment of the film, aside from a fleeting home video shot of the planes smashing into the world Trade Center , is the video monitor tapes re-playing the actual black and white footage of the killing spree inside Columbine High School.Interviews with Littleton residents become surprisingly gut-wrenching when a person suddenly becomes too choked up to talk. Moore, thick -skinned and aggressive in his tactics when questioning proponents of gun use, shows a soft, compassionate side to people who have witnessed a school killing.As with ROGER AND ME , his 1989 film which dealt with his quest to meet the CEO of General Motors and confront the man on his decision to lay off 30,000 workers, Moore saves his best for last.But that last scene may leave many viewers with conflicting feelings. Earlier in the film news footage is shown of actor Charlton Heston , President of The NRA, speaking at rallies near locations where gun deaths have just recently taken place.Director Moore decides to make the trip to Beverly Hills for a confrontation with the famous Academy Award winner at his home.When Moore arrives at the fortress-like gates and talks into the speaker phone, Mr. Heston answers. Moore tells the actor that he is a card carrying member of the NRA (true) , that he's a director making a film and would like to speak with Heston on the "gun control " issue. Heston responds by saying he has guests but tells Moore to show up the next morning when he will have " a little time" to talk with him. That interview in Heston's home the next day is intended to be the film's big pay-off ; it's obvious that Moore's intention is to nail Heston. There is something very disturbing about this scene. Moore's painstaking efforts to make a point backfire here. Although Heston's beliefs may be reprehensible to many, the fact that the actor graciously invited Moore into his home and was so rudely treated in return is simply bad manners.All in all, this is an important film. Just be aware that not all the blanket statements made by Moore are necessarily accurate. For the most part one can't help but admire the man's tenacity. The fact that he got K MART to completely relinquish their stock of firearms and bullets in the presence of two surviving victims of the Columbine shootings is proof that good things can happen.</fullReview>
	</review>

I'm not sure it was indispensable, no matter how much I like him and what he does. Still, GO SEE IT, it's great.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-10-19</date>
		<username>Marley</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Stunning and Shocking, Deeply Necessary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've seen many great movies, but Bowling for Columbine may be the first film I can honestly say I think everyone should see. To some members of any given audience, it will likely be life-changing.Moore takes on a difficult and controversial subject: America's love affair with the gun. He not only discusses (and shows with footage that would leave anyone shaken) tragic school shootings like the ones at Columbine High School, he examines why America is so unique in its shockingly high number of gun murders (over 11,000 per year). The reason he uncovers -- that it's not video games, TV, music, the breakdown of the family, poverty, unemployment, or even gun prevalence -- is ingenious and spot-on.Though the focus also includes other subjects, like America's history of violence with the rest of the world and the world's perception of Americans, the movie never feels like a sociology paper. Moore's humor is as provocative as ever, if not more than ever, and much of it is damn funny. Even some of the parts that are downright disturbing get laughs. For example, John Nichols (the brother of Terry Nichols and longtime friend of Timothy McVeigh) -- a man who was involved in the Oklahoma City bomb plot -- is funny even as he frightens us with his views on why guns are necessary; he sleeps with a loaded .44 Magnum under his pillow.The insights the film provides into the history of the NRA (of which Moore is a longtime member) are also eerie and enlightening. Quite noteworthy is Charlton Heston's explanation of why America suffers from so much more gun violence than Britain or Australia or Canada. The answer is simply too good for me to spoil here.See this movie. You'll laugh and quite likely cry as well (and you may feel the urge to vomit at times), but you'll go home far more educated and aware of the realities of one of the great social problems in American history.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Definitely no gutter balls here. (**a couple of spoilers**)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is the BEST movie I've seen so far this year. This is the first Michael Moore film I've watched and I was pleasantly surprised at how funny, sad, powerful, quirky and insightful both he AND his film are. It's primarily a documentary about guns in America but it's really about so much more than that. The film's recurring question is: Why does America have more gun-related deaths than any other country? There's a staggering moment in the movie where it compares the number of gun-related deaths in other countries with those of America: Canada has like 99 a year, France 150 a year, England 196 a year; but America has 11,120 a year! And Moore spends the movie trying to understand why. The film's closest answer is that America, more than any other country, has always been paranoid and afraid. There's an amusing but disturbingly accurate cartoon midway through the movie that depicts the evolution of America from the time of the Pilgrims to the present and how fear is the main underlying factor responsible for the violence and wars that shape America's legacy.Two major surprises in the film are Michael Moore's interviews with Marilyn Manson and Charlton Heston. In spite of Marilyn Manson's blatant weirdness, you have to admit that the guy had some valid, sensible things to say about the Columbine incident. And concerning Charlton Heston, I never thought he could be so chilling and misled (after all, this is Moses!).Regarding some comments here lambasting Michael Moore for his unorthodox approach to documentary-filmmaking: I think that this is his strength. He's an American original who's not content to just point his camera and roll film. In a world where you see more talk than action, it's touching and commendable to see Moore take a pro-active approach at the end of the film and get Kmart to stop selling bullets and firearms. Moore is like that naughty-eyed, restless kid in class who managed to get the teacher to hold class outside one particular afternoon or to not give homework over the weekend one Friday; your parents tell you he's no good and even the teacher doesn't like him, but you harbor a secret admiration for him: because he says the things you want to say but don't quite know how, and he does the things which you wish you could do but don't quite have the guts to.Put another way: Michael Moore is Robin Hood with a pot belly; maybe even Alexander the Great in jeans.</fullReview>

		<username>wwaters</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Powerful, provocative, original film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Using his trademark mix of satire and provocative ideas, Michael Moore takes us along on his journey to understand America's shockingly high gun-induced death rate. His use of hand-held footage of everyday people in America interacting with guns and discussing violence is not only hilarious at times(and sad simultaneously), such as the bank that gives away guns, but cleverly demonstrates that for too many Americans, guns and shooting is as American as apple pie.Moore is able to mix the genuine tears of victims -- including survivors of the Columbine massacre and the Flint MI teacher who had one six year old student shoot another in her class -- with a satirical look at the roots of this violence in American culture and history. Juxtaposed, these stories demonstrate a culture out of control. His comparisons with Canada, which has a similar per capita gun ownership rate but a much lower gun-involved homicide rate, brilliantly supports his emerging thesis that fear is at the root of the American shooting spree.The most memorable and fascinating moment of the film is Moore's interview with heavy-metal rocker Marilyn Manson. He comes across by far as the most intelligent and person in the film, and as someone who generally cares about the victims of violence. Manson offers strikingly sharp observations and ideas about the role of the media, the president, and US foreign policy in supporting the American gun-based tragedy.Moore has advanced his craft many levels since Roger and Me. His staunch trade unionist stand in Roger, is largely absent from Bowling. This is a largely a-political film about the American tragedy (Clinton and Bush policies receive approximately equal criticism), and a film that everyone who lives, or has lived, in America should see.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Less Moore</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>BFC's very success as a piece of art is its undoing as a piece of social commentary. Before I go on let me briefly sum up the film: MM attempts to discover what is wrong with America- specifically violence in America. The Columbine shootings in spring of 1999 are MM's starting point. MM tries to point out the dubious links posited by the media monster- brilliantly portrayed in a montage of 'scares' thrown out by the media- things from Halloween candy to weight loss products. This is an avenue worth pursuing, &amp; the 'scaring' of Americans into becoming consumers of anything that will substitute as a nipple is a great point. But it's made by shock rocker Marilyn Manson (a Columbine scapegoat), not MM, &amp; then immediately dropped. MM also is at his best when he details corporate America's need to portray black men as 'the problem' despite far more crime being perpetuated by white &amp; white-collared sorts. Instead, we get a whole bunch of amusing, but pointless red herrings- the Michigan Militia, the Nirvana of Canadian existence (aptly showing how good the Canadian health care system is, but woefully neglecting the severe curtailing of Canadian civil liberties- most notably free speech- in pursuit of this goal), workfare programs- which I agree are terrible because they perpetuate an underclass, yet do not let a bad single mother whose 6 year old son killed another 6 year old girl off the hook (as MM tries to imply), a nasty Dick Clark- who employed said bad single mother for slave wages in a mall restaurant, a doddering &amp; senile Charlton Heston- whom MM dishonestly snookered in to an attack interview, &amp; then- in the film's most pompous &amp; sickening moment- left the murdered 6 year old's photo on Heston's property, as if to imply that CH was responsible for her death- not the boy, nor the mother. I admire- &amp; LOVE- how MM uses the media's tools against them in such a screeding fashion. But he has become what he hates with this distortion. Nowhere does MM follow up on the public's &amp; media's appetite for sensationalism- instead he uses 2 dimwitted boys who survived being shot at Columbine to shame K-Mart in to removing bullets from their store's inventory. 1 can argue the rightness or wrongness of this act- I think they were within their rights to demand such, but it's ultimately a futile act. BUT the point is this was not done for any other reason than to bring MM's film to a climax. Instead of showing a problem, discussing its causes, &amp; effects, &amp; then proposing a solution- which a true documentary does, MM's film simply drops the ball at the end, settling for its own 2 hours of sensationalized splendor in MM's sun. The film is much more about Michael Moore's need to preen &amp; pat himself on the back, than in provoking any real debate. Behind us, at the theater, was a typical professorial type who Pavlovianly jeered at the right wingers, tsk-tsked at the appropriate moments of their stupidity, all the while, under his breath, mm-mming at the enlightened left wingers who, truthfully, to an objective viewer, came off being just as stupid as the Michigan Militia men- in their own predictably obtuse ways. Think long of Pogo's injunction about enemies while viewing this film.Still, the film would make Leni Riefenstahl proud. &amp; it would make 'true' Liberals proud, as well, were the film not so laced with ? truths &amp; such. MM has stated that he thinks only 10-20% of people who see his work will get it right away- therefore he has to distort with humor. Well, the same ratio might apply when it comes to the truth in MM's docs?.In short, Bowling for Columbine needed a lot more true depth, &amp; a lot less Moore.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Michael Moore's scathing 2002 documentary attempts to find answers to the question why American culture is steeped in violence and fear, while the rest of the world seems to be less-affected by violence and crime than America. His interviews with a bank that gives away guns, a high school drop-out who's disappointed he only made number two on the towns bomb threat list, and South Park creator Matt Stone and controversial rock artist Marilyn Manson are baffling, hilarious, disturbing and revealing. Together with two Columbine High School Massacre survivors (a shooting that occurred in 1999 in a Colorado high school for those that don't know), Moore scores against K-Mart, and in one of Moore's trademark ambush interviews, Charlton Heston comes perilously close to unmasking himself as an uncaring racist. Moore digs stubbornly for answers and arrives at startling connections, for instance when visits Lockheed Martin, the world's largest weapons manufacturer, which just happens to be located in Littleton, Colorado -- the location of High School massacre.The mystery involving the overly violent nature of America lives on, and what Moore is capable of discovering is that there isn't a concrete conclusion to be possibly drawn. Why is it that any U.S. citizens can personally own handguns just as easily as hunting rifles? Nobody, it seems, can find a valid reason for their purpose aside from as a gateway to further violence.Bowling for Columbine is one of the most thought provoking films in recent memory. In years to come, the film should stand as a watermark for how powerful and riveting a documentary film has the ability of being. It is entertaining enough to grasp the viewer; and is a highly recommended accomplishment.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2007-08-12</date>
		<username>tnrcooper</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What an incredible film. Moore investigates, via incidents and natives from his home state of Michigan, the reasons for America's close and possibly dysfunctional relationship with weapons. The title of the movie comes from the fact that supposedly, although this does not seem to be confirmed definitively by any of Klebold and Harris' fellow students or administrators in their school, the perpetrators of the Columbine High massacres went bowling on the morning of the massacres in fulfillment of an elective class they were taking. Moore looks at the students' decision to go bowling on the morning of the massacre as a metaphor for the disjointed and directionless lives which Klebold and Harris perhaps led, and which may be symbolic of the hopelessness and uncertainty that plague many young people. Moore looks at the horrific accidental shooting of a six-year old by a six-year old in his hometown of Flint and investigates some of the forces which led up to this tragedy. He talks to local officials, co-workers, and casual acquaintances of the boy's mother, who was forced by the welfare to work bill passed by President Clinton, to take a bus 70 miles away in order to pay her bills, in fact working two jobs in suburban Auburn Hills, Michigan, forcing her to spend long hours away from her son who shot the young girl and also from her other child. Still, she could not make ends meet. A week before her son shot a classmate, she was evicted from her apartment and asked her brother if she could stay with him for a short time. Drugs may have been dealt at the house and it certainly was not the sort of environment which would have provided stability and which might have kept his young classmate alive. Moore addresses some of the factors which took his mother away from him for extended periods of time, the dearth of good jobs in Flint-indeed, a GM plant had been closed recently, in an adjoining town and there were other jobs which had been outsourced to other countries. He interviews people affected when Charlton Heston, in his role as President of the NRA, brought his organization to Flint just after this tragedy. He finally interviews Heston at the end of the film in an exchange which does not reflect well on Heston, suggesting he is being disingenuous when he claims that his visits, to Flint in the wake of the shooting of this young girl, and to Denver for an NRA event had been scheduled previously. It is a sad but fitting end to a movie in which Moore once again looks far behind the headlines and does the sort of reporting and investigation which is badly needed by the country at large. He looks at individual cases shaped by gun use in the country and looks for deeper explanations as to why America is afflicted with massively larger numbers of gun deaths than in other countries. He ties blame a great deal of blame to the media's tendency to sow fear among the citizenry and their desire to keep people fearful and supine. Moore recognizes that problems in the United States run deeper than most of the media is willing to acknowledge, and he tackles the seeming dream-state with which many Americans seem to regard the availability of guns, with his trademark casual determination. All Americans should see this film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Filled with inaccuracies and mixed messages, but the main point is very valid.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In this film Michael Moore, in the wake of the Columbine shootings examines American gun violence and tries to find the reason for it. It is a daunting task. America has over 10,000 acts of gun violence a year while all other free world countries like Canada, England and Japan have a few hundred a year Some people insist that it is the violence in the media, others scream that it is the availability of guns and still others think it is because of our history. Which is it? A big part of Bowling for Columbine is picking apart the above claims, disproving them and purporting his own by means of comparing interviews and data. According to Michael Moore, the reason, or at least the biggest factor in American gun violence is fear. He builds this on the fact that crime has decreased over 20% but media coverage of crime has increased over 600%. This statistic blew me away when I read it prior to viewing BFC. I couldn't believe it. He compares interviews with Canadians and Americans that feature questions like "do you own a gun?" or "do you lock your doors?" and the differences are surprising. The Americans seem to be the ones who are afraid.I love Moore's style of narration. How he uses irony, humor and sarcasm to prove his point. Unfortunately this is usually accompanied by not telling the other side of the story. In fact, I don't think he ever tells the other side of the story in this movie unless it makes the other side look silly. Though this will sometimes make you laugh, you also have to be careful about what you take in. There are also a few mixed messages. He spends a good portion of the movie pointing out that gun violence isn't because of the availability of weapons yet he condemns K Mart for carrying bullets in their store. One need only Google Michael Moore to find a host of sites exposing these inaccuracies and mixed messages so I will not go into them. But whether or not you love or hate Michael Moore he makes one point in this movie that you can neither disprove nor ignore and that is that there is way to much fear in American society. Our culture is so heavily steeped in fear and insecurity that it penetrates every aspect of our lives and we are used to it. It is an excellent and entertaining wake up call for America that every American should see. Just be careful what you hear from this guy. I am a big fan of Moore, but I learned a long time ago that, while he raises some fantastic points he can never be trusted to give a two-sided story.86%</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Fascinating</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>True enough, Bowling for Columbine is, as many reviews claim, uneven, subjective and manipulative. Sure. It's important to remember, watching it, that this is not a subjective documentary, but a film that makes a very deliberate and intentional point, just like Mike Moore's previous, smaller scale enterprises. But aside from tackling some incredibly important issues, and bringing to light some fascinating obscure information, Bowling for Columbine should be noted for being one of the finest, most powerful pieces of propaganda ever seen. That's what it is, after all - propaganda, though it supports very positive and respectable causes. Mr. Moore is a master filmmaker, who does a fantastic, wonderful work of making his point and making his viewers care about it. The music, the monologue, the animation sequences and the archive footage are all combined with the interviews (fascinating interviews with Marilyn Manson, Charlton Heston and Matt Stone, among others) to create a powerful and intense ninety minutes that would keep your eyes glued to the screen like few other documentaries could. Highly recommended, no matter what your politics are. It will either inspire you of infuriate you - it's fascinating either way.</fullReview>

Don't get me wrong ? Fahrenheit is quality entertainment, but BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE scores big in diagnosing America's sickness as a whole and features Michael Moore at his best. What occurred to me whilst watching columbine is that he is a voice for the little man, he picks up on stories that the rest of the media would ignore such as the aftermarth of Columbine or the plight of the working classes in his home town of Flint. He stands and reminds us of the people at the bottom of the chain, such as the mother of the little boy who kill a six year old girl, who had to work 70 hours a week and still couldn't pay rent. His films remind us of those sections of society that we would rather forget, in a way he follows in a great socialist (little 's') tradition, that of Orwell or Miller and that is his importance. Whilst his films can sometimes be biased and a little unfocused at times he should continue to make films that speak of injustice and poverty and more over don't let us forget those on the bottom.As for the film its self it is a masterful piece of documentary making, which is far better paced and more focused that his next film 9/11. It takes us through the causes of gun ownership and crime in the US, through harrowing accounts of the Columbine massacre and the shooting of a little girl at the primary school in Flint. This leads finally to the symbolic heart of gun culture in the US, the NRA and ultimately to him talking to Chalton Heston. The film concludes with the most moving of imagery in which Moore leaves a photo of the little girl shot in buelle elementary school in Heston's house. This is an excellent film that calls, no screams at us all to remember that injustice and poverty are a part of modern America and this mix can lead to tragic circumstances.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Interesting but biased</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was the first film I've ever seen where the audience members (all twelve of them) gathered together afterwards to exchange thoughts and opinions. Eight people, 67%, said they lock their doors in contrast to the Toronto portrayed by Michael Moore where no one seems to have a problem with leaving their door unlocked. Yes, Toronto is a fairly clean and safe city but Moore went overboard portraying Canada as some sort of utopia!Overall, I felt this documentary was blatantly contradictory and biased, but it did such a great job of combining humour, horror, anecdotes, statistics and cultural comparisons that I greatly enjoyed the experience of watching it and thinking it over as I walked home. It was nice to see someone finally debunk the myths that are normally associated with gun violence. If children in other countries always play violent video games, watch violent cartoons, grow up in dysfunctional families, listen to violent music lyrics, etc. why do so few of them become violent when they reach adulthood? Those are great questions to ask. Of course, the overwhelming majority of Americans are friendly and non-violent (if you've never visited the U.S., don't let this movie fool you into thinking that the typical American is a paranoid gun-nut) - and yet, there is something unique about the U.S. that causes far higher per capita homicide rates than other countries. This movie is often quite fascinating as it explores these questions.If only the director hadn't been so intent on portraying himself as a hero the film wouldn't have appeared to be so contradictory and hypocritical. For example, Moore is an NRA member who repeatedly mentions that some countries have high rates of gun ownership, along with easy access to ammunition, without necessarily having a high rate of firearms deaths. He concludes that guns aren't the problem and there must be some other reasons for the high gun murder rates in the U.S.A. Why then did he demonise K-Mart for selling the bullets used in the Columbine shootings and try so hard to induce an apology from Charlton Heston for a little girl's death that neither Heston nor NRA had anything to do with.I did very much enjoy the interviews throughout the movie. There were some very funny moments mixed together along with thought provoking insights. Marilyn Manson deserved to have his say after he was widely singled out for contributing to the Columbine tragedy and he did provide a unique perspective on his "role" in the shootings. I also loved the interviews with James Nichols, Matt Stone and the blue-haired Ontario girl. I wish, however, that Moore had interviewed more intelligent gun owners rather than trying to them as mostly stupid fanatics. I've never ever touched a gun myself, but I still feel uncomfortable with that type of unfair distortion. Moore seems to underestimate his target audience in that regard: perhaps he didn't feel that his message would be as powerful if he had interviewed too many intelligent gun owners.From the statistics I've seen, Moore also missed the opportunity to compare cultures within the United States for clues and answers. For example, the homicide rate in the Southeastern USA is much, much higher than the homicide rate in New England. In fact, Minnesota and Massachusetts have lower overall violent crime rates than many Canadian provinces. Why then is Minnesota so laid-back and relatively crime-free if they are exposed to the same manipulative, fear-mongering media as the rest of the U.S.?</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An American hero's film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How on earth does a Micheal Moore documentary about hand guns in America rake in such incredible audiences and critical acclaim? I had to go to the cinema myself to find out. I did, I came, I saw, I was impressed. It starts rather offhandedly ("It was a normal day . . . the milkman delivered the milk, people went to work, and the President bombed another Asian country whose name he couldn't pronounce . . . ") but, as part of the backdrop to his investigation into guns and gun control, Michael Moore puts together an impressive array of facts about American involvement in world terror, its funding of characters and regimes it later attacks, its quick resort to violence internationally, and various other unpalatable facts that a quarter of the world (Europe) knows but tends to ignore and another sector of the world (Asia, Middle East, South and Central America) simmers with frustration over. They are facts that the average American is totally oblivious of or else attributes to malicious lies. That such a documentary should be made by an American, a very humble one it seems, is a testament to the goodness also inherent in American people. The facts and figures on guns, that suggest America easily outstrips all other countries for homicide by use of guns poses some interesting dilemmas - and ones which are portrayed better than they are answered. The film's initial theory is that the availability of handguns is the main cause - but then finds there are just as many guns in Canada but Canadians don't use them to shoot each other. It then looks briefly at the 'historical and cultural legacy of violence' (a theory favoured by a number of Americans interviewed) but in that America can hardly compete with Nazi Germany, the British Empire of Japan in various wars. It settles on a 'culture of fear' which it suggests (with some conviction) sets America apart from other similar developed countries. This part of the movie is somewhat less convincing - it doesn't, for instance, look at religious fundamentalism which sets America apart from most other developed countries but puts it into a similar category to some of its Middle East 'opponents'. But the suggestion that people who are 'so paranoid' should not be allowed ready access to guns appears to strike a note of truth. South Park poked political satire for those who understood the 'other' face of America - Michael Moore does it for real. Columbine, by the way, is the name of the school where a young kid went crazy with a gun, shooting his classmates. It is also near the site of the biggest factory of weapons of mass destruction in the world.</fullReview>

		<username>Mike Weston (mweston)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>3.5 stars (out of 4)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This documentary... but is this really a documentary? I would argue that it is, sort of, although the filmmaker, Michael Moore (who wrote, directed, and helped produce), is the main on-camera character, and this is his opinion. There is also an extended cartoon sequence which I assume was made specifically for this film, which seems counter-documentary. So it's easy to argue that the film is more of a performance piece than it is a true documentary.You might think that the question would be one of gun control, but it's really not. Moore turns out to be an actual lifetime member of the National Rifle Association, and the film shows that gun ownership is high in some other countries (most notably Canada), but the rate of using guns to kill one another is much higher here in the United States. So the basic question is: why?Moore covers a lot of ground in trying to answer that question, including, of course, Columbine High School (the film's title comes from the fact the the killers at Columbine went to a bowling class the morning of the shooting, by the way). I won't give away any conclusions that may or may not be reached, but he does talk with Charlton Heston (head of the NRA), Dick Clark, and, in a surprisingly down-to-Earth segment, Marilyn Manson. There is also a very funny stand-up comedy segment by Chris Rock, and a moving segment when Moore takes some survivors of the Columbine shooting to K-Mart, which is the store that sold the ammunition to the killers.This film manages to be entertaining, disturbing, educational, and thought provoking. The only thing that kept it from reaching my top rating is Moore's tendency to try to milk a situation for everything possible. He sometimes asks questions that are the equivalent of "Have you stopped beating your wife?" And when people leave an interview early, Moore often keeps standing there, trying to look helpless and asking a final question to the air. This feels like pandering to the film's audience far more than it feels like true fact finding.This film was the first documentary in many years to be accepted into the competition for the Golden Palm at the Cannes Film Festival. It did not win that, but it was given a special 55th Anniversary Prize, unanimously. It has also won audience awards at many other film festivals.Seen on 11/9/2002 at the 2002 Hawaii International Film Festival, although it was already playing in normal theaters at the time. I definitely recommend this film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The name of the game is fear.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I almost missed the free screening of Bolwing for Columbine at my school, being that the auditorium already exceeded it's maximum capacity with people crouched on any empty space on the floor. Michael Moore's previous documentaries and television spots (TV Nation) are mostly testimonies of the American workforce and employment practices (see The Big One and Roger &amp; Me). But, Bowling for Columbine is a movie that analyzes one theme: Why is America the highest among all industrialized nations in gun-related deaths? From the theme, it's obvious why Moore got a lot of flack from right wingers who protested the movie as they thought it conflicted with their 'right to bear arms' views. But, Bowling for Columbine only examines gun control as a secondary issue. That's because the question isn't why guns are involved in these deaths--but what is driving people to behave to violently in the first place? And the conclusion that Moore makes is that Americans are conditioned to irrationally fear so much.Bowling for Columbine is good as a comparative analysis, comparing the statistics of gun ownership versus the number of violent deaths. Then, in comparing things like information systems and cultural analyses, especially between America and Canada. For example, we see various clips of local news broadcasts from both countries. The American media always features something to stir up American's fear such as the "Killer Bees" and the Halloween Candy incident back in the 70s or the fact that the amount of violent crimes covered in the American media is statistically out of proportion with the reality of crime because actual crime rates are lower. Moore even provides illustration of how different prejudices (such as racial prejudice) operating to instill greater fear. Then, we see Canadian news and their perception of crime (Moore even notices how not too many residents in the area of Canada he was visiting even locked their door).With the mini cartoon documentary inserted in the film (this was the same animated trailer used to advertise movie), Moore similarly illustrates that America's fear has driven a history of violent crimes, going all the way back to the days the Europeans first settled in the country. As Moore suggests, their fears of the American Indian was responsible for near-genocide, as it would be too during Reconstruction and segregation and so forth. Until that even living in the peaceful suburbs never seemed safe enough. That is what this documentary is all about. Look at how scared everyone appears to be, and how such fears seemed relatively out of whack with the reality of things. Though the title recalls the Columbine shootings that occurred in Colorado a few years ago, the movie contains a lot of different contexts in which Moore makes this point. This isn't a movie about blaming administrations, and that's probably why people either don't take the opportunity to watch it or miss the point altogether, as they take it as a personal attack on their respective political affiliations. This isn't about that at all. Michael Moore, while his satirical presentation does drive a hard point, it does, however, also get somewhat preachy towards the end as he seems to try to get Chuckie Heston to change his stance about gun ownership by showing him the picture of the little girl that died.Some viewers wrote that this is a movie that politicians should watch. I doubt too many of them would address the issues seriously enough, as the goal is typically to try to please as many people possible with the right key words in a five minute soundbite. But, policymakers could take a few lessons from it. Likewise, so could the pathetic commercial media, especially that worthless institution known as the local news. Once again, Moore's documentary inspires a great deal of anger in myself as I think how many people have completely dismissed the film as simply nothing. Don't pass it up.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Why, do American's live in fear?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why, do American's live in fear? While there are many answers to this question, director Michael Moore exposes several on them in his documentary Bowling for Columbine. The movie released in 2002 is center around the bloody massacre that took place at Columbine High School where one teacher and twelve students were killed. Throughout the documentary Michael Moore exposes fear as a theme to this movie.In the movie Michael Moore uses one on one, interviews with many different people to convey his messages to the viewer. The idea of theme is best expressed in an interview that Michael Moore has with James Nichols, the brother of Terry Nichols who was convicted in the Oklahoma City bombing along with Timothy McVey. In this candid interview James Nichols expresses the fact that when he was arrested for possibly being linked to the Oklahoma City bombings that law enforcement officials where afraid of him and what they might find on his property during their search for evidence. Other well known names that appear in this movie are Dick Clark and Charlton Heston. In an interview with Charlton Heston, Michael Moore exposes the fear that the president of the Nation Rifle Association has of answering basic questions that have to deal with gun violence in America. Through the use of many graphical and telling videos Michael Moore continues to use fear as a theme of this movie. For instance he uses live video footage and 911 calls from the morning of the Columbine High School shootings to express the fear that the students and faculty where going through on the morning of April 20th 1999. In the videos the audience can see the students and faculty hiding under tables and running in fear as shots are echoing through the halls and class rooms of Columbine High School. Michael Moore ties all the themes and information that is presented in the movie brilliantly by filming the movie through omniscient point of view. With himself as the all knowing narrator, Michael Moore uses voice over to tie the movies interviews and video clips together. Through this technique Michael Moore not only adds his thoughts on what the audience is watching but also induces questioning and thought provoking ideas to the audience. He wants the audience to question what it is that they fear and what are they going to do about it? Michael Moore's latest documentary master piece Fahrenheit 9/11 just reiterates what a brilliant director Michael Moore is. In these two movies he exposes issues that effect the American population and gives them something to think about and possibly take action on to improve what is wrong in America. In Bowling for Columbine Michael Moore exposes the fear that American's go through day by day.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Sincere Motivation, Excessive Information, Absurd Intention, Manipulative Presentation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While the director Michael Moore's motivation is undoubtedly sincere, the excessive amount of almost random information in Bowling for Columbine makes his intention look absurd. The documentary serves Moore as his tool to observe and develop his thought on the various sociopolitical issues in the US: the gun control, the foreign policies, and the race relations. At the same time, the film attempts to alter the Americans' collective belief on these issues in a manipulative way.The documentary mainly focuses on the two recent shocking gun incidents: Columbine and the Michigan case six-year-old boy shot six-year-old girl. The main argument ramifies into numerous subtopics: the militia in Michigan State, the US foreign policy since the 1960s (in a collage of historic footage), the crime rate comparison between the US and other countries (especially Canada), the White Americans' fear towards the Blacks presented in the US history (in a cartoon digest), the US landscape change since the 9/11, and so on. The information stream dazzles the viewers, flowing one after another without intervals to allow them to reflect each piece.Because the stimulation that Bowling for Columbine offers is instant, it may not deeply change the Americans' views anytime soon. If the film has a genuine power to make a difference, effects may emanate as new generations' values several years or even several decades later. This is a type of artwork that only time can give the final verdict.</fullReview>

		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll get mad. (At least, I did)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a film that all people from age 12 upwards should be forced to watch, especially conservatives and those in favour of the oppressive regimes of the world, uninformed and unaware of the effects of the media and spin.For me, this is Micheal Moore's best work yet. Many say it lacks the personal insight of his earlier Roger and Me and, here in Britain, many are more used to seeing Moore in comedic mode on shows such as TV Nation. But this is a far more far-reaching and globally important film than anything he has done, bar his book Stupid White Men.Firstly, let me address the nay-saying surrounding the film. In the press, on the internet and even on American Network TV, people have accused the film of being a lie about the state of gun culture and culture in general in America. For those people, I would direct them to his website (its easy enough to find), in particular the section titled "Wacko Attacko". That should clear up some things. Know going into this that it deals with some things that are hard to take, but which could not make it into a theatrically released (not to mention Academy award winning) film if they were not gathered from fact.The film: starting with the now famous scene of Moore procuring a gun from a bank - given to him for opening an account with them - it is a no-holds-barred attack on the state of American gun law and the state of mind that comes with the Constitutionally protected right to bear arms. The picture he paints is that that right, paired with the culture of fear onmipresent in commercially-led TV, leads to the notion that we NEED guns to protect ourselves from a savage culture which exists only because we are led to believe it does.Taking a look at the history of fear and xenophobia front and centre in America's past, right up to the shootings at Columbine school and in Michigan in recent news, Moore's case is extremely effective in convincing us that there is a deep-rooted cancer in society which needs to be addressed if we are to break out of the shackles that we are born into through decades of self-serving propaganda. Moore's brief history of the USA is both hilarious and terrifying. But the real meat is the controversial footage which has some up in arms, decrying him as a liar and cruel opportunist and manipulator.The footage taken from Columbine school on the day of the killings is absolutely petrifying - a pair of teens armed to the teeth, killing their colleagues and peers with ruthless efficiency - and simultaneously heartbreaking. I am not ashamed in saying that i shed a good few tears, watching the sequence. It is the essence of good documentary, letting the images speak for themselves, devoid of deliberate commentary, to serve the purpose of the film and make a point far better than any voiceover could.When KMart executives refuse to see the victims of the bullets their store sold, you feel anger and know that the tables have been turned, that the people looking to make a quick buck by selling ammunition in a convenience chain are afraid of the repercussions of their decision. The resultant sequence and the honesty of the boys involved is both powerful and just.And that is the reason that Moore's film was afforded such praise and awarded one of the highest honours for a documentary filmmaker - it exposes an issue we knew existed, but which had not been fully addressed. It does so in an informative, poignant and humorous manner, enlightening us to the sheer scope of the epidemic, pointing the finger and offering an alternative way of life. It opens our eyes to the system that controls and consumes, that relies on our obedience and our money. It is both surprising and encouraging that the Academy gave Moore the Best Documentary Feature award. It shows that while they award dirge like A Beautiful Mind and the dull Chicago over more inspiring and long-lasting art (who will be talking about those films in ten, twenty, heck even five years?), they recognise a genuinely important film when it arrives.Finally, it is important to address the backlash surrounding the Charlton Heston interview. It has been called inappropriate, cruel and fruitless. Watch it. Just watch them both in that interview. Moore is a gentleman and, as one previous reviewer pointed out, actually stops Heston from truly hanging himself. Then think about what we have seen. Heston walks out on the interview - IN HIS OWN HOME!! - because he cannot justify his actions in any way that will not come across as ridiculous. he is the Chairman and spokesperson in chief of the National Rifle Association. He believes that people not only have the right but the cause to own guns. "From his cold dead hands". Manipulation or not, those are his words. And he did say them shortly after the Columbine shootings. WATCH THE INTERVIEW. He does not defend or dispute that fact. So he's old. He's infirm. He's a respected actor. Tough luck. He deserves, as much as anyone responsible does, to have those questions put to him. I will never pay for a Charlton Heston film, I will never watch a Charlton Heston film and I will not miss him when he is gone. His position as a free-thinking adult is indefensible. Shame on him.I may sound angry, and that is the effect the film has. Not in a "I'm gonna get a gun" way, but in a "We as a people are better than this, and I will fight that system all the way for my freedom as a person" kind of way. Once you have seen it, if you are open-minded and fed up with being held responsible for the actions of your nation's leaders, you will look at almost everything in the street in a different light. We don't have to do things this way. That is the film's ultimate message. It is a prescient point, made extremely convincingly. If you are tired of political drivel and commercial or militant spin, I urge you to see this film and support its director. He just might be one of the real good guys.10/10</fullReview>

Obviously, the "truth" is never in the screen or a book; it is out there, in life. So the point is not if it "shows the truth" but how convincing it presents his point: that america is a country dominated by self-feeding paranoia. Does it succeed? I think it has lots of good moments: when he shows the stupid Charlton Heston with alzheimer giving racist interpretations for violence, when the brother of the bomber in Oklahoma says that "there are lots of wackos out there" (and himself is a wacko), the funny summary of american history in cartoons, the (camp) advertising videos with bikini girls with machine guns, the interview with the militia guys, etc. However, even in some of its best moments the movie is closer to propaganda than to a "documentary", in the Discovery Channel sense of the word. This might be entertaining and funny if you previously agree with the ideas of the director ( and I do totally agree). If you just want to see a smart movie, are willing to understand the gun-crazyness of america or don't understand how eazy guns are so bad it might be irritating and confusing, sometimes.</fullReview>

The most memorable moment for me is the comparison between gun violence in the US and Canada. In Canada there are over 7,000,000 licensed guns in households but there are less than 400 people who die in gun-related incidents; in the US, guns kill over 11,000 people. One Canadian youth made a very simple observation: in Canada foreign policy is made through negotiating, but in America it is solved by violence. This couldn't be closer to the truth as we have seen (even as recently as the aftermath of 09/11) that the powers-that-be of American foreign policy do not negotiate, they threaten. People tend to shy away from documentaries because they don't see them as being entertaining. It is a shame that people have to draw a line between what is educational and what is entertaining as it has been my experience that that these 2 terms often merge. Michael Moore's "Bowling For Columbine" is extremely heart-felt but not melodramatic, it is informative and constantly engaging. Gun violence has to be controlled and it has to start with every individual. Although we may not all have the time to make a piece like this film, I congratulate and thank Mike Moore for exposing the issues that surround gun violence. We all have the ability to make a difference, even if it is as simple as voting on who has control in government, and that we can arrange for constitutional propositions to protect us all (and not just the supposed higher echelons). Do not miss "Bowling for Columbine" because we can all learn and take from the tragedies and mistakes it highlights to propose a better society to live in.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Definitely no gutter balls here. (**a couple of spoilers**)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is the BEST movie I've seen so far this year. This is the first Michael Moore film I've watched and I was pleasantly surprised at how funny, sad, powerful, quirky and insightful both he AND his film are. It's primarily a documentary about guns in America but it's really about so much more than that. The film's recurring question is: Why does America have more gun-related deaths than any other country? There's a staggering moment in the movie where it compares the number of gun-related deaths in other countries with those of America: Canada has like 99 a year, France 150 a year, England 196 a year; but America has 11,120 a year! And Moore spends the movie trying to understand why. The film's closest answer is that America, more than any other country, has always been paranoid and afraid. There's an amusing but disturbingly accurate cartoon midway through the movie that depicts the evolution of America from the time of the Pilgrims to the present and how fear is the main underlying factor responsible for the violence and wars that shape America's legacy.Two major surprises in the film are Michael Moore's interviews with Marilyn Manson and Charlton Heston. In spite of Marilyn Manson's blatant weirdness, you have to admit that the guy had some valid, sensible things to say about the Columbine incident. And concerning Charlton Heston, I never thought he could be so chilling and misled (after all, this is Moses!).Regarding some comments here lambasting Michael Moore for his unorthodox approach to documentary-filmmaking: I think that this is his strength. He's an American original who's not content to just point his camera and roll film. In a world where you see more talk than action, it's touching and commendable to see Moore take a pro-active approach at the end of the film and get Kmart to stop selling bullets and firearms. Moore is like that naughty-eyed, restless kid in class who managed to get the teacher to hold class outside one particular afternoon or to not give homework over the weekend one Friday; your parents tell you he's no good and even the teacher doesn't like him, but you harbor a secret admiration for him: because he says the things you want to say but don't quite know how, and he does the things which you wish you could do but don't quite have the guts to.Put another way: Michael Moore is Robin Hood with twinkies in his pocket; maybe even Alexander the Great with an untucked shirt.</fullReview>

		<username>Art Snob</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Before giving credence to anti-Moore harangues like Steve's, please read this</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this film at the Toronto Film Festival last month, one of the relatively few Americans in the audience. I had problems with Moore's approach and attitude in his signature piece, ROGER AND ME, and was braced for him to be taking a similarly simplistic black and white approach to the topic of guns in America.I was pleasantly surprised and impressed. Moore ? a member of the NRA since he was a teenager ? completely eschews preaching the gun control arguments that his more hidebound fellow members are poised to reflexively jump all over. In fact, he specifically supports the notion that fewer guns AREN'T the solution to America's sky-high homicide rates. He doesn't supply pat answers, as advocates on both sides of the gun control debate so readily do. Instead ? drawing heavily on comparisons to Canada, where gun ownership is nearly as widespread as it is in America and consumption of American culture is voracious ? he focuses on the mega question of what could explain why Americans are so astronomically more inclined to homicidally USE their guns than their neighbors to the north. Moore's documentary approach is scattershot at times, but there's no denying that he hits a huge number of satirical bulls-eyes along the way on his odyssey in search of the elusive answer. The film is an emotional roller coaster that keeps shifting between tragedy and absurdity in a thoughtful, tasteful way that often evokes `so that I might not cry' laughter. Whatever your feelings about Moore are, there's no denying that he has an eye for the absurd and a gift for catching interviewees off-guard with straightforward questions that they don't have a prepared response for. Particularly impressive is when he finally gets to interview `Moses' himself at his Beverly Hills mansion. Charlton Heston is so at a loss to explain the huge disparity between American and Canadian homicide rates that he inadvertently makes some racist slip-ups that shatter his long running `I marched with Martin Luther King' facade. You'll be seeing a lot of anti-Moore diatribes (similar to the one by stevetseitz@yahoo.com just below this one in the user comments section) as the film makes its way around the country. Be mindful of one thing: ANYONE WHO ACCUSES THIS MOVIE OF ADVOCATING GUN CONTROL OR `TRYING TO PORTRAY LEGAL GUN OWNERSHIP AS INSANE' HASN'T ACTUALLY SEEN THE MOVIE!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2012-07-30</date>
		<username>ramsfan</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>The Praise is Undeserving</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When one seeks to expose inconvenient truths about our society through honest dialog and fact-finding, they are to be commended; when one seeks to prove their point through shoddy journalism, half-truths and deceit, it's shameful. Michael Moore does mostly the latter in 2002's Bowling For Columbine, a documentary which is at times interesting and thought-provoking but ultimately completely disingenuous and misleading. Most alarming about BFC is that it illustrates just how powerful the media really are and how the public generally are willing to accept things at face value rather than research the issues. One can say ANYTHING in a film, and at least half the people will believe it, no matter how ridiculous or slanted it may be. Moore takes full advantage of this, presents a picture loaded with half-truths and inconsistencies and won himself an Oscar. That the left-leaning Hollywood Academy would reward such an effort should come as no surprise.Bowling For Columbine is not without merit. It deals with the terrible shooting tragedy at Columbine High School and its after effects throughout the United States. In trying to explain how something like this occurred, Moore delves into America's sometimes unsavory history; slavery, alliances with foreign dictators, war involvement etc, and examines society's seemingly insatiable love for guns. Government inadequacies, especially as related to health care and poverty are discussed, and parallels are drawn between these issues and disaffected individuals in our society. Unfortunately, amidst these very real issues, Moore plays fast and loose with the facts; the Columbine killers were NEVER in bowling class that day, Charlton Heston NEVER uttered the "from my cold dead hands" proclamation in Denver, the NRA convention was booked years before the Columbine tragedy and was prevented by law from being entirely cancelled, and on and on. Moore misrepresents numerous happenings- including the whole North County Bank gun for CD program- by cleverly splicing footage and conveniently leaving out important facts contrary to his position. Numerous legitimate journalists, most notably Dave Kopel, have written lucid, extensive pieces exposing Moore's often disingenuous approach to BFC. Trying to pigeon-hole Dick Clark and sandbagging Charlton Heston under false pretenses- as if these guys were responsible for the nation's tragedies- were particularly shameful and pandered to the liberal viewer anxious to see a conservative celebrity squirm.Bowling For Columbine presents very real issues for which much dialog and action is needed, but ultimately any meaningful message that Moore hoped to send is undone by his self-serving and fictitious "facts". In lambasting the government for creating and perpetuating this "culture of fear", with an over abundance of negative reporting, the hypocritical Moore does the exact same thing- for profit no less- in a feature documentary. So much for objectivity.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-11-28</date>
		<username>virek213</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"Thank You For Not Shooting Me"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Love him or hate him, Michael Moore is America's ultimate cinematic muckraker, with a truckload of liberal political beliefs to boot, and there is nothing that anyone can do about it. And for all the ways that the far-right has done to smear his name all over creation, whether it's an attack on his books or his films, he hasn't chosen to fade away. The Oscar-winning 2002 film BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE is a case in point, as he goes after what makes America the most gun-crazy society on the planet, as well as the #1 nation in the world when it comes to gun-related deaths and murders.The title, of course, refers to what Eric Harris and Dylan Kleibold were doing on the morning of April 20, 1999, only a few hours before they entered the grounds of Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado, a suburb of Denver, and turned the school into a scene of utter carnage with bombs and hi-tech weaponry. Twelve students and a teacher were killed in the rampage and dozens of others were injured, before Harris and Kleibold took their own lives.Using Columbine as a linchpin, through the use of the school's surveillance cameras and actual 911 calls from the massacre itself, Moore then takes a long hard look at why it is that Americans have an unhealthy love for guns and killing when other countries that have an equally proportionate amount of gun owners have far lower murder rates than us (combined, the total number of murders in Canada, Australia, England, France, Germany, and Japan add up to only about one-fifth the U.S. murder rate). Many factors are explored by Moore, in discussions with members of the Michigan Militia; James Nichols (brother of Terry Nichols, one of the Oklahoma City bombers); shock rocker Marilyn Manson (who was used as a convenient scapegoat for Columbine because the shooters were fans of his); actor and former National Rifle Association president Charlton Heston; and "South Park" creator Matt Stone (himself a former Columbine student). There are also explorations of our nation's violent past (through a clever and funny "South Park"-like cartoon), and how we export our love for guns and violence to the outside world (in various clips set to Louis Armstrong's "What A Wonderful World", culminating of course with the 9/11 attacks).Moore doesn't offer any easy answers as to why America has become so obsessed with guns and violence, because to try and pin it down to one root cause--be it poverty, racism, or the allegedly violent Hollywood sub-culture--would amount to being dishonest. But he does strongly indict both opportunistic politicians, religious demagogues (e.g., Jerry Falwell), and television shows like "Cops" and the fear-mongering, right-wing proclivities of the Fox News Channel for having instilled such fear of people who are "different" from the rest of us that the only thing we seem to want to do to protect ourselves is buy all the guns and ammo we can. And even though he himself is a gun owner and a longtime NRA member, Moore doesn't let the man who once played Moses and walked with Martin Luther King in the 1963 March on Washington off the hook. Heston, who in the minds of many Littleton and Denver metro area residents displayed a shocking insensitivity to their pain by holding an NRA convention in their town just ten days after Columbine, is grilled by Moore inside his own Coldwater Canyon estate for answers as to the high murder rate in America. Though many of Heston's answers to Moore are sound, they also indicate just how far to the political right he has drifted since the 1970s.BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE obviously stirred up a great deal of incendiary passion (as, of course, would FAHRENHEIT 9/11 just a year and a half later), but it also started a serious debate over this nation's seemingly endless love for guns and killing. Just for that reason alone, its win at the Oscars for Best Feature Length Documentary of 2002 was a well-earned and well-justified one.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I guess I don't have to tell you that this documentary is really a very thought provoking and controversial movie.
