It's all too obvious that someone who claims the opposite must have lived in some cave or on another planet for the past 5 years.Overall I liked what I saw in this documentary, but what has struck me most was perhaps the comparison between the USA and other countries. Did the fact that each year more than 11.000 people get killed by a gun in the US have something to do with violent movies, with the more violent or aggressive history, a larger rate of poverty, the easy availability of guns...? No, as this movie shows us, it has more to do with fear than with anything else. In my opinion that's the strongest message this documentary conveys.But next to this message, there were also a lot of other positive things. For instance the humor, which was sometimes absolutely great, although Moore didn't always have much to do to make it laughable. A good example of that humor is when he asks himself why no-one blamed bowling for the Columbine incident when they found out the boys had gone bowling before starting their raid on the school. Another funny topic is the bank that's also an arms dealer. Each customer that opens a certain account can choose a weapon from their catalog. Moore's question after he finds that out: 'Don't you think it's a little bit dangerous, handing out guns in the bank?' is hilarious and shocking at the same time. Shocking because you wonder if they never thought about that themselves, did all these smart people working for that bank really need a film maker to come up with that idea??? Something else that I really liked was the fact that he gave gun nuts as well as the victims the opportunity to say what they had to say about weapons. Some of these testimonies were more shocking than I could ever expect, certainly when some of them seemed to be proud of the fact that they carried all those weapons with them. And when he used the actual sound tape, made by the emergency services during an incoming phone call in which someone said that a six year old girl was shot by one of her class mates and that she was dying right there on the floor, was almost too much to handle, even for me and I'm used to a lot...If there is one point of criticism that I might have than it must be the fact that Michael Moore knew exactly where he wanted to go with this documentary. Normally this kind of documentary shows all pros and cons without judging, but Moore doesn't work that way. It's obvious that he doesn't like guns and he'll do anything to show it. Nevertheless this is still a movie with a very powerful message. A message that people with guns who are afraid, won't hesitate to kill, but that even when they don't pull the trigger themselves, weapons can be a dangerous thing to have... You know what I thought after seeing this documentary? I thought: I'm so glad not to live in America, perhaps it isn't all that bad over here after all... I give this documentary an 8.5/10</fullReview>

		<username>MovieLuvaMatt</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>One of my favorite movies! Rarely am I so moved by a film!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This ranks as one of my favorite films of all time, and for good reason. First of all, any movie that can make me laugh hysterically, cry and fill up with anger is something very special. "Bowling for Columbine" made me experience a rollercoaster of emotions, and it should be seen by everyone!I've loved Michael Moore ever since I saw "Roger and Me." When I was told, in my class, that I was about to watch a documentary about the closing of a GM plant in a Michigan town, I was prepared to be bored out of my mind. But Moore constructed the film in such a way that it was funny, entertaining and touching. He made the subject matter relatable to the average human being. In the case of "Columbine" I was already interested in the subject matter, and Moore's treatment of it heightened my interest. The movie explores all aspects of violence in this country, and how it compares to violence in other countries. It makes a great argument about violence in the media. Moore shows that in Canada young people play the same violent video games and watch the same violent movies, yet the country manages to be generally non-violent. So take that, all you dummies who attribute every violent crime in the U.S. to what we see on TV and in the movies. The Charlton Heston interview at the conclusion is one of the film's highlights. From now on, I will never be able to watch a Heston film the same way ever again. The guy is the Antichrist! The animated sequence is another great moment. It's a hilarious, yet truthful sequence that sums up the cycle of violence dating back to the very, very early days. The movie also touches on some other provocative subjects, like the portrayal of minorities in the media. Moore intercuts an interview with the creator of the show "Cops," with a comedy sketch that gives us an idea of what the show would be like if it fixated on white-collar crime. To sum it up, few films have moved me more than "Bowling for Columbine." People criticize Moore for being "manipulative." You can't be manipulated into something unless you at least somewhat believe in it. He's not a Fascist dictator. He's a simply working-class Joe who wants to express his views. If you don't agree with his views, that's fine. But don't stop the rest of us from appreciating his work. Because I believe he deserves every bit of recognition he gets. He truly is a genius!My score: 10 (out of 10)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>cruz3</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A must see for the socially responsible</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Moore does an excellent job of presenting so many different things to think about during this movie it is hard to describe them all. Sure, it includes some hyperbole (like using raw numbers vs. per capita statistics to compare the number of homicides in different countries) and some moments that feel more plastic than dramatic (mostly Moore's pleas and comforting moments), but these don't make the movie less worthwhile. There is enough dark humor to go around (like Charleton Heston falling one slip of the tongue away from showing his true colors), so the movie is alluring enough to keep most people interested. As a gun owner, and one who would probably be considered affluent by Flint, Michigan standards, I found Bowling well made enough to make me think carefully about some of my own beliefs and why I hold (or held) them. Sure, Mike bleeds on a little bit - but the movie is powerful enough to make you examine a lot about the country around you and what your place in it can mean. Few documentaries are passionate or entertaining enough to command your whole attention for two hours: Moore accomplished this and made me think as well. I intend to make my son watch it when he is old enough.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-11-19</date>
		<username>harry-76</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Highly Significant Documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Every now and then a documentary comes along which transcends being merely informative to actually being thought provoking and challenging."Bowling for Columbine" is such a work. Michael Moore has done a superlative job of bringing together much factual material and presenting it in such a way that constantly engages the intellect as well as emotions. His challenge to us is to abandon the abject stupidity of fear consciousness: ceasing to be be duped by "fear-mongers" trying to profit from "fear-tactics." The documentary reveals how the news media flocked to a "sniper scene" in America which involved some dozen "victims," while only hours before, hundreds of our "foreign" brethren were being targeted by US bombs.As long as it doesn't happen here, we can blithely turn away our attention and concern--seems to be a message conveyed by this powerful film.All this results in a beefing up of "security," manifest by locking our doors, while cameras and other type of equipment is in force. This is in sharp contrast to our friendly neighbors to the north, who conversely consider such actions as actually locking themselves in, rather than keeping "intruders" out; they in turn not only keep doors unlocked, but actually place "Welcome Mats" on their front stoops. And why not? Isn't the later the way it should be? For what are "security" devices but the result of fear? Moore's documentary points out the violence of America's past, from early settlers through the past century's civic clashes. The result is a fragmented society of "we" and "them," of "inner city" vs. "suburban" dichotomies, and of movement toward a more de facto "class" than "homogenized" societal system. So we have communities in which citizens buy ammunition at local family stores, then use it to "down" their own neighbors. In dealing with the more bloody and shameful aspects of American history, Moore wisely shifts to cartoon depictions--yet this stylization somehow makes the horrors even more biting (as does his use of "smooth" pop songs underneath the graphic depictions of inhumanity).As a result, these images and messages tend to remain in the memory long after viewing the film. They tend to persist and won't easily go away. This is as it should be, for we have a good deal to account for in terms of our own pursuit of violence. It's long time that we reassess ourselves and become much more revisionary in our outlook and actions. The less we buy into violence, the more it will disappear. "Bowling for Columbine" is a major leap toward helping to achieve that objective.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>kida_fish</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>FUNNY, AND SERIOUSLY THOUGHT-PROVOKING</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*Possible Spoilers*Forget Michael Moore's biased views, forget how he conveniently keeps at bay, the 'other' point of view, and forget how he wants us to believe only his side of the truth. As a filmmaker, he is a genius. He has a fantastic sense of humor, and knows better than anyone else, the nitty-gritties of how to use satire as a weapon. In fact, he has mastered the delicate art of sarcasm.A film about violence, 'gun-violence' in particular, is not such a difficult thing to make these days, is it? It is not, but Moore's way of looking at violence and his somewhat cheeky way of presenting his views on it though, are anomalous, and Bowling For Columbine is one anomalous documentary.Bowling For Columbine completely redefines the concept of the 'Candid Camera' form of entertainment. Catching others unguarded in their gawkiest moments, and laughing at their expense, has always been a rather seedy form of entertainment. But, Moore's way of making fools of the 'wiseacres', or simply, the 'ill-doers', by making a big fool of himself before them, has found a more thoughtful and productive use for the trash that is affectionately known as 'Candid Camera'.In the movie, in addition to stating the facts from his sound research-work, Moore does plentiful of 'street-work', basically interviewing all kinds of people, from a school drop-out who felt insulted when his name was number-two on the 'threat-list' of his school, and not number one, right up to the Hollywood 'gun-possession advocating' legend, Charlton Heston, and getting all kinds of answers from them, some funny, some shocking, but all leading to the serious undertone of the movie.Moore's crazy animation byte on the 'History Of America', and his disturbing presentation (amid the paradoxical background of Louis Armstrong's 'What A Wonderful world') of why he thinks the country has always been unreasonably violent, are hilarious as well as acerbically provocative.Moore's facts may be 'doctored' or questionable. But, his presentation of the supposed facts does make those who support his views, as well as those who think he is a big fat fatuous pig, ponder, talk, and have opinions. If this is so, then his job is probably fulfilled. And, along with making us think, if he makes us laugh and cry, then he is indeed a genius, a well-deserving Oscar-winner. Rating: 8/10</fullReview>
	</review>

'Bowling For Columbine' is a powerful piece of film making and Moore has pulled it off brilliantly to make this easily one of the best films of 2002. It centers on the horrific massacre at a high school in Columbine where 12 students and one teacher were gunned down by two kids (also students in the school) and further elaborates on the gun craze in America dating back to our forefathers and why we are the way we are in this country of ours.The movie opens with Moore walking into a bank that is offering a free rifle to all new customers that open an account. You watch with surprise while the teller in the bank confirms that its true. The vault is packed with weapons and Michaels only fair question is, "don't you find it odd to have guns in a bank?" Blame it on this and blame it on that is everyones response to Moore. While some of the arguments seem valid such as high unemployment, racial tensions, and poverty being the reason, Moore easily proves that wrong by giving the above statistics in Canada. While the unemployment rate in the United States averages 5.5 - 6%, Canada's average is 8 - 9%. And we see Japanese people, black people and the likes strolling through the streets of Canada everyday. And poverty? The government of Canada provides more than adequate living for those in need plus health insurance for everyone. (Ok sure, they have higher taxes to subsidize these programs but at least only 75 or so people were killed by guns in their country compared to America's 11,000)One disturbing (but well done) scene is the news team reporting on the murder of a six year old girl who was accidentally (perhaps) shot by a another six year old classmate. The reporter (who I was hoping would get shot) tells the audience what a sad moment it is and his deepest sympathy goes to the family who lost their little girl. But once the camera cuts, his only real concerns are what time lunch is and wishing he would have sprayed his hair before he left home. And remember "nice" guy Dick Clark from America's Bandstand? Lets just say his first name fits his true character perfectly.To no surprise, President of the NRA (National Rifle Association) actor Charlton Heston appears frequently in the film. Unlike Mr. Personality Dick Clark, Heston agrees to an interview with Moore but unfortunately, his replies to the gun violence in America are so unconvincing that I now understand why he has Alzheimer disease.So, does this movie make me hate America? Of course not. 'Bowling for Columbine' makes me feel sorry for it. As many politicians have said when running for office, "it's time for a change", my reply is simple; prove it, because Michael Moore sure as hell did...................</fullReview>

While in Canada the similarities between US and Canada are shown, both have kids who listen to hard rock, cut school, watch violent movies and play violent video games, both have many citizens who own guns. Because of these similarities the question of why is there so much violence in the US is brought up and no one can answer this, but this film gives us a lot of ideas. All in all this is a great film that will leave you wondering 'Are we a nation of gun nuts or are we just nuts?' (the films tagline). 		<username>dee.reid</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The most thought-provoking documentary that I have ever seen. Michael Moore is a genius.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After reading all of the negative press that this film has received, I now feel that I must put in my two cents. Michael Moore asks a number of startling questions in his documentary "Bowling for Columbine," a film about America's fascination with gun culture.First of all, I had never heard of Michael Moore prior to "Bowling for Columbine."Second, I don't believe that the purpose of "BFC" was to convert the people that watch it into anti-gun lobbyists. Moore's purpose with "BFC" was to open people's eyes up to a very frightening crisis in our country, which is our fascination with guns. We seem to live in a very close-minded society and I think that "BFC" did reveal some things to the audience, at least to the people who were willing to open themselves up to the film's message that we're living in very troubling times and our greatest enemy of all may not be Osama Bin Laden, but ourselves.I don't think that the question is why does the United States have the highest murder rate in the world, but it's really more of a question of WHAT causes such disturbing statistics? Moore thinks that it's the media and our constant desire to be armed, but for what cause? I think that both are very interesting and may contribute heavily to the crisis, but I think the answer is more mental than anything else. I think it's more of a question of the psyche, that elements such as racism, terrorism, fear, and rage and to add to that already troubling equation, an unstable political climate, have ingrained themselves so deeply into the American way-of-thinking, that it's basically boiled down to a corrupted rationale.I cannot help but agree with the question that Moore asks the audience - Why do we feel the need to hurt someone else at the level that we do? You see, it's things like this that Moore struggles to understand with "BFC." Why violence and what is our fascination with it? Why do we stoop down to the violent levels that we do to resolve conflicts that could otherwise be calmly discussed?We also have a rather creepy interview with James Nichols (brother of Terry) who is also believed to have been in on the Oklahoma City Bombing of 1995, where 168 people were killed. James had to be released because there was not enough evidence to convict him of anything. Terry received life in prison while his partner Timothy McVeigh was executed in 2001. Both McVeigh and T. Nichols were said to have been attendees of meetings for the "Michigan Militia," a pro-gun group situated somewhere in rural Michigan, close to where Moore grew up.As the the film's title would have it, this also deals with the shooting at Columbine High School, which includes actual security footage of the massacre and interviews with several of the survivors including two kids who were actually wounded in the attack; Matt Stone, co-creator of the hit animated show "South Park" is also interviewed, as he has many fond memories of attending Columbine. This is one of the most affectionate things I have ever seen one man do on camera; totally unexpected from Moore. Just the lengths that Moore goes through to prove his points. One such example: Moore and the two wounded Columbine survivors bravely go into K-Mart headquarters where they go to return the ammunition that was legally purchased by the two Columbine killers (Eric Harris, Dylan Klebold).It also includes one interview with heavy metal singer Marilyn Manson. I have absolutely no respect for him as an artist, but he actually came off as quite an intelligent man in his interview with Moore. Because Manson was labeled as the primary source of the killer's desires to murder people, he flips the script by stating why wasn't the president at the time (Bill Clinton; nothing personal, Bill) labeled as a source of violence, since the same day that Columbine happened, more bombs were dropped on Kosovo than any other time during that conflict. Ironic says Manson.Right around the third act, things become personal for Moore, as he returns to his hometown to interview several individuals about a school shooting, in which a six-year old girl was killed by one of her classmates. It is this segment of the film that most likely earned Moore his Oscar for Best Documentary at 2002's Academy Awards ceremony.To conclude "BFC," Moore sets up an interview with National Rifle Association president and Oscar-winning actor, Charlton Heston. Heston gives some pathetic answers to some really hard-hitting questions asked by Moore. When asked about why he keeps so many guns in his house yet has never himself been a victim of crime, Heston replies, "Because the Second Amendment allows me to keep a loaded gun." The Second Amendment may or may not be the worst of the Bill of Rights, but in my sincere opinion, it is an amendment that is too easily abused by too many trigger happy people living here in the U.S. This scene concludes with Moore begging Heston to look at a picture of the six year-old girl who was murdered in his hometown, and Heston walking away. What's most powerful is what follows. As Moore prepares to leave, he sets the picture next to a brick pillar and the camera does a closeup of the photograph, and follows Moore as he exits off of Heston's estate.Praise Michael Moore.10/10</fullReview>

		<date>2003-08-24</date>
		<username>Jonny_Numb</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>engrossing, compelling, and hopelessly overrated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For all the good Michael Moore accomplishes with "Bowling for Columbine," it still rests on the lower rung of his trilogy of filmed documentaries (behind "Roger &amp; Me" and "The Big One"), basically because of the subject du jour (guns and violence in America and abroad), and how it is emphasized through emotional and political manipulation (reminiscent, in the opposite sense, of a certain band of pirates occupying the White House). In his previous works, Moore functioned as a fearless everyman standing up to the ignorance of corporate tyranny--in BFC, he maintains the role, but the subject relies too much on the tugging of the old heartstrings to sway viewers. The Bush Administration knows that, to keep the approval rating high, you must be able to keep the public's emotions (particularly their fear) under your thumb at all times; Moore knows this as well, which might explain why this film has garnered a lot of hype, praise, and financial success (even an Academy Award) while not necessarily being BETTER than his other films. Granted, it is well-assembled, quite strategic in the editing, and leaves you with much to think about; the montage of American-sponsored atrocities and actual security-camera footage from the Columbine massacre is quite harrowing, yet too often the film seems cut specificially to support Moore's viewpoint, and the subjects of his inquiry seem like stunts (with a heavy reliance on celebrity guest stars like Marilyn Manson and Charlton Heston). For a film that tackles a subject as controversial as gun violence, Moore's approach lacks the subtle ferocity that made his previous films so thought-provoking. Still, in spite of its flaws, even if BFC is the lesser of Moore's filmed works, it is still more engrossing than almost anything coming out of the mainstream Hollywood pipeline right now.7.5/10 (This rating pertains to the contents of the recent DVD release.)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>FilmOtaku (ssampon@hotmail.com)</username>

		<shortDescription>A hard-hitting and insightful documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Boy is it tough to start this review. I finally watched this film after wanting to see it for quite some time, and I'm very glad I did ? it really provided food for thought for me, in more ways than one. Bowling for Columbine takes a look at gun violence in America among other issues, and is in Michael Moore's typical in your face style where the humor is extremely dry. Moore interviews, among others, Charlton Heston and Marilyn Manson in his quest to find out why there are so many gun related deaths in America. This is a documentary that is very one-sided, but? who cares? Moore had the moxie to discuss the white elephant in the room and made an excellent documentary about it ? had the extreme right made a documentary with as much talent then perhaps it would have done just as well. At this point, I have to say that I am an enormous fan of Michael Moore's work. I enjoyed his earlier work in Roger and Me and TV Nation, never missed The Awful Truth on Bravo and loved The Big One. I also enjoy his published works as well. Of course he has a left slant; he never hides that fact, and he takes a lot of beating for it. What endears me to him is that he handles himself in both a serious, yet darkly comical manner. It amazes me that those who deem him a `liberal wacko' and try to silence him are at times the same people who refer to the Constitution of the United States as a defense for owning guns. Apparently, they forget about the whole `free speech thing' that our nation is founded on.Having said that, I was a little disconcerted with a couple of items in Bowling for Columbine, namely the interview with Charlton Heston. I hated the fact that he filmed Heston walking away and then filmed the whole thing about the 6 year old girl who was shot afterward, making it look like he was still talking to Heston. I wasn't so disturbed because it was faulty journalism. I was disturbed because it only has added fuel to those who are trying to decry his entire documentary as fiction. However, that is one of the very few complaints I have about the film. Amazingly, one of the surprising highlights of the film was Moore's interview with Marilyn Manson. Like his music and image or not, he came across refreshingly well-spoken and extremely intelligent. There is absolutely no way one can contradict that, whether you agree with what he had to say or not. I also *really* enjoyed the `cartoon history lesson' ? it had me laughing, but again it was mostly fact.Bowling for Columbine was a hard film to swallow ? any film that closely examines the deaths of teenagers and children is ? but it is an extremely important film nonetheless. I highly recommend this film to anyone ? even if you are conservatively right wing, perhaps it will provide food for thought, and will create a dialogue in expressing why you disagree without simply calling Moore a `liberal wacko.' That term is a bit overused, and if one is educated, the very least thing they could do is come up with a new term for this Oscar winner. --Shelly</fullReview>
	</review>

However, as Moore made clear, Canadians aren't killing each other with rifles or even killing each other as American's do.The film raises a lot of questions. How did Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris get a hold of a TEC-DC9 which is a type semi-automatic firearm which killed and injured numerous people in the massacre. Also how is it that stores such as Kmart are allowed to sell anyone as much ammunition as they please? Moore confronts every issue with skepticism and always has a question to ask when given an answer. So many facts are given yet we are capable to remember it all. We see that the United States may not be the perfect land it is made out to be. The scenes involving Canada make this quite clear. We are presented with both sides of the argument. We meet several people from the Michigan State Militia who I think give the best opinions on the matter. We also meet some people strongly opposed to firearm freedom and some people strongly in support of fire arm freedom. It hits all points of the matter on firearm legalization. Michael Moore has created his best work yet. He has created an important film on an important subject matter. Should semi-automatic weapons be allowed to be owned by everyday people like you and I? Should ammunition be available to be purchased from anyone so willing to do so? Should the 2nd Amendment of the US Constitution be revoked? 		<shortDescription>Very entertaining documentary (yes, it's possible)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>NOTE: This comment is written by me, that is a Canadian citizen. But I swear that I tried to be as objective as possible.When the documentary "Bowling for Columbine" ended, I was almost crying. This movie really shocked me."Bowling for Columbine" is directed by Michael Moore, certainly the most famous documentarist in modern cinema, as well as one of the most controversial.I understand that the issues raised by Moore are uncomfortable and questionable for many Americans. But unquestionable is the fact that he sinks in his subject, without resting, until his questions are answered."Bowling for Columbine" talks about the infamous massacre in Columbine High School in 1999 but it quickly devolves on Americans' 'obsession' with guns and violence, even getting deeper and deeper, reaching themes such as media manipulation, U.S. foreign policy, American history, business and Canada vs. United States culture.If the subject reaches such far-away themes, it's mainly because of Moore's sharp intelligence and his inventive methods of documenting his subject. His 'script' is first rate and he never derails even if he often has to improvise.Many scenes are already considered as classic ones. The first one, where Moore wants to "open an account which gives a free gun" in a Michigan bank, the "What a Wonderful World" segment, the funny South Park-inspired cartoon about American history, the K-Mart campaign and the unforgettable interviews with James Nichols, South Park co-creator Matt Stone, Marilyn Manson and Charlton Heston."Bowling for Columbine" is perhaps the most effective Moore-made documentary, because it's the most original, the most striking and the one who gets the closest to the viewer.Many filmgoers will be surprised that a documentary can be so entertaining, so striking and so educational at the same time. It's because that Moore knows how to give popular value to his product. There's also the controversy factor that helps (or hurts) Moore, because this movie has been so much publicized, much more than "Roger &amp; Me", and his engaged speech at the Academy Award ceremony in 2003 gained him even more attention.Almost impossible to watch with a neutral mind, "Bowling for Columbine" is an educational must, should it be for its 'objective' look at modern America or for its potential to arouse controversy. Should you agree or not with the issues it raises, it's worth watching at least once, because you wouldn't believe how much it's pleasing to watch a documentary.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-04-01</date>
		<username>gftbiloxi (gftbiloxi@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>No Opinion Is Not An Option</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Documentary film makers necessarily bring a certain point of view with them: it is there in the material they have selected, in what they show and do not show, in how they work their bits of film together to make a cohesive statement. But while the vast majority of documentary film makers prefer to hide themselves behind the camera--and thus give the illusion of impartiality--Michael Moore does not. Not only director but also narrator, interviewer, and visible front man, he has no qualm in letting you know right out of the gate that the point of view is his own from start to finish.Most people will probably agree that it is a gutsy thing to do, but that is probably ALL they are likely to agree upon about BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE. Ask ten people what the film is about and you are likely to get ten different answers. Ask the same ten whether they liked it or not and you will probably get two extremes: they either loved it or they hated it. Those who love it tend to champion it as a powerful statement in favor of gun control. Those who hate it tend to consider it an inaccurate attack on gun owners in general and the NRA in particular.But I think it is a mistake to see the film from either stance. It is true that Moore has a lot to say about easy access to and irresponsible handling of firearms; it is also true that the NRA (not to mention then-president Charleton Heston) comes in for a major beating at his hands. But when all is said and done, BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE is no more "about" gun control or the NRA than it is about the infamous Columbine High School incident. When you get right down to the marrow, Moore seems to be making a comment on how both politicians and corporations work to take advantage of the paranoia created in the citizenry by a mass media focused on what is sensational rather than upon what is actually important.There has been a lot of complaint that Moore has fiddled the facts to suit his agenda and that BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE is riddled with inaccuracies. Indeed, there are entire websites (most of them little more than badly researched hysterical rants) devoted to the exposure of these flaws. But whether or not you buy into all or even most of Moore's data, it does seem to me that he has a valid overall point. To throw it out on the basis of surface errors--or still worse, the bizarre idea that documentaries should reside in some rarefied atmosphere of absolute impartiality--is an even greater error than any inaccuracy or bias that exists in the film itself.Whether you actually agree with the film or not, BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE is truly one film that will hold your attention to the bitter end: often laugh-out-loud funny, wildly satirical, bitterly ironic, opinionated, thought-provoking, and extremely disquieting, it makes a powerful statement.Gary F. Taylor, aka GFT, Amazon Reviewer</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>MovieAddict2016</username>

		<shortDescription>I don't respect Moore, but this is a well made documentary...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Documentaries are probably the hardest types of film to review, primarily because it all comes down to whether or not you agree with the filmmaker or not. Style helps, but you can't recommend a documentary you disagree with, can you?To come out with the truth before I get too far into this review, I will say that I totally disagree with Michael Moore on almost all subjects. To call him a liberal is an understatement -- so from a Republican's standpoint, it's very hard to give his film a good rating."Bowling for Columbine," like most of Moore's films, is seriously flawed. He presents a lot of information as truth when it is clearly not so. As entertaining as the History of the US cartoon was, it was also quite incorrect in many ways, and guess what -- killer bees DID come to America through Texas, even though he states that they never did.He doesn't bash the Bush administration as much as I thought he would, or any real political issues. He basically bashes American culture for allowing guns to flow so freely into the grasps of criminals and children.Moore is a lifetime member of the NRA, but he thinks guns should be handled with more caution. America has the highest rate of weapon-related deaths in all the world, and as this documentary shows, Britain, Canada, and other closely related countries have the exact same films, videogames, weapons, and so on. Why is America's gun crime so high?The film is centered on the Columbine shooting a few years back, when two students walked into Columbine high school and shot students, killing and injuring a large number of innocents. It was a wake up call for most of America, and Moore's real point of the documentary is to explore the reason America is so obsessed with guns.From a critical standpoint, the documentary is well made, probably deserving of its Oscar. It's touching and funny, disturbing and outrageous. Sometimes it's a bit too politically correct -- the whole exploration of African-Americans getting arrested more than Caucasians on the television show "COPS" is not only incorrect but sort of a laughable attempt on Moore's part to gain the respect of black viewers. I've watched "COPS" before, and a lot of white guys get arrested -- I can think of many arrests off the top of my head. I don't think that it's a valid point at all. America's reported fear of blacks is not why there are more shootings. Two survivors of the Columbine massacre accompany Moore towards the end of the film when he visits the Wal-Mart headquarters and requests that they stop selling 30-cent weapon ammunition -- the same ammunition bought by the Columbine shooters. Wal-Mart agrees, which is why you will no longer see gun ammo in Wal-Marts across the country.When "Halloween" came out in 1978, the six-year-old killer, Michael Myers, seemed even more evil and scary because he murdered at such a young age. Nobody thought that there could be a child like that. But, in "Bowling for Columbine," we are informed that a six-year-old school kid shot another young girl of the same age in a school cafeteria one day -- by accident, or so they say. That's when the documentary starts to become a horror film as opposed to an informative film. And it's better for it, too.It is our right as Americans to decide whether or not we should carry guns. I think the restrictions on letting guns fall into the wrong hands could be a bit more strict, but the criminals on the street will achieve weapons irregardless of whether or not Wal-Mart stops selling hunting rifles. In that sense, Moore's documentary is almost pointless. By the end, he never reveals why America is infatuated with guns. But his unresolved insight into why our nature is so influenced by violence is the highlight, and the remaining image of the little girl shot to death by a six-year-old boy will stay with you for a long, long time.Another problem with documentaries is that they can be twisted around and edited into whatever the filmmaker wants -- such as Moore's interview with Charlton Heston at the end of the film, or Dick Clark's refusal to speak to Moore, and so on and so forth. We don't know the background story on these things and we don't know what else was said before Moore fiddled around with the footage and crafted it into what he wanted. Splice together images of Heston saying, "From my cold dead hands!" and anything can look bad."Bowling for Columbine" is a very good film, and though I do not respect Michael Moore in any way, even I have to admit that he's made a good -- if flawed -- documentary about violence in America. He handles the content with care -- the way it should be handled -- and it can be both hilarious and saddening at the same time. I don't agree with everything in this film, but some of the real facts are pretty haunting. It's definitely one to check out.4.5/5 stars.- John Ulmer</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Bang, Bang, My Baby Shot Me Down</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Maybe it does not have the magnitude of when JFK was assassinated or when the Challenger exploded on that cold winter day, but the day of the Columbine shootings is etched into the minds of millions of Americans. Being from a small Georgian town, I grew up in an area where guns were ever present. Even when I went to high school quite a number of the boys had two hunting rifles on the gun racks within their pickup trucks. It never crossed my mind that one day one of these guys would bring a gun to school and blow off the principal's head. Even after reading Stephen King's novella Rage and watching the opening sequence of Scott Kalvert's The Basketball Diaries, the likelihood of such an event never crossed my mind. However, on April 20, 1999 while my roommate and I smoked cigarettes in our nonsmoking dorm room at the University of Georgia, we were informed by our local news station that two boys had shot up their school and killed several of their classmates and injured many, many more.While it might not be directly related to the Columbine Shooting, I came to have a strong dislike of guns, especially handguns that, in my opinion, have no other use than to kill people. I came to possess a fear of firearms and hate the idea of even having one near me. Therefore, it seemed, that Bowling for Columbine was made for people like me.Written of by many as a polemic against firearms, Bowling for Columbine actually focuses more on America, popular media, and the neurotic fear that supposedly resonates within a large number of Americans. Moore, with his tongue-in-cheek interviews, talks to several individuals who seem to be a bit less than stable, such as James Nichols, brother of Terry Nichols, and members of the Michigan based militia that Timothy McVeigh once belonged to. To balance things out he also interviews such normal individuals as Marilyn Manson and Matt Stone of South Park fame. However, where Bowling for Columbine truly shines is its caustic critique of the U.S. media that is saturated with blood. Also the documentary focuses on the portrayal of blacks in the media and how easy it is for whites to put the blame on blacks for crimes.While a bit heavy handed, and also quite condescending at times, I think Bowling for Columbine is a decent film about violence and media in America. While many rightists will not look past Moore's overweight and scruffy appearance, Moore succeeds in showing that there is something wrong with America: a country in which a seventeen year old can easily get his hands on firearms and purchase bullets at a department store to rampage and nearly destroy a community.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Can a man be a man in America without a gun?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon.)Did Charlton Heston get blind-sided by Michael Moore? Yes, but he's definitely old enough and savvy enough to know better. Did Moore gain entry to the Heston Hollywood mansion using false pretenses? No, he told the one-time celluloid god of the waters that he was a lifetime, paid-up member of the National Rifle Association, and once inside even showed his membership card. And, although the average guy in the street might be disarmed by Moore's folksy style and declasse dress code, Heston knew that Moore was a big time media guy (previous film: Roger and Me; book: Stupid White Men).But Heston never misses a chance to spread the Second Amendment gospel. He just thought he could handle the situation. There's no fool like an old fool, they say. To his credit, when he realized that he had fallen into a trap, he moseyed off, putting one gimpy leg carefully in front of the other as he carried a bent back and a 79-year-old frame off camera.Well, was this fair? Indeed, was the entire film fair? No, of course not. This is Michael Moore simultaneously making a buck, building a rep, and working a cause. The cause is something like 11,000 dead-by-gunshot Americans every year (a pretty good cause), and the target is indeed Charlton Heston, long-time spokesman not only for God, but more significantly, the NRA, and of course gun and ammo manufacturers and sellers. So at least we can say that Michael Moore was after big game.He mostly bagged them too (and made Dick Clark look heartless), but somehow I didn't gain much satisfaction. I don't care much for Charlton Heston, either as an actor or a proselytizer, but I am finding, after watching this and Fahrenheit 9/11, that I don't care much for Michael Moore either. I think all good, right-thinking liberals should continue to play fair even though the opposition might not. This film preached to the choir and a good time was had by all who agree with Moore's point of view. The cover on this DVD even quotes Time Magazine as saying the film is "hilarious." Somehow though I don't think those on the right thought it was all that funny. And I wonder if those in the middle were swayed one way or the other. It is indeed heartbreaking that kids in this country pick up guns and shoot each other, and the fact that they do it much more often per capita than any other country in the First World does indeed call for an explanation. Ironically, I think Heston actually had the answer. This is a violent country with a violent history relative to other industrial nations. Moore and Heston agreed that our history isn't more violent than, say, Germany's, but they got their ideas confused. In Germany the violence was by the state and its armies and its police. We have plenty of that as well of course, but in the US we also have a tradition of the handy six-shooter in the holster for a quick draw and a further tradition of celebrating the rugged individual who stands up against the state and anyone wanting to take his arms away.Personally I think there's a lot to be said and not said for both sides in this all too American debate. The Freudian implication that would-be macho guys need guns symbolically to feel like men is very real. It was no accident that Heston let slip the "multi-ethnic" rationale for explaining all those dead by firearms in the USA, a rationale that is usually interpreted to mean fear of a big black dude breaking into one's home. Or actually that is often a sort of "make my day" fantasy indulged in by some randy militia types as they sip a little Jack Daniels on the front porch swing as they fondle their weapon.Well, what's the answer? There is no answer. It is a gradual process from the jungle to civilization, and the US, in this gun-toting regard, is just a little behind the rest of the West. If Michael Moore wants to focus on some people who really adore their weapons, he should take a trip to Iraq or Afghanistan, or just watch the nightly news.Still this is worth seeing as a kind of Americana snapshot portfolio. Marilyn Manson proves a fine foil for Charlton Heston, and the Afro-American elementary school principal can be balanced against the poor little black kid who shot the little white girl, who can be contrasted with the members of the NRA who think the black kid should be tried as an adult, who can be contrasted with the kids at Columbine who were just there when it happened. And the mentality of Moore and his crew in imagining that they won a "victory" against K-Mart when it agreed to take the ammo off it shelves can be contrasted with the young dude who was disappointed that he wasn't named a number one collaborating suspect. (Actually the ammo sales are small potatoes to K-Mart which has big management and bottom-line problems.) But see this to study the techniques used by Moore. Oh, where, oh, where has the concept of objective journalism gone--or did it ever exist in the first place?</fullReview>

This documentary explains why it in America is so much higher than in other countries, or at least it tries to...No, "Bowling for Columbine" is not always completely fair and some of the points brought up are not convincing enough. An huge contradiction if you ask me...But than again, the documentary has some strong moments and good and interesting points. It by the way really shocked me and seemed amazing by me that they sold bullets at a store such as the Walmart that literally is at every corner of every town. But the thing that tops everything is the final interview with NRA President Charlton Heston, it was really 'wow' for me.Unlike other documentaries, this one isn't ever boring mainly because it also contains lot's of humor and is very straight to the point and contains some good interviews and points. 		<date>2005-07-08</date>
		<username>Jackson Booth-Millard</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Bowling for Columbine</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This documentary film is one of the most interesting ideas there has been, especially from director Michael Moore. He documents the story of guns and their use in the United States of America. He includes information about deaths in all countries by gun fire, what inspires people to do it, and how easy it is to get a gun and use it. But most of the main focus is about the brutal incident at Columbine school where two young boys killed many students, a teacher and then themselves. Michael Moore adds small bits of comedy to add interest, including a cartoon, and he picks good interviewees from public, press and politics to answer the questions. Starring Moore himself, Marilyn Manson, South Park co-creator Matt Stone (a former Columbine student), and NRA (National Rifle Association) president and Oscar winning actor, Charlton Heston. It won the Oscar for Best Documentary, Features, and it won the Cannes Film Festival 55th Anniversary Prize, and it was nominated the Golden Palm. It was number 3 on The 50 Greatest Documentaries. Very good!</fullReview>
